DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1987[COGNATE BILLS:INCOME TAX AMENDMENT BILL(No. 2) 1987MEDICARE LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1987]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 21 October, on motion by Mr Holding:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the debate is resumed on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1987, I remind the House that it has been agreed that a general debate be allowed covering this Bill, the Income Tax Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987 and the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill 1987.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crawford Ms M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in support of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1987, the Income Tax Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987 and the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill 1987. I am incredulous that speakers on the other side of the House should have spoken about fairness in the tax system. I find it incredible, for as we all know when the Opposition was in government it supported the whole basis of the tax evasion industry and, in fact, pursued it. Since my time as a member of this Parliament its opposition to the Australia Card Bill has been based simply on the support of tax cheats and tax evaders. The fact that the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) can claim that one of the major growth industries under his term as Treasurer was tax evasion is a testament to the kinds of policies on tax reform which the Opposition espouses.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian public has rejected such-not once, not twice, but three times. The Australian public is not stupid. It stands for fairness, it stands for equity, and it stands for a just taxation system. While we acknowledge that Opposition members are slow learners it seems extraordinary that they continue to oppose matters of tax reform which the Australian public has wholeheartedly embraced.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I seek your indulgence, and not in a facetious manner. May we be issued with earphones?
—The honourable member will resume his seat. He is out of order.

—I draw to the attention of honourable members the Opposition's debate on the fringe benefit tax, to its very real opposition to the introduction of such a tax, to how it claimed that the hotel industry would collapse and the res- taurant industry would be in disarray, and in fact, that tourism would no longer exist. Madam Speaker, let me tell you of a restaurateur in my electorate whose opposition to the fringe benefits tax was enormous. He has recently won an award. His restaurant has gone on to become exceedingly successful. People are swarming through his doors and he has become a very successful businessman, despite his railing against the fringe benefits tax. Such opposition to measures of fairness and equity within our community is what we have come to expect from the Opposition. But as we all know, the public does not accept that.

SPEECH.PARA: In fact, the fringe benefits tax has been responsible for one of the major advances in social justice within our community-the introduction of the family assistance package via our Budget. The fringe benefits tax provided the basis, along with moneys from tax cheats and social welfare cheats, on which we could provide very real assistance to poor working families, to enable them to have cash in their hands for their children. Indeed, this is what this Government is about-addressing the very real needs of real Australian workers who are fighting to pay off mortgages and to keep their children in schools.

It is only with policies of tax reform and social justice that we can move to such a result. Indeed, we are the Government of tax reform. Such provisions as we have put in place for sub-contractors have been welcomed within my electorate. Many of those people who, prior to that, operated on the black market and within the cash economy have found themselves willingly drawn in to be part of our taxation system. No longer are they at the margins of society. No longer do they need to look behind their backs. They know exactly what their tax bill is, and they know that they are making a very real commitment to their community and that they are very much part of Australian society. They are happy to join with those provisions because they know them to be fair. Let us face it: this is what these tax amendment Bills are about-the creation of a fairer and more just society.

The pay as you earn group within our society has for too long borne the brunt of the payments within our taxation system. For too long companies, wealthy financiers and others have escaped the payment of tax. Of course they are unwilling to pay it now. They have not been part of our society and they have not contributed to our community in any real way, other than in the making of money for themselves and for their own benefit. They do not see their role as being part of the creation of a society in which we can all participate.

So it is with pleasure that we see the amendment Bills raise the rebate for married couples to $430, and that the margin for taxation for single people is raised to $5,850 and for married couples to $10,350. This is an acknowledgment that it is the pay as you earn people within our community who have supported the taxation system for too long. The fact that we will now be requiring companies and the capital gains tax to contribute to our community and our society at large shows a very real commitment on the part of this Government to move down the path of social justice.

Another issue that the Bill addresses is the Medicare levy. Australian society now accepts the delivery of health services to all members of its community as a right. But during the last election campaign we heard the Leader of the Opposition declare that he would dismantle Medicare. The Australian public failed to buy that. In fact, he suggested that health care should be provided to only those people who had $250 in their pocket-and $250 for every member of a family, which for an average Australian family would have meant $1,000. He would make health care the prerogative of the rich. My Government does not seek to do such a thing.

We are committed to Medicare. We believe that the future of this country and the future of its citizens depend upon good health care. Medicare has some very severe critics in the form of the doctors and the medical associations. Because they are unable to charge whatever prices they want, because they are not given a free rein, they believe they should not participate in Medicare. But let me remind the House that the very real losers in the doctors' campaign against Medicare are the patients whom the doctors supposedly, under their hippocratic oath, care for.

Medicare is here to stay. Medicare is part of the Australian way of life. It represents a fair go for all. It means that health is the right of every citizen of this country. Those who can afford to pay must pay to ensure that all of us are participants in health care. The raising of the Medicare levy to 1.25 per cent is an acknowledgment of the way in which our community has moved. The raising of the margins to $8,980 for single people and $15,090 for married couples, with $2,100 for each dependent child, is an acknowledgment of the kind of people who most need our support within the community. We as a government acknowledge them. We as a government acknowledge that we must care about them.

These Bills represent the Government's commitment to a more just and fair society. They take us down the path of reform which was set when this Government came to office two parliaments ago. It is, indeed, an acknowledgment that we as a community must all work together and participate not just in the wealth of this country but also in the distribution of that wealth through a fair and just tax system. I support these Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —This package of legislation, the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3), the Income Tax Amendment Bill (No. 2) and the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill, has come about because this Government considers that it knows better than every Australian and it is going to redirect its resources in a way that suits the Government rather than the citizens of this nation. The last election gave this Government an opportunity on coming into office to exercise restraint and to provide benefits in a way that the community is willing to accept. That opportunity has been missed for a combination of reasons. The two basic reasons have been the personal ambitions of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) within the Australian Labor Party and the lack of determination of the ALP due to union controls.

SPEECH.PARA: The personal ambitions of the Treasurer can be dealt with briefly; he sees himself as the successor to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), and an air of popularity is necessary for such a successful election within the ALP. I point out to members of the Government that, even within his own electorate, the people of Bankstown strongly rejected the policies and attitudes of the Treasurer with a 9 per cent swing against him-the largest swing against the Labor Party around Australia-at the last election. The Treasurer is seen as elitist and remote from the needs of real Australians.

This legislation does nothing to recapture the concern that the Australian Labor Party should be expressing for the citizens of Australia. The Government has missed the chance to take steps of restraint and to provide benefits for Australians. Rather, it has seen this as an opportunity to increase taxes and impose more restrictions on the average Australian family.

The union control of the Government in the circumstances leading up to the Budget-a theme that will continue right through its years in government-is easily demonstrated when one looks at the Government's incapacity to control the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) in relation to the sanctions against Fiji. Despite the complaints and comments of Ministers in this Parliament over the last two days, nothing has been done to remove the intransigence of the union movement and its ideological commitment to damage the economy of Fiji. The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden) and the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) both have deplored the actions of the ACTU without any effect.

One has to look only at the Budget to see the impact of union control of this Government because the Government has accepted, without the full process of the two-tier wages system going through, that there will be an automatic flow-on of 6 per cent to all wage and salary earners in Australia. That 6 per cent is the predicted increase in wages and salaries across the board as contained in the Budget Papers. Therefore, before the negotiations on work conditions have been concluded, the Government has accepted the 6 per cent as a natural flow-on. So the increases in productivity that are sought may be illusory and may, in fact, not be delivered. The Government has agreed with the union movement that that 6 per cent will be achieved.

There was a chance, I believe, for the Government to move forward in an atmosphere of restraint and with the co-operation of the Australian people. They understood the seriousness of Australia's economic circumstances and were willing to take some reduction in government expenditure provided there was an easing in the dreadful and biting taxes, the pervasive taxes, that have been imposed by this Government and which have reached into every aspect of human endeavour.

The willingness of the Australian community to co-operate with the Government in restraint, with a real eye to the future potential of bringing Australia back into the world economy and of providing benefits for all Australians, has been bypassed. But Australians did see the options at the last election, and the fact that more Australians voted for the Opposition is a clear demonstration, I think that they understood the facts that were on the board. The fact that the Australian Labor Party could, by electoral processes, gain more seats, is a real anomaly; it proves how inequitable the current redistribution and the current political system are. We have to thank the former Special Minister of State for the processes that actually won the Opposition more votes than the Australian Labor Party, yet it is not in government. I note in passing that that type of situation created a constitutional crisis in the island of Malta. It altered its constitution to take account of the fact that the majority of voters across the nation should express the real intent of the people.

The fact that the policies of the Opposition were understood can be put down to the proposals that were put forward in the election campaign that now is the time for restraint in government expenditure, now is the time to reduce the cost of government to the Australian people and to give that cost reduction back to those people who best know how to spend their own money. I remind the House that the proposals that were put forward by the coalition before the election campaign were a reduction of the top marginal rate of income tax from 49 per cent to 38 per cent, a flatter two-tier tax structure of 25 per cent and 38 per cent, a clear bias within the personal tax scales towards families with children and an increase in the tax free threshold from $5,100 to $5,900 to protect low income earners. In this Budget the Government has chosen to increase taxes mainly from pay as you earn taxpayers and then dole back those proceeds.

The philosophical differences are clear if one examines the approaches that the two parties have adopted. Before the election our proposition was that we would leave more money with the people who earned it and give bias in favour of low income earners and people with families. The Government, in a prescriptive way, has decided to collect the money anyway and hand it back on the basis of the formulas contained in this legislation. We are ideologically at odds with that approach. We do not believe that it is appropriate for a government to impose its own view of society in the way in which this Government seeks to do with these amendments.

The fact of the matter is that the Government's tax raising effort in the Budget is really significant. Pay as you earn taxpayers will pay 6.5 per cent more. That is not a reflection of increased productivity or anything like that; it is the fact that the Government expects to collect a lot more tax. So, as the rate of inflation increases tax gatherings will increase. Nobody will be better off in his or her normal pay packet.

In addition to that impost on pay as you earn taxpayers, I point out to the House that small investors and those running small businesses will be up for an 11 per cent uplift on provisional tax in the forthcoming year. That 11 per cent is the calculation in the Budget Papers for the increase in what provisional taxpayers will be providing ahead of the time at which they are required to pay taxation. That calculation of 11 per cent is based traditionally on the projected expectation of inflation for the forthcoming year. It has nothing to do with expectations as to profitabi-lity. It is a calculation that the Treasury can put forward, based on the sound grounds of its expectation of the increase in the consumer price index. But in this instance the Government has chosen to claw back 11 per cent, not 6 per cent as one might expect. The capital gains tax yielded in the Budget $50m or $110m more than expected. Company taxation is up from 46 per cent to 49 per cent. Fringe benefits tax collections are up by 40.1 per cent to $750m. The prescribed payments tax collections increased last year by 48 per cent and will increase this year by 9.1 per cent-a total of $835m.

One can go through the Budget and see the tax raising exercise-in duties, fees and the many techniques which are used to spread a tax increase across the board. The Government is raising more money. That is what the Australian Labor Party fails to recognise. The Government has balanced its books by grabbing more from the Australian community and flogging off a few assets. In that way it claims to have produced a balanced Budget. Well, it is not balanced, and the whole community knows that. In fact, it is being achieved by additional tax grabs. There is no compensation for the Australian community for what the Government has done. I think that the bodgie Budget outcome that is produced by asset sales and tax increases leaves the Australian community not only poorer but also less equipped to take this nation forward, driven by incentive and opportunity. The Treasurer, in his approach, is really saying that we must have big government; that it must be acceptable to the Australian community that we continue with big government. That is not the case. There are plenty of examples to indicate that a country such as Australia does not need, and will not benefit from, big government and big government taxation.

There is no real consideration for families, apart from the small measures contained in this legislation. It is a prescriptive approach. But Australian families wanted some relief; they needed some incentive-and I point out again that more families voted for my Party than for the Australian Labor Party at the last election. Look at the young people in Australia today, those seeking a chance, an opportunity and some incentive. It is deplorable that the Government can continue to lift taxation and expect people to achieve things. One has only to look around and see the enthusiasm of young Australians for a more moderate tax regime, better restraint and more rigor on the part of the Government. There is no incentive. The country is floating into stagnation because the Treasurer has been unwilling to take hard, firm decisions.

What we are doing is waiting for our birthday party. It is like a family who has borrowed some dough so that they can have a birthday celebration. The Government has borrowed the money to celebrate Australia's 200th anniversary, to the detriment of Australian people. The country will wake up at the end of the birthday and find that the cupboard is bare and that we owe a lot of money around the world. It is not responsible management. The satisfaction, the sense of achievement and the pride of success that is needed in the Bicentenary cannot be there because we have been self-indulgent. The Government has put our birthday party on tick, and that is a tragedy. It has missed an opportunity, a short period of unpopularity with those sections of the Australian community-it is mainly the Government's supporters-which think government should provide everything. The situation would be resolved very quickly with additional job opportunities, an expanding economy and a more competitive nation. Government does not have to be involved.

In this legislation there is just a small indication of the way in which things can be done if the Government would so choose. I refer to a program which few Australians know about but which is of great and deep significance to this country, and that is the Australian-Hellenic Memorial. This legislation gives tax deductibility to donations to that memorial. The Government is just giving a tax deduction; it is not building the memorial. It is saying to those people of Australian and Greek background, `Let us remember the great traditions that were established between our two nations over a long period but particularly in the First and Second World Wars'. The tax deductibility of donations will cost little and is an incentive to achieve.

Instead, the Government has chosen in its bicentenary program and many of its other programs to pay the whole bill. The last figure I saw for the cost of the Bicentenary was over $400m of taxpayers' money. The Americans had their Bicentenary at a cost of $10m. The rest was an incentive to private enterprise and individuals to get out and to celebrate. But no, this Government has to collect the money and pay for the lot: it is spendthrift waste on every front. One has only to wander around Darling Harbour to see some of it. One need not move far out of Canberra to see some of the bicentenary waste because the Government feels that it must pay for the projects. It does not trust the people with having some incentive to do something worth while; that is what the Australian-Hellenic Memorial proposals do. I do not know why the Government cannot pick up this example and use it as a model for future activity because the memorial is being constructed to commemorate those who died in the Greek campaigns of the Second World War, particularly in the Battle for Crete.

The Greek community has contributed a great deal to this nation. If there is any bond that is strong it is that between Australians and the people of Greece or Crete who were involved in the great conflict of the Second World War. One has only to visit Crete to understand the continuing link and feeling that is still there. It is a bond that cannot be expressed or denied by government, but it can be encouraged by government. It is being encouraged by this Government, and I endorse what it has done. But it is a great shame that in the tax area the Government has not seen that the need to give people incentive is part of a complete and worthwhile tax regime.

The terrible experiences that people went through in the Second World War will be commemorated in Canberra. The work that the Chairman of the Australian-Hellenic Memorial Committee, Sir William Refshauge, and the patrons-the Archbishop of Sydney, Archbishop Stylianos, Major-General Sir Ivan Dougherty and Major-General Ian Campbell-are doing is to be commended. It is exceptional work, and they are a driving force of fine Australians who want to see that bond, that memory and that commitment to individual liberty, freedom and the democratic principles that the Greek nation stands for enshrined here in Canberra at the War Memorial. Having mentioned that part of the legislation, I just wish to return to my main theme.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are not going to return to the Bill, are you?

—I have been talking about the Bill. That interjection shows the Minister's lack of knowledge. The matters I have raised concerning the Australian War Memorial make up a very important part of the Bill and I am surprised, because of the Minister's background and claimed knowledge of these issues, that he was not aware of that. The Government has seen fit to increase taxation, as I have said, on pay as you earn taxpayers and on small business. It dampens incentive and reins back productive activity by increasing its tax stranglehold on this country, and then it hands out in a patronising way to those poor families of Australia what it considers appropriate.

SPEECH.PARA: The difference in the living standards of the poor and the wealthy is one of the reasons why the Left of the Australian Labor Party is taking up the call for an investigation of wealth. Members of the Labor Party know that. They have encouraged this division; they have encouraged their wealthy friends and have not watched carefully enough the well-being of those constituents they claim to represent-those who are less well off. They have neglected them, and the result achieved by the Treasurer in his own electorate is an indication of the way the people feel about the treatment of those who are less well off. The Government will not alleviate the problem by adopting a prescriptive approach. What it has to do is take the reins off the Australian community to a greater degree and apply a rigor and a discipline to government expenditure, which it has not been prepared to do. By taking that approach it will draw into active participation those families with low incomes, those families with medium incomes and of course the wealthy. They will come together to work as a nation.

I have never seen policies as divisive as those of this Government. It has divided the Australian community into various strata. That is a great shame. I can understand the Left wanting a wealth inquiry, although I do not endorse it. That would also be divisive, though maybe its ultimate objective is to divide the country in that way. It is time for the Government to be positive and adopt positive policies.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Johns Mr G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make some analytical remarks this morning on the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill 1987, which will enable me to introduce debate on Medicare itself. The Bill is designed to amend the Medicare Levy Act to declare and impose the basic rate of Medicare levy for 1987-88 and for all subsequent income years. As announced in the 1986-87 Budget, the basic rate of the levy will be 1.25 per cent of taxable income. That rate has been effective since 1 December 1986. The Bill also contains increases in the income threshold levels, and people with incomes below that threshold will not be called upon to pay any levy-a significant achievement indeed.

SPEECH.PARA: For 1987-88 and subsequent income years individuals with taxable incomes of $8,980 or less and married couples and sole parents with family incomes of $15,090 or less will not be required to pay the levy. The income threshold for married couples and sole parents will increase by a further $2,100 for each dependent child or student. For example, a married couple with two dependent children will pay no levy until their combined taxable incomes exceed $19,290. In other words, more Australians are being freed from the burden of medical costs. Those who can least afford to become ill are being protected by Medicare and further protected with this amendment.

It is a pity that this debate on Medicare allows people with an axe to grind to peddle a series of myths about our public health system. I wish to take up some of the most common myths and, in turn, strike them down. The most common of these myths are that Medicare has caused waiting lists in public hospitals; that its bulk billing mechanism leads to overservicing; that Medicare is inequitable because it subsidises the rich; that it destroys freedom of choice; and that it is a first step towards nationalised medicine.

I want to draw from two excellent documents which shed a great deal of light on this matter, because I am afraid that in these debates we often deal in rhetoric. I propose not to deal in rhetoric; rather, I will deal in facts this morning. The first paper is by Dr John Deeble, written in September 1987, and entitled `Health Care Under Universal Insurance: The First 3 Years of Medicare'. It is an excellent document. The second is a paper entitled `Medicare a Doubled-edged Sword' produced by the Health Issues Centre, Victoria. It is important to remember what Medicare is and what it is not. Medicare is a health insurance program to provide basic cover for medical and hospital treatment. But it is not a total funding system for all health. It is certainly not a scheme of income maintenance for doctors. Medicare extended the public benefits to the whole population. Its introduction in 1984 provided insurance for private medical fees to around 2.3 million additional Australians-that is, 16 per cent of the population. Previously, those people were not covered; they had to think about becoming ill. They no longer have to think about becoming ill; they are covered by Medicare.

In addition to those five myths that I want to discuss, there are assertions that Medicare is administratively expensive and has increased health as a cost to the nation. On the first point, the previous system of paying medical benefits through about 70 private health funds was costly and inefficient. Centralising the payment function in one fund-that is Medicare-has saved over $100m a year in administrative costs. Administration costs for Medicare are about 4.6 per cent compared with around 14 per cent for medical benefits delivery through the major funds prior to Medicare-significant savings. On the second point, the proportion of all health expenditure to gross domestic product (GDP) has, since the introduction of Medicare, been virtually stable. In fact, it has even declined slightly. Health expenditure as a proportion of GDP in 1983-84 was 7.6 per cent; in 1985-86, the latest figure, it was 7.5 per cent. It is a myth that health is costing Australians more. It should never be forgotten that Medicare is a part of the prices and incomes accord. Living standards have been held by virtue of the social wage, a major component of which is Medicare. In other words, Medicare has played a part in maintaining our central economic management program, the prices and incomes accord.

Now to the myths. We hear much of Medicare's supposed involvement in hospital queues around the country. Let me remind people that running the public hospital system is traditionally a State responsibility. However, the issue of waiting times for elective surgery, particularly in some specialist procedures, has been unjustifiably depicted as Medicare related. State governments have already identified the reasons underlying the waiting lists. These are as follows: first, we know that there are nursing shortages which result in bed closures. Second, we know that there is an undersupply of some specialists such as orthopaedic and ophthalmic surgeons. Third, advances in technology, which allow previously difficult or dangerous procedures to be more routinely performed, have drawn more people into the system. And of course, most importantly, there is now a greater public awareness and higher expectation leading to an increased demand for these services.

Some States are coping with those hospital queues or at least they are trying to be creative in finding a solution. They are developing a range of programs to address particular bottlenecks. For example, New South Wales and Victoria are dedicating funds to specific proposals designed to reduce waiting times and have already achieved some impressive results. It is worth remembering that nearly 2 1/2 million people were treated in public hospitals last year. Indeed, last year more people were treated in Australian hospitals-both public and private-than in any previous year. Whilst the Federal Government would not wish to be seen as intervening in an area of State responsibility, there is scope for it to develop a program which will support and maintain the momentum of current State initiatives. Honourable members will be well aware, of course, that this Government has introduced a two-year hospital waiting list assistance program which will provide $25m a year over two years from 1987-88. These funds will be available for specific State government programs where it can be clearly demonstrated that they will have a real impact on waiting times. Funding within the two-year program will be on a dollar for dollar basis with the States and the continuation of funding will be based on the results achieved.

I will provide examples of programs which could be funded under this initiative. First, we could create more dedicated facilities-that is, a more efficient throughput could be obtained if the hospital area were dedicated to a particular speciality. Secondly, we have programs to increase the number of nurses. This has the potential to increase significantly elective surgery capacity, thus reducing queues. Thirdly, the development or expansion of same day surgery facilities-treating patients in dedicated day surgery facilities-is the most cost-effective and efficient means of carrying out many procedures. On present estimates as many as 35 per cent of all operations could be undertaken on a day surgery basis. With matching State funds more than $100m will be made available over the two years of this new program.

I come now to the second myth-that bulk billing leads to overservicing. The basic aim of Medicare is to break down the financial barriers which prevent people from using the health services they need. Many people argue that in eliminating this barrier Medicare has created another problem-excessive and unnecessary use of medical services. This argument relates particularly to bulk billing. Advocates of the view claim that, when people pay no money from their own pockets for each health service, there is no incentive for them to limit the numbers and types of services available to them. No doubt the argument is attractive, but there is simply no evidence to support that myth.

Numerous overseas studies have shown that overall use of medical services is reasonably unaffected by price changes. Using a large United States study, an Australian economist recently estimated that the payment of 25 per cent out of pocket expenses for medical services, lead to a 5.7 per cent reduction in the use of services, but a 50 per cent out of pocket payment reduced use by only 7.6 per cent. This is probably because most people use services when they need them, irrespective of cost and certainly irrespective of any marginal increase in cost. We must remember that most doctors have professional standards about overservicing. The price does not seem to affect the use of the service. That is essential to remember. The lack of connection between cost and use has been confirmed in another recent study of the billing practices of all doctors in Australia. The study revealed that the number of services per person barely changes from doctors who bulk bill most people or doctors who bulk bill few people. The same study shows that bulk billing may be important for a very small percentage of doctors-probably only about 100 in the whole of Australia-who provide many more services per person than the average doctor. These doctors are likely to act in an unscrupulous way under any system of payment. They are not beholden to Medicare for their dastardly deeds.

It would be unfair to deny people the benefits of bulk billing simply to attempt-probably unsuccessfully-to prevent a small number of doctors from abusing Medicare. There are other ways of preventing these doctors from misusing Medicare. It must be remembered that any such action would also have an inequitable effect on low income people. The removal of bulk billing would defeat one of the major purposes of Medicare, that is, to stop financial difficulties being a barrier to medical care for low income groups.

The growth in the use of and spending on medical services has been rising throughout the last decade. That is true. But it has done so with or without Medicare and bulk billing. Between mid-1975 and mid-1983, pathology use increased by 105 per cent. Radiology increased by 55 per cent. There was an overall increase in medical services of only 20 per cent. With Medicare, there has been a slight increase in the use of services. However, that is to be expected because we have removed the financial barriers which have prevented people from using medical services. Medicare itself has not caused any blowout in health spending.

Let us take the third myth-that Medicare is inequitable because it subsidises the rich. The claim that Medicare is inequitable because it subsidises the rich is a commonly heard myth. Those who argue this refer to the health care system of 20 years ago, when people who could afford to use private health services paid out of their own pockets and poor people used public hospitals or were provided services by doctors as charity. The old charity model is no longer accepted as a way of ensuring that people on low incomes have their basic needs met. It is stigmatising and demeaning.

But apart from the stigma aspect, there are strong reasons to believe that Medicare is more equitable than the previous private health insurance system. All people with an income above a specified level, as I outlined before, pay for Medicare through the Medicare levy. Under the pre-Medicare system all people with income paid the same minimum amount for their health insurance, regardless of how much they could afford. Prior to Medicare, the lower a family unit's income, the higher the percentage of its income went to paying for medical insurance. For example, a family on the average weekly wage of $304 in 1981 paid 2.2 per cent for basic medical and hospital cover, while a family on a weekly wage of $465 paid only 1.4 per cent of its income for the same benefits. In short, Medicare is more equitable because people pay for health services on the basis of their capacity to pay.

I turn to two other myths. One is the old chestnut that Medicare destroys freedom of choice. Medicare has expanded people's choice. We should not forget that two million Australians, prior to the introduction of Medicare, had no choice. They could not afford to become ill. We have given to 16 per cent of the Australian population, for the first time, a real choice. They can now afford to become ill. They can go to their local general practitioner, be referred to a specialist and go to the best hospitals in the country. Before Medicare those people were not covered. They could not afford any choices.

Medicare provides the added freedom of a cheaper basic medical and hospital cover than any offered by private health insurance funds prior to Medicare. These funds offered only limited choices and marginal differences in price. For example, a person could not only insure to be seen by the doctor on duty in a public hospital but also she or he had to take an insurance package which included cover for a private hospital and the doctor of the person's choice. If a person needs further treatment that person's choice is usually limited to specialists who are nominated by the general practitioner. Generally, people's choice of doctors is more restricted by the lack of information available on hours, billing practice and competence of doctors than by their health insurance status.

Let me take the last myth-that Medicare is the thin end of the wedge and that it will lead to a nationalised medical system. The myth that Medicare will lead to the type of nationalised health system that exists in England is a scare tactic which ignores some basic facts. First, Medicare actually underwrites, rather than threatens to replace, the private medical system in Australia. It is a huge public subsidy which strengthens our existing system. Many people who support Medicare have often seen this as its great weakness. We see it as its great strength. It supports the entire private medical system. Secondly, it is constitutionally impossible for any government actually to control doctors' fees or to make all doctors come on to the government payroll. So it is simply a myth to talk about a nationalised health care system.

I now move to a discussion of medical fees, dear to the hearts not only of public and private sector doctors but also of this Government. The lack of control over doctors' fees has been one of the thorniest problems faced by any Federal government. The medical profession has strongly resisted attempts to control fees due to the belief that neither government nor non-medical groups should in any way regulate the profession. The fear that the Government might nationalise health services has also prompted vociferous opposition to control over fees. Another crucial factor has been the desire to keep doctors' incomes at a high level. This justification has been criticised by our Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) who stated:
The Government is running a health insurance scheme, not a doctors' income maintenance scheme.

The effectiveness of Medicare, to the extent that it is limited, is limited because of the lack of control over doctors fees. I will cite some interesting examples of doctors fees in Queensland as opposed to those for the rest of the country. There was a similar lack of success in ensuring the predictability of the level of fees as far back as the early 1970s. In 1973 a medical fees tribunal was established by the then Labor Government. The following facts came to light. In Queensland, the level of observance of medical fees--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to take the opportunity today, which is provided by the Bills before the House-the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1987, the Income Tax Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987 and the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill 1987-to talk about something absolutely fundamental to Australian society. It is often said that we Australians are an apathetic lot and that we do not take nearly enough interest in some of our basic institutions. In a sense that is right, although it is also a reflection on Australian society that we are lucky. We do not have to worry about some of the really basic freedoms because we have them. We do not have to worry about the rights that people have in regard to wrongful imprisonment because habeas corpus has been part of our common law tradition. In fact, it is a very old tradition, going back to the Magna Carta in 1215. That is a long time ago, but it is a law and a concept that is as relevant today as it has been for over 700 years.

SPEECH.PARA: The former Chief Justice, Sir Harry Gibbs, when talking about the Bill of Rights, questioned whether we need a Bill of Rights in a country such as Australia when we have these rights already. Then he contrasted that with the statement: `If you need a Bill of Rights, you really have problems'. In fact that point was picked up by Judge Scalia, a member of the Supreme Court of the United States. He came to Australia to attend the law conference held in Perth and he read out part of a Bill of Rights. It was a tremendous Bill. It had absolutely everything in it, plus the kitchen sink. It had rights against wrongful imprisonment, rights of freedom of speech and guaranteed rights of freedom of religion. And where was that Bill of Rights to be found and entrenched? It was in the constitution of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. That is very much a feature of Australian society. We are lucky, as we go into 1988, that so many of these rights are very firmly interwoven into the fabric of Australian society.

Whilst I say that, I have to remember my responsibilities to the people in my electorate of Flinders, south-east of Melbourne, who sent me to Canberra. They say to me, `One of your duties is to be concerned about some of these issues'. Since being appointed shadow Attorney-General by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), I have spent more time looking at some of these fundamental issues. That has brought me to note the provision in one of these Bills before the House, which is to provide tax deductibility for donations to the Lionel Murphy Foundation. The Opposition does not oppose that clause, which is part of the Bill which we do not oppose. But I do want to draw members' attention to a concept which is to be promoted by the Lionel Murphy Foundation. It is to be promoted with our taxes and, so, is obviously a matter very relevant to this Bill, and it is important that we look at it.

The Foundation includes, for example, an intention `to study international law as a developing force for peace and as a means of achieving the rule of law in all nations'. That is a highly commendable objective and one which I strongly endorse. Peace is one of the great issues of our time. I think it is absolutely right and proper that we look to that issue and look at international law as part and parcel of that issue and as a mechanism for working towards and achieving peace. As difficult an issue as it is, it is obviously one which we on this side of the House, and those on the Government side, believe is one we should work to. However, one of the other objectives is `to study law and the legal system in a social context' and another is `to study law and the legal system as a means of attaining social justice and human rights and as vehicles for change'. This concept of social justice has a lot of currency in Australian Labor Party circles.

TALK.START.PARA: —It doesn't have much in your circles, that's for sure.

—Well, for very good reason, Minister, which I will come to. The concept of social justice is a term which was used by the honourable member for Forde (Ms Crawford) in her address-which simply brought to mind how good a member was the previous member for Forde, Dr David Watson. I hope, for the sake of this Parliament, that Dr Watson will find himself back here, because, regardless of which side of the House we are on, people such as Dr Watson make a tremendous contribution to Australia. I think this is a place that could do with his further contributions in the future. The Labor Party in Victoria even has a policy which I understand is called a policy for social justice. It is a term which we hear much about. The view I am putting today is basically that it is a perversion of the term `justice' to put those two words together as `social justice'.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me give the House the definition of `justice' from the fifth edition of Osborn's Concise Law Dictionary, which defines `justice' as: `the upholding of rights, and the punishment of wrongs, by the law'. I think that is a reasonable definition. I looked for some others, and the Oxford Dictionary refers to `justice' as: `just conduct; fairness'-and I think perhaps most relevant to what I am saying today-`exercise of authority in maintenance of right'. At the convention in Perth, Lord Ackner of the House of Lords gave a very interesting and good address, if I may say so. He referred to the following quote from Lord Sankey, who was Lord Chancellor, who said at a dinner given at the Mansion House by the Lord Mayor of London to His Majesty's judges:

Amid the cross currents and shifting sands of public life the law is like a great rock upon which a man may set his feet and be safe, while the inevitable inequalities of private life are not so dangerous in a country where every citizen knows that in the Law Courts, at any rate, he can get justice . . .

I think that is as good a definition for our purposes today as one could get. He talks about law as being like a great rock. Of course, that raises the concept which I think is better known to us, and that is the concept of the rule of law.

If that is all a bit heavy-and I realise it is-let me put it in another way, for example by referring to Australian rules football. I am a Victorian, and my boys enjoy it, as I used to, although I do not enjoy it so much now. Imagine that half-way through the last quarter of a game of footy the umpire blows the whistle and changes all the rules. He says that instead of getting six points for kicking the ball through the middle, the team will get only one point, but will get six for kicking it through the two outer posts. If that happened, particularly in a grand final in Melbourne, there would be absolute uproar. The people would say that the umpire had changed the rules of the game in the middle of the game. People would say, `This is not fair and it is a denial of justice'. They would be right, because one of the things about the rule of law is that it establishes a framework by which people can conduct themselves and know in advance the manner in which they will be treated.

Given that definition of justice and law, let us look to the concept of social justice. When we look at the term `social justice' against the definition of `justice', as I think most of us know it, we will see how greatly at variance is the concept of social justice. This subject has been traversed before. In 1976, out to Australia came someone by the name of von Hayek. He is a very great economist and would, I suppose, be in the league of Lord Keynes, and someone we will have been thinking about this week with the great crash, Milton Friedman. Von Hayek wrote a book called The Road to Serfdom. In looking at economics, he really comes to grips with some of the basic issues about society. The last words of his book put an emphasis, rightly, on his interests. He says:
The guiding principle that a policy of freedom for the individual is the only true progressive policy remains as true today as it was in the nineteenth century.

When von Hayek came to Australia he delivered a number of lectures. One of his lectures, in particular, is very interesting in terms of relevance today. It is entitled `The Atavism of Social Justice'. Let me say, as I should have done, that Hayek was awarded the Nobel Prize for Economic Science in 1974. He says about social justice--

TALK.START.PARA: — Order! I know that the honourable gentleman did approach me before regarding the very limited time that he was going to spend on this. He indicated that it might be a rather tortuous route in deciphering relevance. I am afraid he is begin- ning to lose me at this stage regarding relevance. Will he please come back to the Bill.

—I do not want to lose you, Mr Deputy Speaker, because this is a fundamental issue. I realise that it encompasses matters of such significance that they do not find themselves raised often enough in this Parliament. But the relevance of them is, of course, very simple.
—You may as well be talking about the penguins on Phillip Island.

—I know this matter has gone over the head of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. It is no surprise to any of us. But it ought to be within the realms of understanding of the Standing Orders of even the Minister that the Bill that we are discussing provides taxpayers' funds to promote a concept of social justice. I am entitled to stand in this Parliament today and bring before the Australian people the Opposition's concerns about the use of the concept of social justice, and the ramifications of this term for our system of justice in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: As I was saying, Professor Hayek, in his lecture, explained why he had come to regard social justice as `nothing more than an empty formula, conventionally used to assert that a particular claim is justified without giving any reason'. I think that is a very good summary of the criticism of the concept of social justice. What he said was that social justice is basically distributive justice. But the question then is: who does the distributing? There is no definition, and can be no definition, of justice of this sort because there is no agreement on the definition of testing the concept of justice in that phrase. It is a matter of fundamental importance to the sort of society that we have in Australia. But it was not just von Hayek who, 10 years ago, talked about social justice. In fact the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) is very fond of social justice. He was reported in the Times on Sunday last Sunday as follows:
He called for the introduction of a national social justice strategy that involved looking at greater redistribution through tax, social security and other key areas of social expenditure.

``Our directions for the third term of government and beyond is the creation of a fairer society, a greater degree of social justice, full employment and a society where people have more opportunities to participate and realise their potential, he said.
``Social justice is the foundation of what we are about. A fairer and more participatory society.
This is the nub of the argument; this is the highlight. This is the ultimate definition of social justice from one of the high priests of social justice. The report continued:
It is about the redistribution of power and economic opportunity.''

That is the relevance of it for Australians today. That is what social justice is about. It has nothing to do with justice as we understand the concept-absolutely nothing to do with it whatsoever. Social justice for the Australian Labor Party is about things like the wealth tax. If people find that subject a bit far removed, let them understand that it was only this week--

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. I believe that you have been very tolerant with the speaker, but whatever relation this has to the Bill before the House, which relates to tax law, is beyond my comprehension. I ask you to draw the speaker's attention to relevance.
—The honourable member for Flinders will attempt to become more relevant to the specifics of the Bill.

—I take a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. The shadow Attorney-General is not opposing the clause to which he is referring, but he is absolutely relevant because one of the provisions in the Bill is to give tax deductibility for donations to the Lionel Murphy Foundation. We do not oppose that. But one of the aims of the Foundation is to sponsor research by students into social justice under the law and to print those reports. That is an abiding principle of the Foundation. That is what the honourable member was referring to, and he is in order.
—I still ask him to become more specifically relevant.

—Firstly, I thank the honourable member for Kooyong for his support. Let me add, as a second leg to the relevance argument, the fact that this Bill-the Minister should read it-relates to the capital gains tax. In many situations in this country the capital gains tax raises a liability on the family home. The point I was about to make, before I was interrupted for the sole purpose of the Minister's attempting to deny what I was saying, was that Senator Walsh said this week that the implications of a wealth tax are not just for the few-the Bonds, the Packers and the mates of Hawke-but rather are for every Australian because the family home would be subject to tax.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said, the concept of social justice has nothing to do with justice as the ordinary person in the street understands it. Social justice is very much a part of Labor's philosophical agenda for this country. It is all about equality of outcome instead of equality of opportunity. It is all about a radical socialist Left agenda. I say to the people of Australia, `If you believe, as we do, in the importance of justice as a central and fundamental concept in our sort of society, when you hear the term social justice, stand up and deny it because it has no relevance whatsoever to the concept of justice as we know it and it needs to be stopped'. People need to be made aware of the ramifications of Labor's policy of social justice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Employment Services and Youth Affairs (Mr Holding), who is at the table, for allowing me to speak for a few minutes. I rise to speak in reaction to the comments of the recently elected honourable member for Petrie (Mr Johns), who today extolled the virtues of Medicare, and I do so during the debate on the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill which increases the levy from one per cent of income to 1.25 per cent of income. This represents another of the Labor Government's broken promises to the people of Australia. Time and time again we were assured that a one per cent levy would be sufficient to fund the Medicare program. It became more and more obvious that to continue funding the Medicare program would require a topping up perhaps by up to $2 billion, taken out of Consolidated Revenue or from the taxpayers' funds.

SPEECH.PARA: What the Government has had to do in this legislation is to increase, finally, the levy, to 1.25 per cent. If the price of bread, the price of milk or, indeed, even parliamentarians' salaries were to increase by 25 per cent, the nation would understandably be up in arms. Yet members of the Australian Labor Party sit there on the other side and treat this 25 per cent increase in the levy as a matter of course. It deserves analysis because what it underlines is that Medicare is a runaway cost program. It is a form of medicine the cost of which cannot be contained. As evidence of its effectiveness I hold up today's Daily Telegraph from Sydney. If one wades through the reports on pages 1 and 2 of the misfortunes of the stock exchange, one comes to page 3 which has the first main non-stock exchange story. It says, `13 dead in queue for surgery'. Thirteen people have died in three months waiting to get into the St George Hospital in Sydney. The article shows a chart of how long people in Sydney have to wait in that particular--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I think it would be only fair if the honourable member read what is stated further down in that article. The Minister for Health in New South Wales pointed out that all of them died from natural causes and that it was nothing to do with their waiting.
—Order! There is no point of order.
—The Minister wants me to read a bit more. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: At least 13 people died in three months while waiting for surgery at one of Sydney's biggest public hospitals, State Parliament was told yesterday.
Do you want me to keep going? I can keep boring it right into you. I said to you that I would not speak for too long but I will not be side-tracked.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member will address his remarks through the Chair.

—Thank you very much, Mr Deputy Speaker, for bringing control back to your side of the House. The honourable member for Petrie told the Parliament how marvellous the Government's approach to Medicare was. So much faith have the poor people, the lower income people, in the Government's health system that 42 per cent of the pensioners have opted for private health cover that enables them to go into a private hospital because they know that the Government system is so clogged up. They do not want to join that queue in Sydney where 13 people have died in three months just waiting to get into hospital. The Government, in its approach to health, said, `We will take care of your doctor's bills if you are uncovered, you can go into a public hospital. But if you want to take extra precautions you can pay into a private health fund which gives you a doctor of your own choice in a private hospital'. The Government has destroyed the incentive for people to care for themselves. It has caused hundreds of thousands of people to bail out of private hospital cover. This has had the effect of transferring a great slice of the community into dependence upon the public hospital sector. That is where the Government scheme has fallen down.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst I am on my feet, I put my finger on another little dirty act perpetrated by the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) in recent times. If I go into a public hospital as a citizen who does not have private health cover, 85 per cent of the doctor's fees are refunded. But if I have skimped and saved to give myself private health cover to enable me to go into a private hospital, this lousy mob that runs Australia at the moment says that I get only 75 per cent back. If ever there is a form of double discrimination, this is it. The Government effectively transferred another $100m of the cost of Medicare on to the backs of citizens-I remind the House that that includes 42 per cent of all pensioners-who are frightened of the health system and who, regardless of the heavy cost, have opted to take additional private health cover.

The honourable member for Petrie alluded to the fact that at the beginning of the 1980s somebody earning $305 a week was paying 2.2 per cent of his income on medical and hospital cover. He told us how marvellous it was that a lot of these people now do not have quite the type of insurance cover that they used to have. Granted, they have Medicare cover, but they no longer have hospital cover. That 2.2 per cent also included the right to doctors of choice and to private hospital treatment.

I undertook to make my contribution short. It has not been sweet, but when it comes to the subject of Medicare there is very little sweet about it. The reality is that the Government is endorsing a 25 per cent price slug on the contribution that the people will have to make towards keeping this ineffective system afloat.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HOLDING
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment Services and Youth Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-One can easily summarise the arguments put forward by Opposition members, because their points were mere reiterations. After listening to those very same arguments that were put to the Australian people less than four months ago, one would have liked a glimmer of hope that the Opposition had some new approach or some sense of new direction which would have enabled it to start to move away from the very discredited policies that it put to the Australian people in the election and which were rejected by the Australian people. Opposition members have come back to this House, on tax legislation, and virtually repeated their comments using the same generalities and the same arguments that were put before. They were not always put concisely or accurately, but they were certainly rejected.

SPEECH.PARA: In the course of this debate we were told that what was needed was rigour and discipline in government expenditure. That sounds well, but certainly one needs only to remind the author of that sort of prescription that this Government, probably more than any other government in history, has applied not merely rigour and discipline but also some sense of social justice-if I might use that term-in seeing that expenditure items have been carefully curtailed. I remind the people of Australia, and I remind this House, that what was put to the people by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) in the last election could hardly be described as exercises in rigour and discipline. They were promised a fistful of dollars. `Vote for us and you will get massive tax cuts', the Opposition said. Nobody believed it. The Opposition could not even get its arithmetic right. When Opposition members were asked how it was going to pay for these tax cuts they said, `That's easy. There'll be massive cuts across the board, but don't ask us where we are going to make those cuts; we wouldn't want you to get excited or upset. We wouldn't want you to know that we are proposing cuts in social welfare, in defence or in health. We wouldn't want you to know about that. But you trust little Johnnie Howard and all will be right'.

The people of Australia rejected that argument because they saw through it. It was as cheap a con trick as was ever attempted to be foisted upon the people of Australia. Yet today we hear the same old arguments being used, being recycled like some worn out suit that one does not know what to do with, so one takes it to some second hand shop hoping to get a few bob for it. That is the level of the Opposition's contribution, except for a couple of novel propositions. The honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) told us that not only were these arguments still valid, but the Opposition had actually won the support of the Australian people. Somehow or other the Opposition had won the election; it just did not get enough seats. That is the level of the contribution in this debate. I will not bother going into the kinds of arguments that, again, show the pathological hatred of some members of the Opposition for the whole concept of Medicare. That has been dealt with, I think very adequately and succinctly, by my colleagues on this side of the House and I do not propose to take up the time of the house reiterating them.

There was one further argument which I felt ought to be mentioned because it was raised by a number of members of the Opposition. It does not add anything to the debate about fiscal policy in this country, but apparently they felt that it was worth a bit of a run. I refer to the argument that somehow or other this Treasurer (Mr Keating) has a need to seek personal popularity and that that need has somehow or other affected his fiscal judgment. I have heard of some unworthy arguments in this House from time to time, and I think that members of the Parliament are used to over-exaggerated comments. But no Treasurer in the history of this Commonwealth has produced such important and significant changes to our tax system-again, with a sense of social justice-which produce some sense of equity in our tax base.

It was not easy to introduce such concepts as a capital gains tax and a fringe benefits tax-and dire predictions were made. But, at a time when this Treasurer has produced virtually a balanced Budget, when he has won the acclaim of the business community, the average Australian and indeed the international community, we are told that this person-who not only has produced these concepts but also has been prepared to stand steadfast against a level of hysterical criticism that was weighed against these policies-despite his history, is somehow allowing his fiscal judgment to be affected by some seeking of personal popularity. We still do not know whether the honourable gentlemen opposite are pledged to repeal the assets test, the capital gains tax and the fringe benefits tax. I mention that sleazy argument for no other purpose than to consign it to the gutter whence it emanated.

It has been a disappointing contribution from the Opposition. I feel sorry for the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock). I wish him well in his belated attempts to take this polyglot mob on the other side in some new direction which may at least give some credibility to the sorts of arguments that these people are prepared to put in this House. There are real issues to be enjoined in this whole area of fiscal policy, and it is about time we heard about them from a responsible Opposition.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 8, page 6, line 13, omit from the definition of ``asset re-valuation dividend'' in proposed subsection 46e (1) ``4 June 1987'', substitute ``23 September 1987''.
(2) Clause 8, page 8, line 12, omit from proposed paragraph 46e (6) (a) ``4 June 1987'', substitute ``23 September 1987''.

I simply wish to say that our concern relates to proposed section 46e contained in clause 8 of the Bill before the Committee. Without going into details on the substantive provisions of the clause, the new section 46e should remove the scope for tax avoidance by denying the inter-corporate dividend rebate in respect of dividends paid out of asset revaluations in the circumstances described by the proposed new section. Our complaint is that the Bill will have retrospective effect on those dividends which were paid on or after 4 June of this year.

On 4 June-prior to the election and during the last Parliament-the Government introduced legislation and announced its intention to implement similar provisions. However, that legislation was not passed with the calling of the early election. Since that election the Government has introduced this later Bill. The relevant proposed new section in the earlier legislation put before the previous Parliament has been amended considerably since that time. It still purports, however, to have effect from 4 June, and therefore has retrospective effect. Taxpayers, noting the nature of the legislation introduced in June, who then legitimately arranged their affairs so as not to contravene the proposed section 46e released in that earlier Bill, now find that they may have contravened the amended proposed new section. The ambit of the proposed new section has been widened by the amendments and regrettably those alterations do not include the date from which the new section is to have effect.

So, as a matter of fairness, we are proposing amendments to allow the new section 46e to take effect from 23 September 1987. We are not opposing what is contained in that proposed section other than the date. It would therefore take effect not from 4 June but from 23 September, the date on which this particular Bill was first presented to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) in moving these particular amendments. I spoke briefly on this matter last night and, I hope, made the same point that my colleague has made this morning. I must say I was amused when the Minister for Employment Services and Youth Affairs (Mr Holding), in responding to the second reading debate, conveyed the impression that he was aware of all the arguments that had been put in that debate. He was not even present in the chamber last night and he was therefore unprepared to answer my argument or perhaps even foreshadow a reaction to the amendments that have now been put.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to deal with clause 15 in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3), which seeks to amend sections 108 and 109 of the principal Act. Like the present section, the proposed section deals with the possibility of an actual distribution subsequent to the deemed dividend. While the existing section eliminates double taxation, it is fair to say that the proposed amendment is not revenue neutral. Proposed sub-section 108 (2) provides that, where the whole or a part of a dividend is set off in satisfaction of the whole or part of the amount deemed to be a dividend by early application of section 108, the amount set off should not attract further income tax. It does this in a very curious and tortuous way indeed in that it seems to invoke a grammatical triple negative. It is very hard to read these provisions, given that they are expressed by way of a triple negative. Specifically, proposed paragraph 108 (2) (b) provides that so much of the amount of the dividend or subsequent dividend as is set off and as does not exceed the unfranked part of that dividend shall be deemed not to be a dividend other than for the purposes of imputation. Plainly-but after a great deal of study-this means that subsequent unfranked dividends will not be assessable while subsequent franked dividends will remain assessable and, incidentally, while partly franked dividends are partly assessable.

The proposed changes are simply unfair, in the way that I read the application of the clause. It seems to be sloppy draftsmanship. I cannot for a minute believe that the Government would want to do what it seems effectively to achieve in this context; that is, triple taxation by the imposition of a triple Medicare levy on a transaction. If we assume a shareholder, whose marginal tax rate is always 49 per cent, has received a loan of $1,000 from a private company, that loan is first deemed to be a dividend and is subsequently offset by a fully franked dividend. In the year of deeming a dividend in these circumstances the shareholder will pay income tax of $490 and a Medicare levy of $12.50. In the year the franked dividend is distributed, the shareholder will be assessed a tax of $960 as well as being entitled to a tax rebate of $960. He will also be assessed a Medicare levy of $24.50. It will be seen that there is no mechanism in the clause to refund the tax paid earlier and that a triple Medicare levy has been imposed under these provisions.

The Bill also contains a transitional section-proposed new section 108-which caters for situations where the existing section deems amounts to be dividends but where the set-off will occur when the proposed new section is in force. This transitional section is equally unfair, in the way I have described, to subsequent franked dividends. I believe that this is a drafting error. I accept that my interpretation might be at fault but that is my advice. I would like the Minister to consult with his advisers because I am sure that if that is what the Government has effectively achieved-triple taxation by the imposition of three lots of the Medicare levy-further amendments will be required. As I have already said, I do not believe that this Government would intentionally get into a situation in which it would impose a triple impost in the manner described.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HOLDING
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment Services and Youth Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) summarised his arguments in favour of this amendment on the basis that it takes the provisions beyond 4 June 1987. This has to be seen in the context that on 4 June this year the Treasurer (Mr Keating) released an exposure draft of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1987 in order to inform the business community of proposed anti-avoidance measures so that legitimate business planning could be proceeded with. In releasing the exposure draft the Treasurer announced that some technical provisions were not yet fully settled. He emphasised that the provisions of proposed new section 46e, as contained in the exposure draft, would be extended to apply also where entities were interposed between a company revaluing its assets and a company disposing of its shares. The provisions contained in the Bill before us do precisely this.

SPEECH.PARA: To prevent the tax avoiders, at whom these measures are directed, from circumventing the measures by arranging for an associate to sell shares which effectively give control of a company, but not the shares on which asset revaluation dividends are paid, the provisions also apply where, as part of a scheme to avoid tax, shares are disposed of by another party in such circumstances that a tax benefit is conferred on the company which has received asset revaluation dividends.

I assure the Committee that legitimate business will not in any way be affected by these measures. Only those actively seeking to avoid paying tax, by contrived arrangements, will be affected and these people were clearly advised of the Government's intention by an exposure draft and the Treasurer's announcement on 4 June 1987. That being the case, the Government will oppose any move to have the provisions apply from a date later than 4 June.
Question put:
That the amendments (Mr Peacock's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Mr Holding)-by leave-read a third time.
Consideration resumed from 23 September, on motion by Mr Holding:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Clauses 1 to 3-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 4 (Levy of tax).

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition opposes clause 4 and will vote against it. I gave the reasons during the second reading debate last night. It is an attempt to deny the annual review of tax scales by the Parliament, and the Opposition regrets and opposes the clause and will vote against it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HOLDING
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —The present situation is that the legislation declares both personal and company tax rates. It is now put before the Parliament only when there is a change of rates, and the rates are not declared on an annual basis. In this situation the Government questions whether there is any necessity to continue to have a Bill formally imposing income tax each year. As the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) pointed out, there is not an annual imposition of other Commonwealth taxes, and the Commonwealth Office of Parliamentary Counsel has advised there is no legal requirement for the annual imposition of income tax. The past practice of annual imposition apparently had an historical basis.

SPEECH.PARA: In a climate where staff resources for drafting legislation and time for parliamentary debate are at a premium, it seems a waste to process a Bill each year when it is not required. It is not the imposition of income tax that is the usual subject for debate, but the rates at which it is charged. For that reason the Government will insist on the clause.
Question put:
That the clause be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Remainder of Bill-by leave-taken as a whole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 5, page 2, omit the clause, substitute the following clause:
Repeal of sections 9 and 10
``5. Sections 9 and 10 of the Principal Act are repealed.''.
Clause 6, page 2, lines 9 and 10, omit ``of all subsequent years of income'', substitute ``of the next succeeding year of income''.
I have moved these amendments for the reasons earlier discussed, namely, the supremacy of the Parliament and the duty of the Executive to answer to it for its annual review of tax scales.
Amendments negatived.
Remainder of Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Mr Holding)-by leave-read a third time.
Consideration resumed from 23 September, on motion by Mr Holding:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Clauses 1 to 3-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 4 (Application of amendments).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 4, page 1, line 14, omit ``and for all subsequent financial years''.

The strength of debate on this Bill is evidence that the Government has a responsibility to present its tax levies for annual scrutiny. A number of honourable members chose to speak very widely on the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill in giving their views as to how Medicare is treating Australians. That process is very healthy because it puts the system under scrutiny, and that is what Parliament is for. Parliament is the place where the activities of the bureaucracy and of executive government are monitored. To suggest that because there is not to be a change in a tax levy such provisions should continue ad infinitum is not sustainable.

In the debate on that Bill honourable members heard an excellent presentation by the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Donald Cameron), who raised severe concerns which were published in the media yesterday as to people on waiting lists who were dying. I was surprised that the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mr John Brown) took a point of order and said that those people all died of natural causes. He can take it from me that it does not matter much. Most people who are waiting to get into hospitals are waiting because of natural causes. The system has not yet got that bad that a person who has a car accident or who is badly injured cannot get into hospital. It is people with natural causes such as eye problems, heart and arthritic conditions who are on waiting lists for four years, and it was reported that in three months 13 of them died. We are quite prepared to admit the Minister's view that those people died of natural causes. The reality is that they are dead. Prob- ably all of them suffered from operable conditions and had they been able to get into hospital immediately, as they could have done in the past before this wonderful thing called Medicare came about, and had they been able to have the necessary treatment, no doubt a number of those people would be living today.

These are the sorts of issues that the Parliament is entitled to raise when these levy Bills come before it annually. That has been the practice of this House for many years.
