If this Government continues with these sorts of actions-the automatic indexation of various excise taxes-it will have a scandal on its hands. The community no longer has any chance to lobby against increases in those taxes because they are imposed automatically. People see a rise in costs at the bowser, for example, or down at the local hotel and they no longer know whether that is due to a government imposed tax, a wholesaler's imposed price increase or a retailer's imposed price increase. That is not the way in which a democracy such as Australia should operate. We know of the ambitions of certain Government members for a corporate state, but let us get this straight: this is still a parliamentary democracy, a tax is a tax is a tax and it should be debated annually, irrespective of its change, because it is there to produce certain results. This is particularly so with something like the Medicare levy. In other words, even if the levy is not to be increased, the people are entitled to consider whether they are getting value for money.

As this debate has proved, the Opposition is clearly of the view that the public is not getting value for money in this case. The levy represents a very small amount of the money that is being spent in this area. There is excellent reason for having the opportunity to refer to items appearing in the Press. I thought it was a matter of considerable interest that the Bulletin chose in its 27 October edition to run an article on `The crisis in the surgery-why your GP is considering militant action'. One part of that article points out just how much many doctors are actually making in personal remuneration. That is a point well worth making because it indicates that the gross income of a doctor is $153,000, which is apparently indicative of a country practice. However, he is left with a net income of $62,801.

That is a point that the Government should accept because the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories spoke on television the other day in terms of the scandal of the medical services in Canberra, saying that the doctors are earning $200,000 a year. That is grossly misleading the public. It is totally unnecessary and it is similar to remarks that could be made about politicians' salaries. One would never hear that Minister or any other Minister making those sorts of remarks about politicians! Let us be honest about it; let us talk about the doctors' personal, disposable incomes received from their work. As many politicians might want to argue in their own cases, let us look at the hours that doctors put in for their money. This is not a case for them to screw the system any more than anyone else. The point I am making is that that television statement by the Minister, which I observed personally, was grossly misleading and is indicative of the type of tactics so often used by him. It is about time that he gave up and just told the truth. The truth is that $200,000 a year is the gross income of some of the better off in Canberra; it is far from their net income when one looks at the sort of expenses they have to pay. For example, they have to pay receptionists, practice managers and for telephones, stationery and so on. A receptionist takes $16,000 a year out of that and I guess most would be lucky to find a good receptionist for that money today.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you talking about specialists or GPs?
—I am talking about the people to whom the Minister referred the other day. The Minister said that the doctors of Canberra get $200,000 a year--

—I take a point of order, Mr Chairman. I did not want to restrain the honourable member for O'Connor, but the amendment he has moved is very narrow and technical and the comments that he is making are perfectly appropriate to a speech in a second reading debate. I am reluctant to restrain him, but I think that the amendment is narrow and should be addressed at this stage.
—There is some validity in the Minister's point of order--
—A lot of validity.

—There is no real validity in the interjection of the honourable member for Maribyrnong, however. The honourable member for O'Connor might refer more directly to the matter before the Chair, which is that clause 4 be amended to omit the words `and for all subsequent financial years'.

—The purpose of the amendment is to remove those words `and for all subsequent financial years'. The Government's purpose in including those words is to remove this legislation from the parliamentary debate as is presently required every year, irrespective of present and past arrangements and irrespective of whether the Government chooses to change the levy. It has a responsibility to have the matter reaffirmed by this Parliament every year. I was giving examples to the Parliament as to why there is a need for this debate, even if there is no change in the levy. The most interesting thing about that is that it was amazing that the Government was not prepared in its original legislation, when it brought the levy in at one per cent, to say, `and for all subsequent financial years', because that was the intention at the time. We were promised faithfully that the levy would never exceed one per cent. Of course, in reality, it is now more like 5 or 6 per cent when one looks at the total expenditure on Medicare. These are the reasons why the Opposition demands that those words be removed and that the other amendments, to which I will refer, be accepted because it is essential that each year the Government be asked to answer on the issue of the taxes it raises.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not just a matter of the amount of money the Government extracts from the Australian taxpayer; it is the value that the Australian taxpayer gets. This is a wide-ranging debate and the very strength of that debate and the evidence brought forward by various members is such as to demonstrate the need to expose a massive expenditure-in total $5,000m to $6,000m-to the scrutiny of Parliament. Let us face it. The estimated raisings of the levy this year are $2,065m and the Minister is suggesting that that is not a matter which should be discussed by the Parliament annually. Next year that amount will be $2,300m or something like that, even if the levy remains as it is. If that is not a good reason to remove those words, I do not know what is. We are well aware why the Government wants to get this matter off the debating agenda. It is embarrassed by the ineffectiveness and the cost of its proposal. It is also embarrassed by the fact that so many people are not getting the service that the Government promised, particularly the less well off in our community. For those reasons I have pleasure in moving this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McHugh Ms J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I oppose the amendment put forward by the Opposition because I support the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill, just as I support Medicare. This Bill amends the Medicare Levy Act to declare and impose the basic rate of Medicare levy for 1987-88 and all subsequent income years. It also increases the income threshold levels below which people with low incomes will not be called upon to pay any levy. In supporting the Bill and opposing the Opposition's amendment, I wish to comment on those remarks that have been made by Opposition members in relation to the New South Wales hospital waiting lists.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition consistently raises this matter in connection with Medicare for one simple reason-the Opposition loathes Medicare and the Australian public supports it. This is an attempt by Opposition members to reverse Australian public support. They constantly blame Medicare which, I remind them, is a universal health insurance system, for any problems that occur in the delivery of health care. There are problems at every level in the delivery of health care, but those problems are the responsibility of the health carers, including the hospitals. The hospitals are primarily the responsibility of the States. Honourable members opposite referred to the story in this morning's Sydney Morning Herald, which was also referred to in the New South Wales State Parliament, of deaths of people allegedly on a hospital waiting list. These people were waiting for care in St George Hospital. I have some information which I think is worth including in this debate. Hospitals do not keep waiting lists. The document which has been referred to is apparently an internal management document, compiled from individual doctors' lists. It is the doctors who keep lists. It is the doctors who determine the priority of admission into hospital.

Serious doubts can be cast on the accuracy of doctors' lists. For instance, they sometimes forget to delete the names of people who no longer require admission to hospital because they have received care at another hospital, perhaps at very great expense, under the doctor's persuasive rhetoric in one of the doctor's private hospitals. But the name will remain on the doctors' lists for admission to hospital. So serious doubt can be cast on the accuracy of these lists.

Apparently, the list quoted was so inaccurate that it involved four and not 13 deaths. I am not here to say that four deaths are meaningless. Four deaths are very meaningful. It appears that the four deaths were of aged people, all over 70 years of age, who have every right to everything the public hospital system can offer, which is the best in the world. But what we are arguing about here is whether they were on a hospital waiting list, unable to get into hospital to be treated for the condition from which they died. Not one of the people who died died as a result of a condition which caused them to be placed on the doctor's list. The tragic cases referred to in this morning's Sydney Morning Herald are being investigated by the New South Wales Department of Health.

I have enormous confidence in the New South Wales public hospital system. The sort of thing the Opposition is saying and the sort of story that is being put around about deaths on waiting lists are designed to undermine faith in our great public hospital system. St George Hospital has reduced from four months to four weeks the waiting list for cardiac surgery. This year it has conducted 1,011 more operations than last year and has treated 2,421 more patients than it treated last year. It has opened 62 extra beds. It has reduced by 171 the number of people waiting for surgery for more than 12 months. This Government, responsible for the universal health insurance scheme which is so successful and which the Opposition, even if it gets into power, will never undermine and will never get rid of because it is so popular, nevertheless recognises that there are difficulties and problems in the delivery of health care through our public hospital system. For that reason it is helping the States with extra funds. We recognise that there are problems. Many of them are because of the current shortage of nurses caused by the transfer of nurse education from hospital-based to tertiary education. But the States are addressing that problem. In New South Wales, which is so constantly under attack, 300 new nurses will arrive from overseas within the next six weeks.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shame!

—I beg your pardon! This will overcome a current difficulty. When the transfer of nurse education is complete the current shortage of nurses will be overcome. I repeat: the Commonwealth Government recognises its responsibility. Specifically to address hospital waiting times it is providing $25m a year over the next two years to assist the States rapidly to reduce waiting times for elective surgery for Medicare patients. Because the funding will be on a dollar for dollar basis with the States an additional $100m will be allocated under the public hospital waiting list assistance program over the next two years. In New South Wales a $27.4m program has already been introduced which is specifically shaped to open beds and reduce waiting times in public hospitals.

SPEECH.PARA: The only point of the Opposition's attacks in regard to this problem is to undermine public confidence in the best public hospital system in the world-the public hospital system of Australia-and to help the doctors who are trying to get people out of our magnificent public hospital system and into their own profit-making private hospitals.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not take very much of your time this time, Mr Chairman. I note that the interest of the Minister for Employment Services and Youth Affairs (Mr Holding)-I refer particularly to him and not to you, Mr Chairman; I think you have treated this debate very properly-in relevance seemed to disappear all of a sudden. I think that point is worth making.
—You could have taken a point of order.

—I was at pains not to do so because I did not believe that it would have been proper to do so. I thought that the honourable member for Phillip (Ms McHugh) had the right to make the remarks that she did. At no point did I choose to stop her. I have chosen to take some of my own speaking time to remind the Minister that it is quite reasonable for one to stick to one's beliefs. If the Minister believed that I was digressing too far he had a responsibility, as is his charge, to raise questions as to the relevance of the honourable member for Phillip. He did not, for pure--
—I will deal with that. She was certainly relevant.
—Of course she was relevant, in the Minister's view. So was I. That is the point I wish to make.
—Order! Let us not have a debate about relevance.

—Let me quickly respond to the points that have been made. Medicare is not a health insurance program. The Minister, in his second reading speech when he introduced the Medicare legislation, was at pains to tell us that. Medicare is very selective about where it will give people financial assistance if they have medical problems, particularly in regard to where they go if they need to be hospitalised. They can go only to a public hospital. If they want free hospital treatment under Medicare they are obliged to go to a public hospital. Because that has happened and because of the effect that Medicare has created by grossly overcrowding public hospitals and putting demand upon their operating facilities, we have problems with those hospitals, dumped as was said, on State governments. There are 9,000 beds vacant in the private hospital sector.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Phillip made it very clear why this Government does not want to give financial assistance to people who choose to go to a private hospital. The honourable member is concerned that someone might make a profit. That is her worry. She is desperately concerned that someone might make a profit. She overlooks the fact that frequently that profit is made through efficiency, not through overcharging. The true cost of a hospital bed in the public sector to the taxpayer is about $350 a day, whereas for a bed in a private hospital one pays about $250 a day. But the honourable member chooses to hide all that. She says that a public hospital bed costs nothing. The cost of hospitals in the New South Wales system, which the honourable member says is so remarkable--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman--
—Come off it! The Minister sat right through her speech and said nothing. I am responding to what she said.
—Order! The honourable member will resume his seat.
—I hope that it is a relevant point of order.
—I call the Minister.

—It is a relevant point of order. The honourable member for O'Connor produced amendments which were very narrowly based. I was perfectly happy to sit here and let him be general. Then I took a point of order which you, Mr Chairman, properly upheld. Following that matter a speaker chose to answer the honourable member for O'Connor, who now wants to extend this debate into a general debate on Medicare. That is not the issue before the chamber. They are his amendments. He has made some statements that have been replied to. To allow him to go on in this vein would constitute a gross abuse of the Standing Orders. I ask him through you, Mr Chairman, to come back to the issues that are before the chamber which are very narrow and very specific.

—The Committee has before it a Bill in relation to the collection of money to finance the Health Insurance Commission. There has been a reasonably wide debate on the amendments to and the clauses of the Bill. The honourable member for O'Connor used some examples. The honourable member for Phillip used some examples. The honourable member for O'Connor, in speaking for the second time on the Bill, because of the number of examples we have allowed to be used can use examples, but we do not want him to regurgitate his second reading stage speech on the matter. Having taken that on board, I call the honourable member for O'Connor.

—Thank you, Mr Chairman. I will take the least possible time. I have spoken on this second occasion, which the Standing Orders allow, only to rebut the remarks made by the honourable member for Phillip. I was about to tell her that the cost to the taxpayers of delivering medical services in New South Wales is $3,000m a year. In fact, when we add up the total cost of health to the Australian taxpayer, it comes to $23 a week per family. That cost should be the subject of some consideration. As the honourable member has admitted, there are some huge problems, particularly in the New South Wales health system. She is entitled to defend it, and we are entitled to criticise it. I hope that the Australian people will be the winners from that debate and will be able to make a judgment. But I tell honourable members that if only four people die because of the failures of the system, their relatives will already have made their judgment.

SPEECH.PARA: Whatever the arguments we have had here today, we say that the debate should be held annually. The Government proposes to hide a revenue provision of $2,065m this year, which is not peanuts. The honourable member for Phillip, as a Government backbencher, should be given the opportunity once a year to express her strong support for the system, just as I, as a member of the Opposition, should be given the opportunity to criticise it in the public interest. That is the point we are on about. That is exactly why the Opposition is suggesting the omission of just these words. We are not in any way opposing the Government's right or intention to lift the levy to 1.25 per cent. We are criticising it and we are saying that we want to delete the words that this levy be applied for all subsequent financial years. We agree to one year, and we expect the Government to come back, irrespective of whether it wants to increase the levy, and give an accounting to the Australian people of that $2 billion or $2.5 billion which it soon will be. That is exactly why we invite the honourable member for Phillip to support that very worthwhile amendment that does no more than guarantee that there will be a debate on this issue in approximately 12 months time, and, I hope, after each subsequent 12 months whilst the proposal is in existence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HOLDING
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment Services and Youth Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendment is rejected by the Government because it really is specious. Looking at the principle involved, the Opposition is really saying that if any charge or addition to revenue which is raised on an annual basis is proposed, that has to come back before this Parliament on an annual basis so that it can be debated, even if there is no change. The result of that would be, considering the range of charges that are encompassed in our laws, that this Parliament would never get up. This is a nonsense proposition.

SPEECH.PARA: Despite the fact that the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) regards himself as something of an expert on the Standing Orders, he knows as well as I do that if he, as a member of this House, is concerned about any aspect of public policy, be it Medicare or any other aspect, he has a whole range of parliamentary opportunities to deal with that issue. He has the choice of matters of public importance, the Budget debate itself and the debates on the Budget Bills. There are all the provisions within the Standing Orders. This shows just how ill-contrived and badly thought through are the basic propositions. It is a nonsense proposition in parliamentary terms, because if this precedent were established in respect of this item, we would have to say that it was part of the parliamentary process for a whole range of items. One could imagine the problem that would create.

The fact is that the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill is like any Bill which imposes an income tax. Like other taxes, the levy is imposed as a standing measure. If there is any change in the rate of the levy, either up or down, that will be put before the Parliament when those changes have to take place. Honourable members will then have an opportunity to debate that. For those reasons the amendment is rejected.
Question put:
That the amendment (Mr Tuckey's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Remainder of Bill-by leave-taken as a whole.
Amendment (by Mr Tuckey) negatived:
(2) Schedule, page 2, omit the amendment to subsection 11 (1), substitute:
``Subsection 11 (1):
Omit `1986', substitute `1987' ''.
Remainder of Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Mr Holding)-by leave-read a third time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being near 12.45 p.m., in accordance with sessional order 106a, General Business will be called on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House expresses concern at the effects of road trauma on Australian society and commends the Government for policies aimed at lowering deaths and injury of drivers on Australian roads.

Around 3,000 people are killed each year on Australian roads. At the end of 1986 the national toll was 2,883. Of those people, 482 died on Queensland roads. Since the beginning of this decade, over 21,800 people have been killed in road crashes in Australia. The Federal Government shares the deep concern of the Australian people regarding this trauma. We acknowledge the extensive nature of a problem which is hard to quantify. Accidents may be caused by an emotional driver, a driver who is feeling frustrated or aggravated for some reason, one who overtakes on a road which is rutted with potholes or a person driving into the evening sun just before an intersection. Who can tell which of these factors is the cause of any resultant collision?

However, a number of practical and, in some cases, innovative measures have been undertaken by the Hawke Government which I believe have contributed to the national fall in the road toll. I say this in complete awareness that people on both sides of the House share the great concern of the Australian people about the number of drivers and pedestrians-young people, children and the aged-who are being killed on Australia's roads.

However, while there were 2,883 road fatalities in Australia in 1986, there is a bright side to the picture. This figure is lower than for any year between 1964 and 1982. In fact the number of road fatalities to 30 September 1987 has fallen by 8 per cent. The figure is 1,972 this year compared with 2,149 in 1986. We take some encouragement from that. But I must stress that there is still a need for continuing action to reduce fatalities and injuries resulting from road crashes. There is absolutely no room for complacency. The annual cost to the community in dollar terms alone, not to mention the greater cost of grief and lifelong disablement, is estimated at about $3,000m per annum.

Moreover, a comparison of Australian and overseas figures shows that we have more road fatalities per head of population in this country than in the United States, Canada or Great Britain. In 1986, 18.1 Australians per 100,000 were killed on the road. This staggering figure is almost double that for Great Britain. This is the size of the problem facing us as a community. This problem has been faced by this Government, firstly, by the previous Minister for Transport, now Minister for Resources (Mr Peter Morris), who was known for his energetic work in the area of road safety, and now by the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support (Mr Duncan), who has already shown that he will follow on that interest in this area.

They have worked in conjunction with the Federal Office of Road Safety. I mention Bill Upton, who has worked in this office for many years, and Peter Makeham and Carol Boughton. I mention also the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Road Safety, which has changed its name to the Standing Committee on Transport Safety. Those committees have worked in a bipartisan manner and have included as members the honourable member for Streeton (Mr Lamb), who is here at present, the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck) and the honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Katter), who was the chairperson of the Road Safety Committee before I had the honour to carry on in that role.

A number of members on both sides of the House, some of whom will be speaking later in this debate, have co-operated with the Government to enable the Commonwealth to undertake a leadership catalyst role which has been developed together with a Government road safety strategy consisting of three fundamental elements. The first is to provide safer roads. An allocation of $1,250m has been made for road construction and maintenance in 1987-88. People in local areas will be aware of the excellent Australian bicentennial road development program which has brought better roads to many areas, including in the Brisbane area of Queensland. The national highway program has been most successful.

But, in saying this, I make the comment that providing safe roads alone is not enough. I feel that we must look at attitudes and drivers. We have become a pretty soft and pampered society which is willing to speed and take risks on roads which in some areas may not be 100 per cent and then complacently turn around and blame the roads. I think drivers have to take note of existing conditions. If they do not really want 3,000 people to be killed every year, though that number is down below the 3,000 now, thank God, and if they do not want continuing disablement, they should go more slowly. They should not drink drive. They should make sure that it is their responsibility to see that they get safely across that particular road.

The second element is to ensure safer vehicles. This is a most important aspect. The stability and safety aspects of cars, buses and trucks are an issue of concern to most people. New certification arrangements, together with regular checks on vehicle safety standards, provide Australians with vehicles which are amongst the safest in the world. The cost of the new certification system is only $5 per vehicle, which is recover- able through the sale of compliance plates. This is one of the areas in which the Government is seeking to implement practical policies, Mr Deputy Speaker. At the last meeting of State and Federal Transport Ministers a new design rule was endorsed to require the labelling of all new vehicles with a unique vehicle identification number. This will help prevent the reregistration of stolen vehicles.

Some other areas at which the Commonwealth is looking are those of general standards, including noise standards. Although we have made substantial progress with vehicle safety standards there are, unfortunately, still some problems with non-uniform vehicle noise and emission standards. In our cities there is a community expectation for vehicles to meet reasonable contemporary noise standards. There is a growing consensus that the best way of achieving this is by using United Nations standards applied uniformly. This is another area at which this Federal Government is looking.

The third element of Commonwealth road safety policy is research and promotion to counter the human act factor. Attitudes are the most important aspect of road safety and the most difficult to change. The aim of this element of the Government's strategy is to change attitudes and promote responsible road user behaviour. Just over $2m has been spent on this activity in recent years. I would point to Federal Office of Road Safety publicity campaigns, such as the Molly Meldrum `Wear a bicycle helmet' campaign and the Paul Cronin campaigns against drink driving-`Would you let a mate drink while he or she has been driving?'. They were most effective programs. It is very hard again to evaluate just how successful in money terms such a program is, or in terms of saving lives. But I can only say that one must keep putting these programs forward. I think the overall lessening of the road toll does show that the programs being followed have been effective, at least to a noticeable extent.

There are two groups in the community most prone to road deaths. The first is the under-25 age group. For Australians 15 to 24 years old there are three times as many deaths from road crashes as from suicide, the next largest cause of death. In 1984 there were 955 deaths from road crashes and 310 suicides. This may be a real indictment of the attitude to road safety in Australia. A number of programs have been undertaken to try to counter this problem. I can note only some of them here because, again, a variety of programs has been carried out at different levels over a number of years by people who share the Government's concern at what is happening.

One program that we are putting out, aimed at young people, is the Road Warrior video program, our most recent video for young drivers. The Road Warrior video seeks to involve young drivers and give them a more realistic perspective of the time involved in becoming a safe driver. Without this realistic perspective some young drivers believe they are highly skilled, even in their first year of driving. Research and crash statistics show that over-confident young drivers place themselves in situations they cannot handle, for example, through inappropriate speeds or risky overtaking, and serious injuries can result. The video is designed to be used as a discussion starter: a poster and an L-plate leaflet which promote the video are available and are being actively used in student driver education. It is encouraging young people to ask questions such as: `When do you become a safe driver? How?'. It deals with the relative importance of car handling skills and, most importantly, the danger of over-confidence.

The second group are probably the real victims of the senseless road slaughter-children. A total of nearly 400 children is killed each year on Australian roads, and another 44,700 are seriously injured. Around 170 of these children are passengers in fatal car accidents. Thirty per cent of the children are under five years of age. One thing that the Government is doing most actively now is presenting the out and about campaign. It is material for primary schools, a road safety book and a book for parents which will encourage young children to follow the program in a fun way, and at that early age have an attitude towards road safety which could save their own lives in the younger years and carry on as they develop and save other peoples' lives within the children's adulthood.

The guide is now being put out in 10 different languages, including Italian, Turkish, Croatian, Greek, Vietnamese and Arabic, and is an excellent program available to people in the community and available to schools. The material for primary schools has five components: a teachers' guide; workbooks; stickers; a parents' guide and other activities which reinforce in a fun way children's knowledge of how traffic and pedestrians use the road. I thoroughly commend the Government and the Federal Office of Road Safety for promoting this excellent program.

I have spoken of three major elements of road trauma, about which the Federal Government is concerned, and for which they are framing policies; but there is another killing factor-alcohol. Alcohol is the major single cause of road fatalities in Australia with 40 per cent of all road deaths being directly related to drink driving. We must never lose sight of that fact. We should not, because of the social acceptability of alcoholic drink, overlook the fact that drink underlies most of the road slaughter; on the road it was 50 per cent, now down to 40 per cent, of all road deaths.

What we mean by that is that 40 per cent of drivers killed on our roads have an unacceptably high blood alcohol level; that is, over .05 per cent. It is not that we are sitting on the sidelines and condemning drink, condemning a habit which is socially acceptable and enjoyed by many people, without having evidence on which to base our contentions. We are not even looking at the number of people who could have been killed and have not been identified. We are looking at blood sampling from the people who have died in road trauma, and we see that 40 per cent of those drivers have had high blood alcohol levels. Of all road users involved in a total of 1,935 road traffic accidents in Queensland last year, 1,565 registered a positive result when receiving a blood alcohol analysis; that is, over three quarters of accident victims had been consuming alcohol. Only 102 of that total of 1,565 with blood alcohol content were within the legal limits.

The number of road traffic accidents for the 17 to 20 years age group is the highest of all the age groups, and the proportion of positive blood alcohol results is just as high, even a little higher. The combination of alcohol and inexperience in driving is a particularly hazardous one. But survey results also indicate another alarming trend, and that is that the use of drugs other than alcohol may also be contributing to the road toll with 80 per cent of commonly used drugs being known to increase the effects of alcohol. Between 30 per cent and 65 per cent of driver and pedestrian fatalities have used drugs other than alcohol, caffeine and nicotine according to surveys of crash victims in Australia and overseas.

A study completed in Melbourne revealed that over 46 per cent of the drugs used by those involved in fatal crashes were prescription drugs. Another third were over the counter preparations. Twenty-two per cent of road user fatalities had used illicit drugs, mainly cannabis. Although reports have concluded that alcohol has a greater effect on driving skills than marijuana, the combined effects of alcohol and marijuana are far greater and therefore more dangerous than if either drug is used separately. More research into the combined effects of alcohol and legal or illegal drugs on driving skills is definitely needed and the Federal Office of Road Safety has been taking a lead in this area for some years now. It set up a research program over a number of years, a program of activities in which a study was undertaken with people being stopped at random breath testing stations and policy being directed to ask those people what medications they had taken.

This research looked at driver and pedestrian fatalities and did an analysis of blood samples to determine drugs in the system before the crash in which they had died. This research basis which has been undertaken by the Commonwealth Government has been carried on at State level with practical research in the way in which people can be tested for drugs, which is not an easy dilemma. There is not any type of device such as the random breath testing device which can instantly and easily take a reading from drivers. The New South Wales Government has evolved what it calls the tandem mass spectrometer with which it can take blood samples for testing. It is working on legislation to introduce this program. The New South Wales Government will be looking at people involved in crashes, at this stage. It will mean pricking the finger of persons who had been driving and involved in a crash to see the extent, if at all, to which those people had been taking drugs.

In Tasmania there have been some encouraging developments regarding on the spot breath sampling for drugs. They are at the research development stage but there is hope here. The device which they have developed within Tasmania is not sophisticated and we do not know at this stage how effective it will be but the major point, Mr Deputy Speaker, is that the States are co-operating with the Federal Government, are taking up the lead offered by the Federal Government and by people in non-government organisations to get together and show that we in Australia mean business when we say that it is not acceptable to have thousands of people dying on Australia's roads every year.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion and reserve my right to speak later.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cowan Mr D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to lead for the Opposition, Mr Deputy Speaker, as the Chairman of its Transport and Communications Committee and to say that we are pleased that the honourable member for Lilley (Mrs Darling) has brought this matter before the House today. We support the features that she mentioned, particularly with respect to the measures that are being adopted so far as road safety is concerned. I suppose it could be termed a great social problem, Mr Deputy Speaker, today within Australia because we are a motorised society. We are a society that lives on wheels which is important to industry and important to the individual. And so, when we have a country with a geographical situation like Australia's, with very long roads, it is very important indeed that the Commonwealth and all the States are very cognisant of the road safety problems.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a great trauma, as the honourable member for Lilley said, particularly for families, when we see the younger generation being killed off. This nation cannot afford that loss because we need more people. So we have to protect as best we can the people that we have. It is of interest to note that there were more people killed in the 15 years up to 1983-52,243-than were killed in the Second World War. Those are alarming figures when one comes to think about them.

I suppose in the community today we basically accept the fact that while we have vehicles on the road we will have deaths, and so it is that we have that responsibility to create the measures to give as much safety as we possibly can. It is not only the expenditure of funds; it is a matter of being able to spend those moneys in the most appropriate way in order to create those safety measures that are so necessary today. Looking at the future, the experts inform us that over the next decade at least 35,000 people will be killed on our roads, which in turn will cost Australia about $3 billion; that is a lot of money indeed.

We in the Opposition realise that the measures that are being adopted by the States particularly have meant that there has been a reduction in the number of fatal accidents within Australia over the last year or so. This has been caused by the education program, particularly, that is being embarked upon, and I must mention here our driver training that is taking place in a lot of our secondary schools. I find this particularly valuable because it is teaching our younger people how properly to look after and handle a vehicle. In Australia, so far as deaths per number of vehicles and deaths per number of population of people and also of kilometres are concerned, we have more fatal accidents and injuries on our roads than most other countries of the world. But that can be accepted because of what the honourable member for Lilley has said.

There are three factors that I think we have to look at: the first is the personal factor so far as people are concerned; the second is the vehicle; and, of course, the third is the condition of the roads. On the personal side, let me say that we recognise that excessive speed, alcohol, irresponsibility, inexperience and wilful disregard for the law are all factors that we have to consider. We know that penalties are a most important factor on the personal side and that police supervision is another important factor. My own experience-and I travel the roads of my electorate of Lyne quite a lot, particularly the Pacific Highway-is that where there is police supervision on the roads one does not see nearly the number of accidents that would otherwise occur.

It is nice to know that the breathalyser effort today has achieved a considerable effect. Previously one in every two accidents actually related to alcohol; today it is one in every three, which is a decided improvement. I think there must be a greater sense of responsibility on the part of our people who drive vehicles. As I said earlier, our school training program is one factor, but people have to be told and the younger generation must be told because they are the ones who are suffering; up to 36 per cent of the fatal accidents today in Australia involve people under 25 years of age. This is very, very concerning.

Is receiving a driving licence a right or is it a privilege within our society? I know it is a right but it is also a privilege because one can go out and drive upon the roads. We have to get that message across as best we can. The personal element in this is very important indeed. Gradually we are improving our driving standards. Our States are doing a reasonably good job with their L plates and with their P plates. Compared with other nations of the world we have not trained our drivers as well as we should in this regard.

Let me turn to the vehicle because the vehicle itself is a most important factor. Over the years our safety design standards have greatly improved and, slowly, we are building ourselves up to the international standards of vehicle quality. Research, of course, has pointed this out to us. Being a farmer, I often think of the value of roller bars on a tractor. There were many accidents on farms and on roads because tractors without roller bars were turning over. That safety was not there. So this is being taken today into the vehicle industry generally, particularly in our larger semi-trailers and the trucks that are becoming much more numerous today on the roads.

We can refer to seat belts. They have been a major factor, like the breathalyser, in overcoming fatalities because the seat belts have proved themselves to be an advantage. These are the measures that we have to look at. There are approximately 8 1/2 million motor vehicles today within Australia, and about 450,000 motor cycles. When we talk of motor vehicles we must never forget the motor cycles or the pushbikes, because approximately 100 children were killed on bikes last year in Australia. These are the things that we have to recognise.

I want to say something about the condition of roads because in the House on Tuesday of this week I was one who participated in the debate on the Australian Land Transport (Financial Assistance Amendment) Bill. It is interesting to note that a vehicle is not safe unless the condition of the road is good. That is one of the problems that we face today within Australia-the conditions of the roads generally. I suppose that in a period of 200 years we are lucky to have the communications and the arteries of roads that we have. We are so dependent upon roads for communication; in transport, in every way, getting our produce to market and our children to school and people getting to work. We have to give a greater priority to road spending. It is disappointing.

While I give credit to the honourable member for Lilley for what she has done as Chairman of the Standing Committee on Transport Safety, I want to point out to the Government that it is extremely disappointing to us that in four years there has not been an increase in road funding in this country. I would go so far as to say that there has been, allowing for an average of 9 per cent inflation each year, 36 per cent less money in real terms being spent on our roads than we were spending back in 1983. This is rather disastrous. As much as we have to cut, and we support the cutting back of government spending, our priorities must be sensible and must realise the importance of our nation's roads.

We appeal to the Government once again to give roads a greater priority. I have here the figures from the Budget Papers of this year which indicate that there has been allocated for roads $1,245m in each of the years from 1984-85 to 1987-88. In fact there is only $1,244m this year, a reduction of $1m. Those are the dollar terms. As to the actual value of the dollar, allowing for the inflationary trend, there is at least 35 to 40 per cent less money being spent today on roads, irrespective of the fact that we have the bicentennial road funding program in operation today. Where would we be without that fund? We would be in a disastrous situation so far as our main arterial roads and our rural and urban local roads are concerned. I will not go into the further figures because we have not the time, but it is terribly important.

The wealth of the nation, as we say, is in the country areas of Australia. Yet, as we see in the Budget, the national roads are getting 43.3 per cent of the finance, the local roads are getting 20.5 per cent, the rural arterial roads are getting 14.8 per cent and the urban arterial roads are getting 21.4 per cent. The point which I wish to raise here is that it is the rural arterial roads and local roads that we are very concerned about. I am pleased to see Mr Peter Morris come in the House, because as the Minister for Transport he did his best with the money available to put the roads of this nation in order. I will give him that credit. We have told him our views from this side of the House and I guess that he agrees because he is dependent upon priorities of funding, too. We have pointed out on many an occasion that the priority is such that roads do demand extra expenditure because they are the arteries of Australia, they are the ones that this economy will actually depend upon-communication and transport.

It is so important that this be recognised and be recognised so far as our road safety is concerned. I live on the Pacific Highway at Taree and I phoned the Taree police this morning to find out that in the Taree district in 1984 there were 17 fatal accidents and 20 people killed; in 1985 there were 21 fatal accidents and 31 people killed; in 1986 there were 21 fatal accidents and 25 people killed. That is principally in a little area just south of the town of Taree.

I want to point out quickly some of the things that we can do to roads that will improve the situation there. The New South Wales Department of Main Roads, the police, the local council and the community have done everything that they can possibly do with the funds available to overcome the problems. It is one of the worst patches in Australia. The State road safety organisation came and looked at the area specifically. The thing about it is that we must spend the money that we have wisely in the design of the roads to overcome frustration and error and this is very important.

I believe that motorists get frustrated, not only from fatigue; if there is a narrow part of the highway and then a dual carriageway after that, as soon as motorists get on to the dual part or a wider road or a passing lane, they increase speed to pass the fellow in front. We have to look particularly at realignments to take out the sharp corners and the curves, at general signposting, electronic too-fast warning signs, the removal of trees beside the road or the placing of guards around them, speed restrictions, divided carriageways wherever we can put them, and warn people that they should rest periodically to avoid fatigue. We know that we need more police supervision on the roads. Of course, associated with this are the rescue squads, the ambulances and also the medical care. These make up a combination that we have to look to so far as road safety is concerned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to speak in support of the motion moved by my colleague the honourable member for Lilley (Mrs Darling). Members on both sides would be aware of her interest in the general area of transport safety. In the last Parliament, and indeed the Parliament before that, she was Chairman of the Standing Committee on Transport Safety, a committee on which I was pleased to serve. The new awareness of transport safety in this country is in no small measure due to the untiring work of the honourable member for Lilley. There would be no argument in this chamber about the necessity of lowering the number of deaths and injuries on Australian roads. Road accidents impose a cost on all Australians; this cost should not be measured only in financial terms, there is also the social cost and indeed a psychological cost.

SPEECH.PARA: Each weekend, especially holiday weekends, as we learn of the carnage on our roads, it is interesting to reflect that road fatalities in Australia are actually decreasing. For example, although there were 2,883 road fatalities in Australia in 1986, this figure was lower than for any year between 1964 and 1982. Road fatalities in 1987 to 30 September have fallen by 8 per cent. But, and this point must be stressed, there is still a need for continuing action to reduce fatalities and injuries resulting from road crashes. The annual cost to the community is estimated at about three billion dollars. I am proud of the record of this Government for the part it has played in reducing road accidents. A fundamental aspect of this is the Government's commitment to provide safer roads.

I noticed when the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Cowan) was speaking that he said that this Government had not done enough for roads; but, given the economic constraints that this Government has had imposed upon it, I think it is doing a good job for roads. I am particularly pleased to see the Minister for Resources (Mr Peter Morris) at the table, because it was under his guidance as the Minister for Transport that so much was done for Australian roads.

Recently I represented the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support (Mr Duncan) at the opening of an intersection at Hoddles Crossing near Moss Vale. I mention this project not only because it is in my electorate but also because; it is typical of the work that has been done by this Government in eliminating black spots. This project cost in excess of $10m and eliminated one of the accident black spots on the Hume Highway. But we are doing that not just in my electorate; we are doing that in many, many electorates throughout Australia. I listened carefully to what the honourable member for Lyne said. I know the north coast region very well, including the Pacific Highway. I say to him that it is a much, much better Pacific Highway than it was 20 years ago when I used to travel up and down it.

We are doing, given the economic restraints that were imposed on us, what we can on roads. There is never enough money, as we would all agree, to do all that we would like to do everywhere, and that applies whatever government or whatever political party occupies the treasury bench. I think the honourable member for Lyne actually made the point that you can have the safest roads in the world, but the vehicles travelling on these roads must also be safe. This Government has a commitment to ensuring safer vehicles. New certification arrangements together with regular checks on vehicle safety standards provide Australians with vehicles which are among the safest in the world. The cost of the system is only $5 per vehicle, which is recoverable through the sale of compliance plates.

A third aspect of the Government's approach is research and promotion to counter the human factor. The aim of this element of the Government's strategy is to change attitudes and promote responsible road user behaviour. Just over $2m has been spent on this activity in recent years. This basic three-pronged strategy is continuing in 1987-88. Road improvements continue, more effective police enforcement of road law infringement is apparent and the task of changing attitudes and developing more responsible road user behaviour also continues with the out and about child safety campaign, the Road Warrior film aimed at young drivers, the Right Rider motor cycle video training package which I will mention later, and the safety of older pedestrians campaign.

A road safety resource package is being developed for community groups to assist them in developing their own road safety programs. Road safety remains our most horrific social problem and despite the publicity and alarm created by other causes of death, such as drug overuse or violent crime, nothing anything near approaches the trauma and suffering of death on our roads. More Australians have been killed on our roads in the past 12 years than died on active service in World War II.

Another area of concern is the high number of accidents involving bicycles. Each year in Australia some 100 bicyclists die on our roads and about 1,000 are seriously injured. Sixty per cent are children under 16 years of age. The Transport Safety Committee inquired into bicycle helmet safety a few years back. Head injuries are a major cause of death of cyclists. There is no doubt that if all cyclists wore helmets, especially helmets complying with the Australian standards, their chances of being killed or severely injured would be greatly reduced. Bicycle safety is one of the elements of this Government's road safety activities; in fact, a number of initiatives have been taken which are intended to increase the rate of voluntary helmet wearing.

The Federal Government is also doing a great deal to encourage more bicyclists to wear helmets. Following the Molly Meldrum campaign and associated State activities there was an increase in the number of young people wearing helmets whilst riding their bicycles. Further promotion using this successful approach will continue. As part of the parallel activities, Victoria has had a rebate scheme covering the purchase of approved helmets. There has also been a number of school and bulk purchasing schemes. Perhaps other States could follow the Victorian lead.

It is desirable to improve helmet wearing rates by schoolchildren by such methods as schools requiring students to wear helmets whilst in the school's jurisdiction and perhaps they should consider bulk purchasing schemes. Whilst steps are being taken to encourage the wearing of bicycle helmets, another important aspect of bicycle safety is the establishment of minimum standards for helmet design and construction. I noticed this when I was on the committee looking into bicycle helmets. I see in the chamber other members, the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck), the Chairman, the honourable member for Lilley and the honourable member for Streeton (Mr Lamb). We were horrified, Mr Deputy Speaker, when one day we saw something like 70 helmets and the standard of some of them was quite frankly appalling. They had great deficiencies including a lack of ventilation and some of them were too heavy. We reached the conclusion that it would have been safer for some people to wear no helmet at all than to wear some of these deficient helmets. We all stand up here and talk about how important it is for children to wear helmets. We were very worried about the false sense of security incurred when a parent had purchased a helmet which was a cheap, and dare I say it, import.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just like toys.

—Yes, like toys. Those parents then thought their child had security and protection. We actually said that it would be better to wear no helmet at all than to wear some of the helmets that were on the market. In regard to bicycle helmets and the campaign to have more people, especially young people, wear them-we should not forget the oldies either-I should like to pay a tribute to my good friend Alderman Mick Pilton of Shellharbour Council, who, as a personal campaign, has promoted the wearing of bicycle helmets. He uses every opportunity and, I might say, every media outlet to promote the wearing of bicycle helmets amongst the young.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Deputy Speaker, I believe the Transport Safety Committee performed a very valuable function during the years of its existence. This work now falls to the Infrastructure Committee. I hope that the members of this Committee continue the work of the Transport Safety Committee and, indeed, take up the current reference that we had started to look at of enforcement because that is a very important area that has not been looked at very carefully in this country.

Road safety in Australia has advanced rapidly in recent years. The new era is characterised by a new approach to a problem that simply will not disappear within our lifetimes. The goal of saving lives and reducing injury is not achieved by considering the total picture. The days of simple solution and the quick fix are gone. There is a need to recognise that we are dealing with the hard part of the problem from now on. Some might argue that returns will be hard won and not spectacular. The many measures to reduce deaths and injuries need to be weighted to achieve the desired results in the most cost-effective way.

The Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support recently launched the first stage of a special road safety program specifically targeted at older pedestrians. Pedestrians are often described as a traffic system's forgotten people and older people, in particular, must feel this acutely. About one in five people who are killed on roads is a pedestrian. Two groups stand out as being particularly vulnerable: children, who make up about 20 per cent of the total pedestrian deaths, and people over 60 years of age, who make up about 40 per cent of pedestrian deaths. Already the Federal Government's out and about campaign for primary school children is addressing safety for children as pedestrians. However, the safety of older pedestrians is a much more complex issue. On the one hand, we are dealing with people who have had a lifetime's experience of coping with traffic, not that this will help anyone who simply steps out into traffic while his mind is on something else. On the other hand, we are dealing with people who may resist the idea that somehow they are not coping so well any more.

The Federal Government is mounting a nationwide campaign to demonstrate the positive actions that older pedestrians can take to protect their safety and ultimately their lives. This campaign is part of the Government's continuing effort to reduce the horrific and senseless deaths of Australians killed in road crashes. Hopefully, in the future we will see pedestrian protection receive a higher priority from all of us.

Finally, I wish to make a few comments about motorcycles. It is a few years since I have been on a motorcycle, I might add. A particular group in the community at risk on our roads is the motorcyclist. The number of motorcyclists fatally injured on our roads is extremely high. Each year they represent 14 per cent of road fatalities, yet motorcycles are only 4 per cent of registered vehicles.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you ride your brother's motorcycle?

—My brother has a motorbike, so have my two nephews; that is why I am so interested in it. Last year nearly 400 motorcycle riders and pillion passengers were killed in road crashes. Most of us will be aware also that youth and bravado coupled with inexperience all play a major part in road crashes. Motorcycle riders have benefited from a number of safety measures over the years. Compulsory helmet wearing and random breath testing are two important measures, but more needs to be done.

SPEECH.PARA: Research has shown that inexperienced riders have 20 times the risk of being killed in a crash compared with car drivers. So it would seem that the best insurance available for riders is experience. Fortunately, proper training can successfully substitute for a lot of the trial and error that goes to make up experience. The Federal Office of Road Safety has produced a motorcycle training package recently launched by the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support. I would also make the point that it is not always the motorcyclist's fault. Many drivers of motor vehicles pretend not to see or really do not see motorcyclists and I do not put all the blame on the motorcyclist. The video package aims to give motorcyclists off-road training by teaching rider skills in control and braking before they ride on the road. Training is needed because in 75 per cent of crashes motorcycle riders do not use their brakes correctly; that is, both front and rear.

Some collisions could be avoided or their severity reduced if riders had the skills to use their brakes correctly or if they could take other evasive action. All blame, as I said, for motorcycle accidents is not the fault of the cyclist. There are many drivers who do not seem to be able to see motorcyclists at all. This campaign has been endorsed by Mr Wayne Gardner, current 500cc world motorcycle champion who happens to come from the Illawarra. As the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin) so eloquently informed the House last Tuesday evening, not only does Wayne Gardner come from the Illawarra, but last Saturday he came home to the Illawarra to a richly deserved hero's welcome in which both the honourable member for Macarthur and I participated. Let me quote from the world champion:

It does not make sense to treat the road as a race track. What does make sense is to learn to ride your bike properly. Anyone can go fast. There is nothing too clever about twisting a throttle but not everyone can use their brakes properly. On the track the best riders are usually those who are able to use their brakes well. But on the road good braking is even more important. It could save you from injury or worse.
He continues:

I am delighted that the Commonwealth Government is getting behind rider training and education because it has been neglected too long. Besides, like anything, you will find that once you learn to ride properly you will enjoy it so much more and is not that what motorcycling is all about?
We all have a part to play in reducing road accidents, whether it is through our own driving behaviour, our own attitude as pedestrians, the instructions we give or the example to set for others.

TALK.START.PARA: — Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Dr H.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, this motion, to the extent that it deplores the effects of road trauma and the deaths and injuries in road accidents in Australian society and to the extent that it would urge the Government to step up its policies to lower deaths and injuries on Australian roads, is one which would command the general support of members of this House. As you said, Mr Deputy Speaker, just a little while ago, the Opposition applauds the honourable member for Lilley (Mrs Darling) for bringing the matter before the House as well as for the work she has done in this area over many years. I think I would be bound to say, however, without detracting from that, that this approbation falls short of commending the Hawke Labor Government in all aspects and particularly in the matter to which you referred and to which I will refer subsequently, Mr Deputy Speaker-the matter of road funding, or the lack thereof.

SPEECH.PARA: The statistical facts of the problem are tragic and horrific and have in fact been set out by the honourable member for Lilley. I repeat some of them for the benefit of listeners who may not have heard the earlier part of this debate. We start, for instance, from the position that on average eight people are killed and 80 seriously injured each day in road accidents around this country. Since the beginning of the decade over 22,900 people have been killed in road crashes in Australia. Next, road crashes are the largest single cause of death for people aged under 45 years, in 1984 killing 800 more people than all forms of heart disease and 300 more than cancer. For Australians, 15 to 24 years old, there are three times as many deaths from road crashes as from the next largest cause. That group, of course, would include many of those who are regular riders of motorcycles.

I second and commend the remarks of the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) who has just completed his remarks in that area. He is obviously speaking from some experience, which I actually do not share. But I do state the fact that the number of motorcyclists fatally injured on our roads is extremely high. Each year they represent 14 per cent of road fatalities, yet motorcycles are only 4 per cent of registered vehicles. Last year nearly 400 motorcycle riders and pillion passengers were killed in road crashes. So I certainly commend the remarks on the importance of proper training in this area which in some measure can be a substitute for the trial and error that goes to make up experience, which is all important but often lacking. As has been said, the approach to road safety requires systematic effort in respect of the main elements of the situation-roads, road users and vehicles.

In respect of road users, I recall that the mandatory provision of seat belts and their compulsory use, an initiative of the Victorian Liberal Government of some 17 years back, has been the single most effective road safety counter measure.

TALK.START.PARA: —And child restraints.

—And child restraints should be added, as my colleague mentions. Also I note in this context that excessive speed and drink driving, to which now increasingly is added drugs, as the honourable member for Lilley stressed, are among the most widely acknowledged causal factors in road crashes. I have no hesitation in asserting that excessive speed and drink driving, either in isolation or together, constitute irresponsible and unacceptable behaviour by drivers or riders of vehicles, as they put at risk all other road users. They very certainly directly offend the second of the great commandments that `thou shalt love thy neighbour as thyself'; or the royal law of the Scriptures, to do unto others as you would have them do unto you.

SPEECH.PARA: So albeit some people will refer to these activities of drink driving and excessive speed as merely unwise or indiscreet, it is fortunate that an increasing number of people regard it as anti-social as a minimum and criminal at its worst. Of course in this area random breath testing has been an important counter measure. Introduced in New South Wales in January 1984, the resultant effect was dramatic. Some people look for an ongoing reduction of that order, but that is not a proper expectation. The important thing is the continuing preventive effect.
I commend the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support (Mr Duncan), who in a Press statement of 14 August last stressed:

In surveys undertaken by the Federal Office of Road Safety only 2 per cent claimed that they would drive after drinking, yet, nationally, 40 per cent of drivers and motorcyclists killed still have a blood alcohol content over .05.
I admit that there has been a reduction, but still 40 per cent of those drivers or motorcyclists killed have a blood alcohol content over .05. It is a very big problem. The Minister went on:
As the Minister responsible for road safety matters I will be maintaining a concerted effort to change the attitude of people who persist in driving after drinking.

I commend the Minister. Mr Deputy Speaker, I am endeavouring to limit my remarks so that the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck) can participate in this debate. I turn to the third aspect, which is the condition of the roads. It was claimed in another Press release:

The Hawke Government has done more to assist road safety nationally than any other government since Federation. Our road system has been dramatically upgraded and motor vehicle safety standards have been improved.

I want to question that statement, particularly in the area of the provision of road funds. We all recognise the importance of containing government expenditure. It is not as if-despite the boast of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) that there is the greatest cut in government expenditure for 35 years-that that has really been done. That boast is an idle one. There was a claimed cut in excess of $3,000m. Of that, $1,000m was a cut in grants to the States, which I do not necessarily disapprove of. One thousand million dollars represented, of all things, asset sales-the sale of land in Tokyo and the ambassadorial residence in Paris and things of that order. When one looks at the remainder, while there are cuts from the Forward Estimates, the Commonwealth's own spending, in areas of its own direct responsibility, has in fact increased slightly in real terms.

I repeat: in areas of the Commonwealth's own responsibility the spending has increased slightly in real terms. That means it is to be increased more in actual money terms, despite this claim in respect of cutting. What I want to drive home is that within that context, within that framework, the provision of funds for road funding has been held constant in money terms. In virtually most other areas spending is to go up in money terms so that in real terms the level is the same; in this area of road funding it has been held level in money terms. It is to be the same this coming year, as it was last year, and as it was the year before. So this represents a very significant reduction in the Government's provision of road funding, of the order of 20 or 40 per cent in real terms depending on the index used. I was going to go on and point out that this has come home to me in my own area in respect of the freeway from Pearces Corner to Berowra, a most important commercial and defence artery carrying all the traffic to the north in New South Wales and very important for Hornsby and surrounding suburbs.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have done a lot.

—I have, indeed, endeavoured to push this project along, as my colleague says, basically because of its effect in relation to the development of Hornsby, not only residentially, but also as a commercial and shopping centre. That project which was set down for completion by May 1988 has now been pushed back to 1989 or who knows when. The Minister for Resources (Mr Peter Morris) and former Minister for Transport is at the table at the moment. I know he has done much to further that project and indeed for the whole matter of the highway north to Newcastle. I commend him for that effort.

SPEECH.PARA: I suspect that perhaps what has been behind this cut in the allocation of funds has been the intervention of the New South Wales State Government. I suspect that some of the funds, as I said the other day, that should have gone to this freeway, have been directed by the Unsworth Labor Government in New South Wales to its pet project, the Darling Harbour. What we have in New South Wales is the Unsworth Government-`the Brereton-Unsworth Government' might be the better description-which is consumed with the provision of `monuments and circuses for the people' at the cost of getting ahead with the more basic factors that contribute to the welfare of the people of New South Wales, such as this road. I will not elaborate further on that point in the interests of allowing a short period for my colleague the honourable member for Franklin.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lamb Mr A.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to join the honourable member for Lilley (Mrs Darling), the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Cowan), the honourable member for Berowra (Dr Harry Edwards) and the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) in this debate. Road safety is one of those things we all agree with, something we are all working hard for, and so this debate is essentially bipartisan. I notice that two honourable members opposite have introduced the subject of road funds-as they quite rightly should have-but I do not wish to dwell on that, except to say that one can argue all day about the level of funds. It is simply true that there are never enough dollars, there is never enough money for road funding. I would agree with that. I think that given, however, the general cuts in government expenditure, which the general public demand so that they can have lower taxes, it has been some achievement of the Minister for Resources (Mr Peter Morris), who is now at the table, that we have been able to maintain in dollar terms at least consistently over the last three years, a level of $1,250m a year to be spent on roads from Federal government sources.
—What is great about that?

—I will tell you what is great about it. It is great that people like you go out in the community and argue strongly for cuts in government expenditure, except in the single area that you might be interested in. You cannot have it both ways. I think it is a compliment to the Minister and this Government that the road funding has been maintained. As I said, Mr Deputy Speaker, I want to concentrate on road safety as much as anything in this debate and to give some recognition of that to the bipartisan approach that is necessary towards this topic.

SPEECH.PARA: Since the beginning of this decade, as other speakers have pointed out, we have lost some 23,200 Australian citizens in road crashes in Australia. It is not a small number; it is almost the size in total of the population of Queanbeyan. We are talking about a large country town being wiped out in 7 1/2 years. That is the magnitude of the losses of Australian lives. In fact, the number, if extended over a 12-year period, rivals those of our Australian forces who were killed on active service in World War II. So we are not talking about insignificant numbers, and members in this House have a right to be greatly concerned about the effects of road trauma on Australian society.

The honourable member for Berowra pointed out, for instance, that road crashes are the single largest cause of death for people aged under 45. The two great killers of our society, heart disease and cancer, ran a poor second and third to our road killer as one of the greatest killers. He pointed out that on average eight people are killed and 80 seriously injured each day in road crashes around the country. That means that while we are talking here in this debate for an hour and a quarter, a number of people-if you spread the statistics evenly-have been seriously injured, and possibly one or two deaths have occurred in that time. We cannot go on talking; we have to take action, and that is what this debate should be more about.

Road crashes cost the Australian community in excess of three billion dollars each year, and based on the 1985 estimates each fatality costs $300,000, representing a community cost of some $881m in 1985. Each serious injury costs $52,000, representing a community cost of some $1,500m in 1985. Approximately a billion, or $1,000m, is attributable to the cost of minor injuries and property damage. I think one should be aware, too, when talking about those aggregate figures, of the personal and family trauma resulting from road accidents, as well as those national costs.

I am talking about the lives, the potential of those people, the skills and the contributions to family, love and care, and the contributions to society represented by those statistics. They are not included in those money terms but they are just as important to the human way of life as actual cost to the community. I will give two examples: one very serious accident occurred in my own electorate at Healesville. In the late afternoon or the early evening five young girls set out for a twenty-first birthday party for one of them, their lives before them, their whole future, their future marriage, having children and so on all to come; and in the other direction came a young man, a good sportsman. All of them as a result of an accident were killed, wiped out. One can imagine the impact on the town of Healesville where those girls and the young boy all went to school together. They knew each other well and suddenly four or five families were affected, devastated by a single split second accident. One just cannot really comprehend, unless one is directly involved in that sort of thing, the impact of road trauma on human lives.

My wife's family, only a few years ago, suffered something similar. Her cousin, a very promising architecture student at Melbourne University, was hitchhiking during the Easter holidays in Tasmania. He was picked up by some other tertiary student friends in a van and a freak accident occurred. The van slipped in gravel and in a split second once again another life was snuffed out. Two years later that young man's father was killed in another freak accident, not far from his own home in the Gippsland area, just outside my electorate. That man was noted for his responsible and careful driving. So there is no way that we can avoid all accidents. Some will inevitably happen.

What we can do, what governments can do, is make sure that there are programs spending on those factors which contribute to avoidable accidents. I think that is what we should be talking about. The second part of the honourable member for Lilley's motion here before the House commends the Government for the policies arrived at in lowering the deaths and injury of drivers on Australia's roads. It is true that our road safety road performance has improved over the years. From a peak of 3,800 road deaths in 1970 the number has dropped steadily, if somewhat erratically, to 2,883 last year.

The trend line downwards has occurred over the last decade covering both the Fraser years of government and the Hawke years of government. But significant drops have occurred since the change of government. This year we may be rewarded, we may be headed for the lowest level yet since 1983, the best year, if I can call it that, for road deaths over the last 25 years. That is not to say that governments of different political persuasions are better than the others. But I will in the next few minutes give some statistics that indicate that either cumulatively or incrementally contributions by previous governments and this Hawke Government have increased the downslide in deaths on the roads. We know that the vehicle numbers and distances travelled, along with the population, have increased rapidly over the years and the improvement in road safety is more clear and marked when we examine not just the absolute number of fatalities but also measure it against those growths.

In terms of fatalities per 10,000 vehicles registered, the incidence has dropped from eight or nine in the 1960s to just over three over the last four years. Fatalities per 100,000 population over the same time have dropped from 25 or 30 to around 18, while the fatalities per 100,000,000 vehicle kilometres travelled has stabilised at one-third of what it was in the 1960s. The record is impressive, especially over the years of the Hawke Government. But we would be chauvinistic and false to claim that only the Labor Government has contributed to this improvement.
