All governments are committed, State and Federal, all persuasions, and all have contributed and improvements are built as much on past initiatives and contributions as they are on more recent ones.

Road safety advances are incremental and are harder to achieve, as the honourable member for Throsby pointed out, each year. This makes the current Government's achievements even more remarkable. But we have a long way to go yet before we compare favourably with other similar countries. In a comparison Australia, the United States, United Kingdom, Canada, New Zealand, Japan, Sweden and Germany, countries we can conveniently and accurately compare ourselves with, and using the same statistics as I did earlier, fatalities per 10,000 vehicles, fatalities per 100,000 population or fatalities per 100 million vehicle kilometres travelled, Australia ranks well behind all those countries except New Zealand. But, and we have to point this out, the gap is closing gradually.

This Labor Government is not content to see Australia simply catch up, it wants Australia to be in the forefront of road safety. The Minister responsible, Mr Peter Duncan, the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support, is as committed to this objective as was the Minister before him, the Minister for Resources, Mr Peter Morris, who is now at the table and who oversaw the big improvements over the last four years. Future improvements will come, as they have from improvements in areas before, in better roads. Despite the debate about the lack of money-as I said, there is never enough money for roads-we must admit that we do travel on better national highways and if there is a fault that we are not getting good roads in local roads and rural arterial roads, that depends on the distribution of Federal Government funds by State governments as much as anything else. I know that the Minister at the table worked very hard to try to secure a better deal for rural roads in Victoria. Hopefully, the new Minister, Mr Duncan, will bring that about.

The future improvements for better roads should always be continued, just as we have gained improvements from safer vehicles through the Australian design rules, another matter which the honourable member for Throsby gave some attention to in his speech. I believe that the biggest gains are to be made by concentrating on the human factor, through education, both formal and informal, and through appropriate law enforcements. The Government, to its credit, has spent over $2m in recent years on research and promotion to counter the human factor in road accidents. Through the Federal Office of Road Safety half a million dollars each year has been spent on amassing a national mass data system. One cannot target or plan campaigns if one does not have a good data collection. It is essential to pinpoint the areas for further work for government action. Through the Federal Office of Road Safety the Government has promoted education of young children, inexperienced drivers and riders and elderly pedestrians. The purpose is to change the attitudes and behaviour of those groups, in fact, the whole community indirectly, towards road use, to bring about more responsible and defensive behaviour.

I turn to some of the programs. The out and about program is designed for grades 2 to 4, the 7- to 9-year, olds at primary schools. This is in booklet form and is designed to encourage children so that by the time they are able to ride a bike responsibly and cross roads on their own at the age of 9 they have had some preparation. A film called Road Warrior, which is directed towards young drivers, is not an attack on young people as such; it is a demonstration that young people, because we do not give them licences until they are 18, are inexperienced drivers. It is the inexperience associated with other factors confronting youth, the socialisation process, that demands that they be a target audience. Right Rider is a video training package produced at a cost of some $350,000 and directed towards preventive motorcycle safety.

Finally, a television campaign has been directed to our eldest and senior citizens of our community, for the safety of older pedestrians. All these campaigns embody the proper technique of communication and persuasion; that is, using an appropriate medium, employing colloquial language for the particular age group and role models with whom the groups can strongly identify and aim to emulate. Each campaign is targeted to groups which form an overwhelmingly high percentage of road deaths in relation to their size and the total population. Motorcyclists, as the honourable member for Throsby pointed out, form 14 per cent of road fatalities, yet only 4 per cent of registered vehicles are motorcycles. Inexperienced riders have 20 times the risk of being killed in a crash, compared with car drivers, yet experienced motorcycle riders have only twice the risk of car drivers.

Older pedestrians form 18 per cent of road fatalities and yet 40 per cent of those victims are aged 60 and over and 20 per cent are children. Obviously they have to be a targeted group and it is to be noted that it is between the hours of 4 and 8 p.m. that elderly people are the most vulnerable. I congratulate those behind the campaigns for their recognition that targeting is the most likely avenue to bring about desired results. It is an on-going task to turn back the chilling tide of road deaths. I congratulate the Federal Office of Road Safety and the Ministers responsible. I urge them to continue their work and the financing of these essential programs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Goodluck Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I would like to congratulate the honourable member for Lilley (Mrs Darling) on introducing this motion and thank my good friend the honourable member for Berowra (Dr Harry Edwards) for giving me four minutes to speak in this debate. Bruce John Goodluck can say a lot in four minutes. I would also like to compliment the Minister for Resources (Mr Peter Morris), who is at the table, for when he was the Minister for Transport, he gave the Standing Committee on Transport Safety a lot of support, but I regret that we have closed that committee down. It has been incorporated with some other committee. I have not had time to look at it. Self-praise is no recommendation, but, as a committee, I thought that we did a dashed good job in promoting awareness of problems associated with road safety in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: We brought down many reports that this Government is starting to bring into play; State governments are starting to wake up to the fact that they were good reports, that they were reports given a lot of research, a lot of thought and a lot of time. And sometimes, I think, in this Parliament-and I have said it before-a lot of politicians join fashionable committees because they think they can get up the ladder a lot quicker and sometimes they did not give transport safety enough thought. That happened on both sides of the House regrettably. It was one of those committees that were bi-partisan, where the members worked together without getting into politics or trying to outplay one another, because we were doing it in the common good of trying to save young lives and old lives in Australia.

If we had had a war and lost a certain number of lives each year there would have been a hue and cry. Everybody would have been walking in the streets protesting. But each day on the roads, on average, over the last 10 years 10 people have died, one invariably a young motor cyclist. Regrettably, publicity comes, of course, the media do their job, spasmodically, but it is not one of those ongoing things. And the speeches today have been excellent. It is good to see my friend Mr Bob Katter, the honourable member for Kennedy, coming in because he was the Chairman before the honourable member for Lilley and he did a lot in that Committee to promote road safety, to tell the people of Australia that we need to do something if we are to save lives on the road in Australia.

The honourable member for Streeton (Mr Lamb) made a very good point. We talk about the number of people who die but what about the people who are left behind, the parents? I am a father and when my daughters started to learn to drive the worst possible thing was waiting for them to come home at night. Sometimes they came home rather late, too.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where were they?
—Do not ask that question.
—A negligent parent.

—Yes, all right; interrupt me, good. But I was trying to make the point that we are all parents or grandparents; some are grandparents, I am not, I am not old enough. I ask honourable members to be serious for a minute. The point that I was making concerns the suffering, the problems associated with young people losing their lives and, of course, older people. So we have all got a part to play in a bipartisan way.

SPEECH.PARA: There were a few things said today that I could disagree with. This Government has gone down the road of normal upmanship. I understand that. But we have to be careful of that, we have to work together if we are going to reduce the road toll in Australia. It saddens me that we changed our committee system, that we have not got a committee specifically on road safety, because it is going to be with us, it cannot go on--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It is now 2 p.m. In accordance with standing order 104, as amended for this session, the time allotted for precedence to General Business has expired. The honourable member for Franklin will have leave to continue his speech when the debate is resumed. The resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day under General Business for the next sitting.
—I call the honourable member for Hume.
—Madam Speaker, is the Minister for Administrative Services coming into the House today?
—I call the honourable member for North Sydney.
—Where is the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Madam Speaker?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —As there are no questions without notice--

INTERJECT.PARA: Mr Spender-Madam Speaker, I raise a point of order. It is Question Time-2 o'clock-and the practice of the House is that if Ministers are not going to be here an announcement is made on ministerial arrangements. Here is the Minister for Administrative Services at last. I am glad to see the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Administrative Services. Have the agents appointed by the Government to sell the Grumman Tracker aircraft sold all the spare parts belonging to those aircraft? Because the Government agreed to sell the spare parts separately, has the Korean Navy now withdrawn its interest in purchasing the aircraft in a multi-million dollar transaction? Did the agents purchase all the spare parts from the Government for about half a million dollars and on-sell them overseas for up to $5m? What steps were taken to satisfy the Government that the spares were properly valued at only half a million dollars? What assurances were received that the aircraft could be disposed of without any spare parts? Finally, can the Minister explain how the Government allowed a multi-million dollar sale to slip through its fingers, and how the taxpayers received half a million dollars for spares and nothing for the 14 aircraft which are now rotting in Jervis Bay, all of which were valued at many millions of dollars?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am a little at a loss to understand the thrust of what the shadow Minister is talking about. Basically, I think he has his facts astray. For instance, in June 1984 these Tracker aircraft and a large quantity of spares were declared for sale. I am informed that between August 1984 and June 1986 three companies involving similar groups of directors were appointed to market the package. The companies were Ford and Vlahos Australia, Ford and Vlahos Australia Pty Ltd and Defence Equipment Pty Ltd. Ford and Vlahos, was also involved in the attempted sales of the Hercules aircraft. It has not been very successful, I can tell the House, on any front. So the arrangements were unsatisfactory both for the Hercules aircraft and for these aircraft.

ANSWER.PARA: There have been some problems with regard to particular aspects of that company's activities, and the Australian Federal Police are investigating these matters at present. I have asked that they be followed up very stringently. In July 1986-this comes to the tail of the honourable member's question-new registrations of interest were invited and in December 1986 Hookway Aerospace Pty Ltd obtained the sole rights for five years to market the aircraft. The Commonwealth has received payment in full. With regard to the technical aspects of the question, it is the first I have heard of the Korean connection. I will certainly look into it. As far as I am concerned, my Department has informed me that Hookway Aerospace Pty Ltd obtained the sole rights to market and it has paid its commitment to the Government in full for the aircraft and for what remains of the spare parts.

TALK.START.PARA: —What remains of the spare parts?

—I have already told the honourable member that the company that had the sole agency rights was unsuccessful in selling them and we are not satisfied with certain aspects of its handling of the matter. Those aspects are in the hands of the Federal Police. I have directed the Federal Police, through my Department, to keep up their investigations of those matters most stringently.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Industrial Relations. I refer to reports of stoppages by Federal public servants today and proposals for a 24-hour strike tomorrow. Can the Minister advise the House of the Government's attitude towards this action?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the case, as the honourable member for Prospect said, that there are stop work meetings in every capital city of Australia today by public servants who are members of the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association (ACOA) and the Federated Clerks Union (FCU). They have before them proposals from their executives for a 24-hour stoppage tomorrow and for rolling stoppages thereafter. It is the Government's view that that action is utterly unnecessary, pointless and quite counterproductive. The background to this matter is that there have been, for some months now, negotiations taking place between the Government and the unions, particularly on the office restructuring, which is the restructuring of classifications for office based staff which will be the main basis by which a second tier increase can be awarded to public servants. The unions have also known for months that the Government's position is that we would need to get full cost offsets before we could agree to a second tier increase. Recently, we gave them a proposed package of measures, which includes the office restructuring, and also some other measures which are required in order to enable us to have a satisfactory package to provide for the second tier increase. The unions' reaction to that was to discuss it for three hours, walk out and then threaten the stoppages which are now occurring, and industrial action after that. They have demanded the withdrawal of some of the items which were in that package as a precondition of the recommencement of negotiations. We have told them that that is an unacceptable position, that we are prepared to negotiate on the whole package on which there is some flexibility, but that we are not prepared to remove items piecemeal on demand from the unions. They have also organised the stop work meetings which I have mentioned. The program we now face is one of considerable industrial action if the members support the executive in the recommended action.

ANSWER.PARA: The effect of all this is to delay members of the Federal Public Service from receiving a second tier increase. Already their union officials have wasted this week which could have been used productively to negotiate the package. So long as industrial action is taking place, or there is a threat of it, the Government will certainly not be resuming negotiations on this matter. The members of the ACOA and the Federated Clerks Union should understand that it is not the Government that is delaying the finalisation of this issue; it is their own unions that are refusing to negotiate. They have already wasted the time I have mentioned.

Union members of the ACOA and the FCU should understand that the Government will not accept a situation in which the key areas of government activity are targeted for disruption. If the unions go down the path that they are now contemplating they will meet a very strong Government reaction.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Administrative Services. It is interesting to hear from the Minister today that we now have the Grumman aircraft debacle following the Amann affair and the Hercules fiasco. Does the Minister recall the haste with which the Prime Minister moved to capitalise on his public relations stunt by sweeping aside all bureaucratic rules in order to get the Hercules aircraft delivered quickly to Ethiopia? Will the Minister confirm that a special unit within the Australian Federal Police, which has investigated Amann Aviation Pty Ltd and is now, as we learned today, investigating Grumman as well, is also investigating the Hercules disaster? Will the Minister advise the House whether the Hercules investigation arose because of the Prime Minister's action? Will the Minister confirm the nature of all the police investigations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first thing I should say is that I am unaware of any connection between Amann Aviation Pty Ltd, the Hercules transaction and the Grumman transaction.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Seeing that the honourable member has asked a detailed question, I now ask him to have the decency and, I would hope, the astuteness to listen to a detailed answer. I want to tell the honourable member about the Hercules aircraft. The first point to make is that they were made available for sale back in 1977 and there were four attempts between 1978 and 1981 to sell them by tender. Contrary to certain stories in the media, nothing like $30m was ever offered by tender for the 11 original aircraft.

ANSWER.PARA: Subsequent to that, the Fraser Government entered into an exclusive agency arrangement with an outfit named Ford and Vlahos Pty Ltd of California. This company sold two aircraft in 1983. In 1984, the United States Government withheld permission for the sale of two aircraft to a Colombian company and money paid in connection with these aircraft is the subject of litigation in the Australian Capital Territory Supreme Court at the moment. One further aircraft was refurbished and leased to the Red Cross for famine relief in Ethiopia in 1986.

The agency arrangements with Ford and Vlahos-that is, the company that the former Government appointed-proved most unsatisfactory and steps have been taken to ensure that such problems do not recur. We have heard, I think in this House-certainly in the media, I think on the Four Corners program-about a number of extensions to this Ford and Vlahos company that were granted by the Fraser Government and by former Ministers. There were six extensions by Ministers for Administrative Services under the previous Government and, I think, five or six by Ministers of the present Government-all on the recommendation of the Department of Administrative Services, I might add.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are ducking.

—What I am saying is right. By any judgment, the sole agency arrangements with the private sector operators were proved unsuccessful. The Australian Federal Police are inquiring into two aspects of all of this, at my direction. They are the alleged theft of spares and alleged fraud against the Australian Development Assistance Bureau during this period under Ford and Vlahos. The agency arrangements that honourable members opposite commenced were terminated by us in July 1986.

ANSWER.PARA: In 1986, new registrations of interest were sought and an entirely different exclusive agency arrangement for the sale of the nine remaining aircraft was established in March 1987 with Military Aircraft Sales Pty Ltd (MAS). The financial arrangements signed on 16 March last required a substantial payment to the Commonwealth, with a guarantee that it would be paid by 15 April and with the major balance due to be paid by 15 May. As far as the private sector exclusive agency with MAS was concerned, there was a failure to pay the guarantee by the due date and also a failure to pay the balance by the due date. The Government then extended to 12 June.

In early August, when I took over the portfolio, I found that no further payments had been made. I approved the termination of the contract with Military Aircraft Sales on 13 August 1987. I gave the company 50 days to reach an agreement on a new contract with the Commonwealth which had to include payment of a down payment and automatic termination if the company failed to pay the balance on an agreed date-no more extensions to these outfits. No such agreement was reached and neither I nor the Government will extend again.

On 19 October this year, I approved a sales strategy involving direct individual sales by the Commonwealth against the firmest of guidelines. There will be no agencies with exclusive sale rights. They will be dealing directly with the Commonwealth on an individual competitive basis only. If MAS wishes to compete with other players, it may do so. But, as far as I am concerned, while I hold this portfolio there will be no more dealings with the types of exclusive private sector, small time agencies that honourable members opposite started as far back as 1981.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is your predecessor--
—Order! The honourable member for Deakin will remember that, while the Chair accepts some interjections, continued interjections are disorderly.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Community Services and Health. I preface the question by referring to the fact that the Government's aged accommodation program has been very warmly received in the community, but there appear to be some residual misunderstandings about the extent to which the program is being implemented. I ask the Minister: Will he inform the House and the Australian community about the progress that the Government is making in connection with the implementation of that program.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I acknowledge the question from the honourable member for Charlton. I recognise that he is one of the members of this House who recognise that the challenge of aged care is one of the great challenges facing late twentieth century governments in all advanced industrial societies. As with so many of these problems, this problem was neglected by our predecessors, so that the quite formidable and difficult questions have had to be addressed by this Government. We started with the basic principle that we should provide as broad a range of services as possible for the aged so that they could choose between the most appropriate care services in terms of their social, medical and emotional needs. Thus, we have emphasised home care and hostel care as well as nursing home care.

ANSWER.PARA: We have already put in place funding arrangements for non-government nursing homes which will protect the residents from financial exploitation and put an end to the rorts that occurred in some aspects of the nursing home industry, which were recognised, of course, in the report of the all-party Senate Select Committee on Private Hospitals and Nursing Homes. At the same time, we have achieved some measure of control over nursing home costs while providing the industry with greater flexibility and efficiency incentives. We have adopted for the first time in this country a clear needs based approach to residential accommodation, and we have planned that, again for the first time, so that we get a fair and proper distribution of residential accommodation for the aged across the country. We have substantially increased and indexed recurrent subsidies to the hostel industry to provide for more elderly people. We were the first national government to establish proper assessment systems so that, again, there could be appropriate assessment of the needs of the aged. We have increased substantially capital subsidies to the hostel sector to assist the industry to cater especially for disadvantaged groups-particularly Aboriginal and other ethnic groups.

I am very glad today to be able to announce the commitment we have made for the next three years in residential accommodation for the aged. We commit ourselves to provide 12,197 places in nursing homes and hostels in that period. There will be 1,295 nursing home places and 10,902 places in hostels. I will be announcing next week the details of this year's program which will include 396 nursing home places and 3,552 hostel places. We note the greater emphasis on hostels, which is in recognition of the need to boost this sector to give people greater access to a more appropriate range of residential care services. Next week, when announcing these details, we will also indicate the location of the new places and that location will be part of our long term strategy to ensure a fair distribution of residential places for the aged across this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I draw his attention to the report in the Australian today to the effect that `influential members of Suva's new power elite are counselling Colonel Sitiveni Rabuka to ``play the Moscow card'' and take up long-standing offers of help from the Soviet Union' and the suggestion in the report that the proposed Australian Council of Trade Unions flight bans have been a contributing factor to this counselling. Does the Minister agree that moves by Fiji to play the Moscow card would be damaging to our national interests and destabilising to the South Pacific region? Is the Government willing to put Australian's national interests at risk by allowing the Australian Council of Trade Unions to go ahead with its proposed bans?

—There is no evidence that Fiji intends to play what is described by the honourable member as the Moscow card. There is a report in the Australian but, if one accepts that as evidence, one is easily persuaded. I answered a question on the Australian Council of Trade Unions bans yesterday and a little later the Minister for Industrial Relations will be responding to a matter of public importance on the topic.

—Will the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs inform the House of the details of his recent trip to Asia, especially to the refugee camps? Can he inform the House of what conclusions he has drawn in regard to refugee policy and immigration policy in the light of his trip?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Calwell for his question. It was very pleasing to note, in talking to the various authorities in Thailand, Japan and Hong Kong, that Australia is held in the highest regard for the programs we have carried out over the last 12 years in the settlement of refugees from Indo-China. That is due to the success of both the Fraser Administration and the Hawke Administration in dealing with this question. We have now settled in this country about 100,00 people from that area at the same time as the United States has taken about 845,000, Canada about 120,000 and France about 120,000. The first thing to say is that, to the extent to which we are involved in discussions in this region, we are held in the highest regard because of what we have been able to achieve in the settlement of these people.

ANSWER.PARA: The problem is not diminishing very much. There is still an enormous problem in this region. Tens of thousands of Kampucheans, Laotians and Vietnamese are still in camps in Thailand. I was able to visit the camps there and those in Hong Kong. An increasing number of people are now coming from North Vietnam to the camps of Hong Kong and this is of great concern to the authorities there. Whilst our quotas for the refugee and special humanitarian programs for 1987-88 have been set at 12,000, in my discussions I was unable to indicate to any of the authorities that we would have the capacity to increase that number. I indicated that the number we will take from Thailand this year is 2,100 and the number we will take from Hong Kong is 475, as originally planned in the program which I previously announced to the Parliament.

However, a great number of other political problems have to be settled and I will be discussing many of the matters that were raised with me with the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade because, obviously, as honourable members on both sides of the House know, the only way this massive problem can be solved is by political solutions. There is no way that the major settlement countries-which are now the United States of America, Canada, ourselves, France, Britain, New Zealand and others-can possible solve the problem by trying to achieve the total settlement of those people who may wish to settle in a third country. The issues have to be solved politically. It was very rewarding to be able to talk to people in all of these areas about what is trying to be achieved and the work that is now being done by not only governments, including the Thai Government, but also the various voluntary agencies that are working in the camps both there and in Hong Kong. To the extent that we are able to assist, our reward is that we are looked upon with great favour in this region and we are spoken of very warmly for what we have achieved. Both the Fraser and the Hawke governments can be extremely proud of what they have done for this country.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: LOAN COUNCIL BORROWING LIMITS: SOUTH AUSTRALIA

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Treasurer. I refer him to the fact that the Chief Executive of the South Australian Financial Authority wrote to the South Australian State Government Insurance Commission on 19 November 1986 pointing out that it is possible to circumvent South Australia's Loan Council borrowing limits by using the State Government Insurance Commission as a conduit for overseas loans. Is the Treasurer aware that this letter was written on the express instructions of the South Australian Premier and that, in exploiting this loophole, as instructed by the Premier, the South Australian Government was able to exceed its previously agreed Loan Council borrowing limit by 126 per cent? How does the Treasurer reconcile this breach of the spirit of the Loan Council borrowing limits with his stated attempts to control Australia's exploding overseas debt?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first thing is that our debt is not exploding; the rate of increase in our debt is slowing down. If the honourable member wishes to frame a question he should at least frame it in terms of there being a very greatly diminished slowdown in the accumulation of that debt as a result of the Government's policies. On the first point, I am not aware of the correspondence to which the honourable member referred. I can only say that whenever we have become aware that States may attempt to circumvent the global limits of the Loan Council arrangements, we have taken up those issues with the States to have the position corrected, as we did recently with Victoria in respect of the Victorian Equity Trust.

ANSWER.PARA: I will examine the issues raised in the honourable member's question to see whether the claims he has made-directly or by implication-are correct. But I ask the honourable member, `Where do you think the damage was done when the States bolted from the Loan Council?'. The answer is: `Your mate's infrastructure program'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Years and years ago.

—Does the honourable member know when it was? It was in 1982 or 1981. When I became Treasurer only 25 per cent of the States' borrowings was under the control of the Loan Council. We re-established the global limits and brought all the surrogate borrowing instruments back under control. We have been reducing the gross public sector borrowing requirement, obviously through the Commonwealth deficit and the States, and we are now reducing the net PSBR by squeezing down the cash reserves or liquid reserves of the States. That position should never have obtained.

ANSWER.PARA: It was the height of folly and irresponsibility on the part of the last conservative Government in this country to allow the States to borrow willy-nilly for a thing called the infrastructure program which, I think, was thought up a couple of hours before the meeting actually occurred. It was a typical case of policy on the run, no forethought, no regard for the long term economic interests of the country and, as usual, as I often say, guess who was left to clean up the mess? It was us. In 1984 we put a ring around the States with the global limits and we are bringing them down. I will examine the implications of the claims made by the honourable member in his question, but let us not have any indignation about the Opposition's role in the PSBR. It allowed a disgraceful haemorrhaging of the public sector borrowings of this country over the last few years it was in office.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ROYAL AUSTRALIAN AIR FORCE: PILOT SEPARATIONS

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel to recent Press reports indicating that pilot separations from the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) have reached record levels. I ask the Minister to indicate what steps are being taken to ensure that the continued growth in civilian aircraft traffic does not give rise to continuing losses of pilots from the Defence Force at such a level as would prejudice our defence capability.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kelly The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a fact that separation rates of RAAF pilots over the last couple of years have been considerably higher than was previously the Air Force's experience. In the 20-year period 1966-67 to 1985-86, the average annual loss was 47 pilots. In 1985-86, 70 pilots left the Air Force, and in 1986-87, 107 left. So far this year, 75 pilots have either resigned or retired. The number of new pilots graduating is between 55 and 65 per annum. Separations-that is, people leaving-are occurring for a number of reasons. About 40 per cent of the separations in 1986-87 involved those who had completed 20 years of service and were pensionable. Many of the other 60 per cent were responding to pressure from the private sector, particularly from Qantas Airways Ltd. In 1986-87, 32 of the pilots we lost indicated that they were going to Qantas, and so far this year about 13 have gone to Qantas.

ANSWER.PARA: We are adopting a range of measures to deal with this problem. We have confronted it in two ways. First, we have had discussions with Qantas and, secondly, we have taken steps internally. Of course, Qantas is going through a growth phase, and one of the reasons for that is the success of this Government's tourism policy. Of course, we hope that that will continue. However, it is a fact that when Qantas is recruiting more of our pilots are likely to go there. I recently met with John Menadue, the Chief Executive of Qantas, to discuss the issue. It was a very fruitful meeting. There was general agreement that Qantas and the Air Force should work more closely in the future to ensure that Qantas's recruiting activities are better understood and that they are not pursued in such a way as to prejudice the operational capability of the Air Force. A range of practical measures were proposed which would help to minimise the impact of continuing pilot losses from the RAAF to Qantas, and I am confident that the talks that have taken place will lead to a satisfactory continuing relationship with Qantas.

Pilots are very expensive to train. To ensure that the Defence Force receives a reasonable return for its investment in training, the return of service obligation for pilots has recently been increased from six years to eight years. Of course, this will take some time to impact. The Chief of the Air Staff has now taken additional steps to increase the attractiveness of a RAAF flying career. I would like to go into the details of some of those.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not now; it is all rubbish.

—This is an extremely important issue for this country. We are increasing the compulsory retiring age for pilots with the rank of wing commander and below to 55 years. This change will allow many of those who want to stay to do so. Also, we are introducing a limited air crew specialisation scheme which will allow an extended flying career for selected officers. This scheme may necessitate operational promotion and new salary scales at existing rank levels which recognise higher levels of experience. We are also adopting policies designed to widen promotional opportunities for non-pilots in such areas as personnel and materiel, thus reducing the demand for pilots in staff posts. To meet the need we are also increasing training opportunities, and we are looking at increasing recruitment activities and therefore recruiting more people into the Services. Also, the Chief of the Air Staff has indicated that there will need to be some reductions in the levels of activity in the operational force because of pilot shortages, but we must still give high emphasis to the training area. I believe that all of these measures, taken together, will ensure that the Air Force is able to adjust to the changing market situation and will provide a better basis on which to plan for the future.

—I draw the attention of the Acting Minister for Defence to the proposed closure of 8 Platoon, 41 Battalion, Australian Army Reserve, situated at Macksville, in the electorate of Cowper, where Reserve members are eager to continue serving Australia, and ask the Minister: Is this indicative of the Government's overall attitude to the rundown of Australia's defence forces, including the Army Reserve? Can she give an undertaking that this and other valuable units of the Army Reserve will continue and not be destroyed by departmental shortsightedness?

—The fact is that under this Government the Army Reserve has had an enhanced role in the Australian Defence Force. It is this Government that has done more to integrate the reservists into the total Defence Force than any other government in the history of this country. I have taken note of the particular unit to which the honourable member has referred, and I will give him a written response on that in line with the points he has raised.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NEW SOUTH WALES HOTELS AND CLUBS

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Consumer Affairs: Has his attention been drawn to an article appearing in today's Sydney Morning Herald which alleges that patrons in New South Wales clubs and hotels are being ripped off by the use of undersize glasses?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Staples Mr P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure that all honourable members will be interested in this matter. I know the honourable member for Lindsay has a great interest in weights and measures in a variety of industries, and I have noticed his very serious interest particularly in the racing and hotel industries.

ANSWER.PARA: Of course, many other honourable members have a great interest in weights and measures. I also commend members of the Press Gallery because they have brought this serious matter to our attention today. There was a report in the Sydney Morning Herald this morning relating to tests carried out by the Australian Capital Territory Consumer Affairs Bureau concerning undersize glasses and incorrect measures.

It is difficult to relate this problem to the Trade Practices Act; it is more a matter for the State consumer affairs agencies and their weights and measures divisions. Nonetheless, if there is a problem, I am sure it will be handled efficiently.

I know the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, who has responsibility for Australian Capital Territory weights and measures, will look into this to see whether there is any problem. I am sure he will get to the bottom of the matter so that the shouting can die down and we can continue to have consumer confidence in this and many other areas.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Is the Government considering reducing the level of Export Finance Insurance Corporation (EFIC) cover to Australian exporters and thus placing significant exports at risk? In particular, is the Minister aware that insurance cover for wheat sales to Egypt provided by EFIC is in the process of being withdrawn? Can the Minister assure the Australian wheat industry of the Government's continued support for EFIC cover to this very important and strategic Egyptian market?

—As is proper, the function of the Export Finance Insurance Corporation is being looked at at present. I mention in passing that this matter is not within my ministerial portfolio responsibility but, from time to time, I help other Ministers with comments not always helpful to myself. This matter is being looked at and the honourable member, I am sure, as a committed member of the National Party, will be pleased to know that we shall be looking at the matter on the basis of market principles.

—Can the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy advise the House on the implications for the rural community of the Government's decision to impose anti-dumping duties on imports of urea fertilisers? I ask the Minister to comment specifically in relation to the sugar industry, one of the most efficient sectors of our primary industry.
—Order! The Minister will not make any comments, but will answer the first part of the question.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question and acknowledge his representations to the Government on this issue. As the House well knows, the honourable member for Leichhardt takes a close interest in fertiliser. The simple fact is that anti-dumping duties on urea will have no impact whatsoever on farmers-even the sugar farmers whose interests he so closely guards. Through the section 96 arrangements with the States, the burden will be borne by the taxpayer, not by the farmers.

ANSWER.PARA: I note that the National Farmers Federation has been highly critical of the Government in this matter. Its Press release said that the Federation was outraged, that the Government was hypocritical, that we were mollycoddling the industry and that we were putting up the price of fertiliser by $50 a tonne. The Federation's comments are wrong. A simple telephone call would have established that farmers will be protected by the section 96 arrangements.

My colleague Senator John Button has twice reviewed the anti-dumping system to ensure that we have the most prompt and efficient operation consistent with the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade codes. This is a difficult area and this Government is committed to effective anti-dumping arrangements that adequately balance the interests of both consumers and producers. We cannot have it both ways. If the National Farmers Federation wants otherwise, it should first get its own affiliate-for example, the Australian Dairy Farmers Federation-to stop complaining about cheese imports. That is an area in which we have taken action to protect the Australian dairy industry by putting on the tariff quota arrangements. This will not affect the sugar industry. I understand the industry's concern, but some people have simply got it wrong.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Treasurer agree with his Finance Minister that to be effective a wealth tax would have to be imposed on the family home?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Finance was giving views on questions put in the Senate speculating about such a tax. I made it quite clear on behalf of the Government in the last election campaign, as did the Prime Minister, that the Government has no intention of introducing such a tax. We also made it clear in the White Paper on tax reform that we would leave the whole system subject to review, despite the provocation in the 1984 election campaign from the Opposition, and then we chose not to move on a wealth tax either. That is the Government's current position.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members-Current position.

TALK.START.PARA: —`Current' being always.

—Is the Minister for Employment Services and Youth Affairs aware of certain allegations by radio broadcaster Ron Casey that Asian immigrants are getting preferential treatment for employment from employment assistance programs through the Commonwealth Employment Service (CES)? Can the Minister answer these baseless and racist allegations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of comments made by Mr Casey, of radio station 2KY, to the effect that unemployed persons could get a job through the Commonwealth Employment Service by having plastic surgery on their eyes, to make them slanty, and their noses, and by having contact lenses fitted that give nice big black eyes. From their own knowledge of the way the local Commonwealth Employment Service operates, all honourable members will know that it is a function of that service and its employees to place job applicants with employers on the basis of the skill requirements of those employers. In making those allocations there is no basis upon which any CES officer would give preferred treatment. In respect of job training schemes, the emphasis is on the long term unemployed.

ANSWER.PARA: Credit should be given to the management of 2KY, which immediately suspended Mr Casey. Such is the nature of the allegation that I think that, unless Mr Casey apologises for the gross and misleading statements about CES officers, but more importantly withdraws the comments and apologises for the offence he has given to many Australian citizens of Asian origin, he should not be allowed to go back and pollute our airwaves.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: CADMAN; CAMERON; COBB; LANGMORE; RUDDOCK; SULLIVAN; WHITE
PETITION.TITLE: Human Embryo Experimentation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned expresses concern that some scientists in Australia are intent on undertaking destructive experimentation on human embryos. This subject was examined exhaustively by the 1985-1986 Senate Select Committee on Senator Harradine's Human Embryo Experimentation Bill which received 270 submissions and more than 2,000 pages of evidence. The report of the Senate Committee recommended in October 1986 that the Commonwealth Government make unlawful any destructive experiment which frustrated the development of the human embryo.
Your petitioners therefore request the House of Representatives and the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to:
Implement without delay the major recommendation of the Senate Select Committee to outlaw destructive experiments on human embryos.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cadman,Mr Ian Cameron,Mr Cobb,Mr Langmore,Mr Ruddock,Mrs Sullivan and Mr White.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: BEALE; JENKINS; KENT; MILTON; SAUNDERSON; SCOTT
PETITION.TITLE: Food Irradiation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth. We most strongly oppose the process of Food Irradiation by radioactive Cobalt 60 or any other radioactive substance.

We oppose the introduction of regulations that will facilitate the food irradiation process by State Governments. We express our deep concern at this attempt to extend the use of radioactive substances and exposure of workers to radiation.

We call on the Government to immediately ban the importation of radioactive Cobalt 60 or other radioactive substances and to immediately disallow the regulations that permit the irradiation of food here in Australia.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beale,Mr Jenkins,Mr Kent,Mr Milton,Mr Saunderson and Mr Scott.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: CAMERON; DOBIE; FISCHER; PORTER; SHARP; WHITE
PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Identity Card
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned citizens, respectfully showeth:
That we are totally opposed to the introduction of the Labor Government's Identity Card;

That this form of national and compulsory identification will be intrusive, costly for taxpayers and business and will not be effective in combating the growing problems of tax evasion, illegal immigrants or social security;

PETITION.TITLE: Pine Gap
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned, call on the Federal Government to give notice to terminate the lease of the US base at Pine Gap before October 1986.
We believe that in the interests of world peace and the Australian people, this lease should be terminated and the base closed because Pine Gap is a spy base and a war base:

Since it was opened in 1969, it has eavesdropped on Australian telephone and telex communications. Information obtained in this way was used by the CIA to destabilise the Whitlam Government in late 1975.

It provides communication facilities for CIA activities in countries throughout the world, much of which is connected with overthrowing other country's governments. Last year it became clear Pine Gap was spying on Greece.
The electronic and photographic information its satellites receive is used to select nuclear targets in the territory of the Soviet Union and its allies.
Many US military activities short of nuclear war are also co-ordinated by Pine Gap. These include the war against Vietnam and the invasion of Lebanon by US marines in 1984.
Pine Gap spends only a tiny percentage of its time monitoring arms control agreements, and even then the data gathered is so top-secret Australia has no access to it.
Pine Gap's role will be expanded under Reagan's Star Wars scheme to extend the arms race to outer space, threatening the existence of our planet.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Blanchard,Mr Kent,Mr Milton,Mr Scott and Mr Snowdon.

PETITION.TITLE: X-rated Videos
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable, the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled.
The Humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth concern:
About the evil caused by the fact that x-rated videos with their depiction of unnatural sex and often horrible violence, are allowed to circulate around Australia from Canberra.
And your petitioners, therefore humbly pray that such circulation be prevented.
The laws regarding obscenity in the media should also be revived and enforced.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beale,Mr Ian Cameron,Mr Allan Morris and Mr Ruddock.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The Humble Petition of certain Citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

The Government by persisting with the Australia Card Bill has wilfully rejected the advice and recommendations of the Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia's `Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card' which unequivocally rejected the Government's proposal in these words:

``The majority believes the creation of a new bureaucracy of 2000 public servants within the HIC [Health Insurance Commission], with the sole task of identifying every man, woman and child in Australia, is a wasteful exercise which will not address the problems of tax evasion and social security fraud but will provide the mechanism by which the very fabric of our society will be irreversibly altered, opening the way for the greatest attack on the privacy of individuals as the `Identity Bureau' identifies, monitors, and updates information on every person in Australia.'' (Report, 4.55, page 148)

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government now withdraw the Bill as being contrary to the Common Law and traditional freedoms we have hitherto enjoyed in Australia, and should the Bill be nevertheless re-introduced, that the Members of the House without regard for party should unanimously reject the Australia Card Bill as being contrary to our personal liberties and the national interest.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cunningham,Mr Prosser and Mr Rocher.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed National Identification Numbering System
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that we strongly oppose the introduction of the `Australia Card' or any other form of National Identification Numbering System.

We believe the introduction of a National Identification Numbering System is not only totally unnecessary but is a severe threat to our civil liberties and privacy. We condemn the Government's actions on this matter, particularly as no reasonable nor responsible justifications for the proposal have been forthcoming from the Government.
We humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should reject any proposal for a National Identification Numbering System.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Andrew and Mr Wilson.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Identity Card
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the proposed introduction of compulsory identification cards should be reconsidered and rejected because the proposal:
Is not a cost-effective method of reducing tax evasion and social security fraud, and to the contrary, in the form proposed will facilitate such evasion and fraud,
Will constitute an unwarranted infringement of individual privacy by the aggregation of a wide variety of personal information of a private matter,
Will cause a further large and costly growth in the bureaucracy and burden on the taxpayer, and
Cannot be guaranteed against misuse for purposes other than for which their introduction is stated to be intended.
And your petitioners humbly pray that the problems which identification cards are intended to reduce should be attacked by other, more effective methods.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cobb and Mr Sharp.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Pornography: X-rated Videos
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Parliament of Australia assembled.

We, the undersigned, being appalled that the Government has set no penalty for the possession of child pornography, and has set no penalty for importing unclassified child pornography, do ask that Parliament urgently legislate to:
Make the importation of child pornography, and the possession of child pornography, and all tapes and goods banned by Customs, to be a Criminal Offence, with Deterrent penalties, and
Close the Customs barriers to pornography in the A.C.T., in respect of X rated videos, (and ER) and end the shameful Canberra trade, and the Mafia Connections.
Because 98% of Australians in other State have banned X rated videos.
Because the trade is still flourishing, and it's availability escalates sexual crime.
Because importers of child pornography face only a fine for lying.
Because child pornography pedlars are safe if they cross a border, and cannot be extradited for a summary offence.
Because anyone can have these tapes in their possession for private use.
Because the Government does not intervene in that.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will give this matter earnest consideration
And your petitions, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Ms Fatin and Mr Rocher.

PETITION.TITLE: Post Office Agencies
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we strenuously object to the proposal that many post office agencies are to be closed. They provide a network of offices with postal and agency services to residential areas and small communities.

They serve a community need and we would be seriously inconvenienced if forced to travel further to purchase postal items or collect parcels. It would be an unnecessary expense particularly for pensioners without their own transport.

We maintain that the purpose of Post Offices should be to service the public for the variety of services they offer. They are a community centre particularly in country areas and if necessary they should be subsidised to retain them.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House should take all possible steps to prevent the closure of post office agencies and that the network should be extended, with the Agency services they offer expanded.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that the Fringe Benefits Tax is an iniquitous and unjust impost which will further damage the Australian economy and further increase costs to employers.
The tax will:
(1) further increase the level of unemployment;
(2) increase the administrative costs and overheads for business and Government;
(3) particularly disadvantage small businesses and farmers; and
(4) act as a disincentive to those who are the most productive and skilled;
and we the undersigned call upon the Government to immediately repeal the Fringe Benefits Tax.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
The fringe benefits tax will cause hardship to business throughout Australia, especially in the already severely-depressed rural sector and in the motor vehicle industry.
The fringe benefits tax will be a disincentive to employment and worse, will result in additional unemployment.

The economy of this country would best be served by policies that lightened the tax burden, not increased it, that encouraged enterprise, not stifled it and stimulated growth, development and jobs, not prevented it.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House will repeal this legislation and your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Superannuation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:
That many Australian wage and salary earners and self-employed persons do not enjoy secure retirement incomes provided by superannuation; and

That the Government issued in December 1985 guidelines for the implementation of the proposed productivity decision by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and draft Operational Standards for Superannuation schemes.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government:
1. Guarantees to every employee the right and freedom to select the superannuation scheme of his/her choice.
2. Protects the individual exercising that freedom of choice from any coercion, influence or other pressure which may be applied by any employer, association or trade union.
3. Will recognise only those schemes which provide genuine superannuation and reject those schemes which do not provide for-
preservation of benefits to retirement
vesting of employer contributions
equal employer and employee trusteeship control to ensure security of investments.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom Business Offices
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we oppose plans by Telecom Australia to close many of the Telecom Business Offices (TBO's) and replace them with a reduced service to be co-located with the District Customer Services Office. We believe the public should be able to make telephone bill payments, applications for new services, selection of telephones and complaints, in person at a convenient and easily accessible location. Telecom Business Offices provide this service, and therefore it is wrong that their contribution and performance will only be assessed on their sales revenue.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to instruct the management of Telecom Australia to immediately cease all action to close any Telecom Business Offices.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, your humble petitioners showeth:
The Federal Government has done nothing to ease concerns that it will support Telecom's plans to introduce timed charges for local calls; and
Call upon the Government to undertake that such plans will not be implemented.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully sheweth that:

Any proposals to time local telephone calls gravely concerns all country people. Isolation and communication was the second biggest problem facing rural women according to the `Survey of Rural Women' questionnaire and any attempt at timing local calls will only add to this problem not decrease it.
Your Petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, urge the Parliament to: Ensure that Telecom do not proceed with the timing of local telephone calls.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The Humble Petition of the Undersigned Citizens of Maranoa respectfully sheweth that:

Any proposals to time local telephone calls gravely concerns all country people. Isolation and communication was the second biggest problem facing rural women according to the `Survey of Rural Women' questionnaire and any attempt at timing local calls will only ADD to this problem, NOT DECREASE it.
Your Petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled urge the Parliament to:
Ensure that Telecom do not proceed with the timing of local telephone calls.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Identity Card
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully sheweth:
That the proposed introduction of compulsory identification cards should not be considered any further, and in the event of it coming again before parliament it should be rejected because:
We do not accept the concept of an I.D. card as necessary to control social security fraud or tax evasion,

It would be an unwarranted infringement of individual privacy and our democratic society, in particular because it being required to work, operate a bank account, enter hospital or enter into any transaction,
It would cause a further large and costly growth in the bureaucracy and burden on tax payers,
It cannot be guaranteed that the aggregated private information would not be misused for other purposes,
The people of Australia should be fully informed and consulted in a referendum before legislation for any such change with such wide-ranging effect is considered, and
We call upon the Government to cease immediately any endeavour to introduce this invasion upon our lives.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Kurnell Peninsula
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully sayeth.

Your petitioners humbly pray that your honourable House direct that the existing 4 (C4) zoning on the Kurnell Peninsula, in New South Wales, be removed and that this be replaced by a zoning more appropriate to the unique ecology of the area and to the historical significance of the Kurnell Peninsula, being the birthplace of the nation.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Free Zones
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of citizens of Australia shows-

That the people of New Zealand and the New Zealand Government have given an example to the world in their efforts to achieve a nuclear free South Pacific, and such decision being endorsed by the people at a general election.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government support the principled stand taken by the New Zealand Government and urges it to condemn any efforts by the U.S. Government to impose economic or other sanctions on New Zealand in retaliation for their stand on nuclear vessels.
We further urge the Australian Government to urgently implement its policy to promote the development of zones of peace and nuclear free zones in the Indian and Pacific Oceans.

PETITION.TITLE: Tobacco
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of these Electors sheweth that as:

In Australia, tobacco kills about four times as many people as the total killed by drink, drugs, murder, suicide, road accidents, rail accidents, air accidents, poisoning, drowning, fires, snakes, lightning, and every other known cause of accidental death all put together.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will prove your worth with effectual action against the promotion of tobacco.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To The Honourable The Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we consider the 2% discounting of Commonwealth Occupational Superannuation Scheme pension adjustments on 10 Oct. 86 to be a serious breach of trust by the Government.
This cut has reduced the base for future adjustments. The Government has promised to restore the base as soon as economic circumstances permit.

Having regard to state of the economy as portrayed by members of the Government during the recent election campaign, your petitioners humbly pray that the Government restore the pension base in the 1987 budget.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Identity Card
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned citizens, respectfully showeth:
That we are totally opposed to the introduction of the Labor Government's Identity Card.

We consider that this form of national and compulsory identification will be intrusive, costly for taxpayers and business and will not be effective in combating the growing problems of tax evasion, illegal immigrants or social security.
We therefore ask the House to take action to prevent the implementation of this legislation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Closure of Macksville Army Reserve, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully sheweth that:

The decision by the Department of Defence to close down the Macksville Sub-section of 41 Battalion, Australian Army Reserve, is of grave concern to the unit members and citizens of the surrounding districts. The decision to direct unit members to Coffs Harbour, some 60 km distant, would impose sufficient hardship to prevent many continuing in the reserve and be a major deterrent to potential members.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled urge the Parliament to:
Intervene to stop the proposed closure and sale of land at Wallace Street, Macksville, and initiate action to have a permanent Depot built on the Army's Macksville land.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: English Language Tuition Hours
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth-
That the number of hours of English language tuition for migrants and refugees has been reduced in South Australia
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Minister of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs reinstate English language tuition hours for migrants and refugees to their previous levels.
Your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Department of Veterans' Affairs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

Any proposals to abolish the Department of Veterans' Affairs gravely concern ex-servicemen, ex-servicewomen and their families, because they renege on clear and unequivocal commitments from various Commonwealth Governments to care for Australia's Veterans.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, urge the Parliament to:
Ensure that the Department of Veterans' Affairs continues to exist as a separate and distinct Department of State servicing the needs of Veterans and their families.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tropical Rainforests, North Queensland
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of certain electors of the division of Kennedy and Herbert respectfully showeth:

We are strongly opposed to the proposed nomination of Wet Tropical Rainforests of North Queensland to the World Heritage List. The listing of such a vast area will inhibit the future development of North Queensland on a broad economic base;
We are deeply concerned that roads presently connecting the coast with the hinterland may be eventually closed;
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Parliament rejects any moves to list the Wet Tropical Rainforests.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound will forever pray.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker has received a letter from the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The adverse implications for Australia's trade and foreign policy of the ACTU bans against Fiji.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —In a week when the stock markets here and around the world have been uncertain and unstable and when people are looking to the Government to give leadership, nothing shows the ineptness and incompetence of this Government more than its total inability to address the bans applied by the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) on trade with Fiji. We all know that over a little while there has been a deal of rhetoric from Ministers of this Government about the way in which they have been speaking severely to Simon Crean and Bill Kelty of the ACTU, telling them how serious it is that they should dare to usurp the foreign policy of the country. Yesterday we heard that the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden) had actually spoken twice to Mr Crean on the whole issue. We learned that the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) had been extraordinarily silent, although on an earlier occasion he said he had tut-tutted his way around telephone calls with the ACTU. The reality is that the ACTU is imposing disciplines on this Government which are far more profound than just an internecine fight between one element of the Australian Labor Party and another.

SPEECH.PARA: For a long while there has been concern on this side of the House that the Government does not appreciate the significant relationship between Australia and the island nations of the Pacific. Even less does it understand the way in which the Melanesian nations look to Australia in terms of both their trade and political ties. They also look to Australia in communications and as being a stable and reliable friend. They have customarily come to look on this country as a nation on which they can rely, whatever might happen to the super-powers and other countries in the region. The sad reality is that, whatever the rhetoric of the Government or the Foreign Minister, this Government's attitude to Fiji in particular is being totally undermined by the fact that the leadership of the ACTU knows that it has to bow to yesterday's communist and Senate Labor candidate for Victoria, namely John Halfpenny, and the attitudes that he and some of this colleagues have had in their intervention to establish the trade union movement in Fiji.

On an earlier occasion when I spoke in a similar debate I referred to the long-time association between the Pacific Trade Union Forum, which subsequently became the Pacific Trade Union Community, and the establishment of the trade union movement in Fiji. We should remember an editorial in the Northern Territory News on 15 April last which actually pointed to the fact that the Pacific Trade Union Forum, which was sponsored and endorsed by friend Halfpenny, was the brainchild of the Soviet sponsored Prague Congress of the World Federation of Trade Unions in 1978. The point of that association is that within the ACTU there is obviously an inability to address any significant direction being placed on it by the left wing unions. After some discussion between the Government, some members of the ACTU and the waterfront unions there was a temporary lifting of the earlier waterfront bans that were imposed after the first coup in Fiji but they were subsequently reimposed on 28 September.

This Government is not prepared to take the actions necessary to ensure that Australian interests are protected in the trade pattern that should be continuing in a normal way between this country and Fiji, irrespective of our concern about the manner in which Colonel Rabuka has taken, or usurped, power in that country and without in any way prejudicing the continued concern of this side of the chamber about the reintroduction of democracy and the preservation of the rule of law.

It is paradoxical that, while this Government is so inept in its relationship with the trade unions that it is unable to get the trade union bans lifted, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is in Geneva at the moment talking about the problems for Australia because of the actions super-powers take against countries like Australia in their primary industry and minerals trade. We had the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in the last few weeks telling us how he had been berating the world about how the United States and European countries should run their economies. But when it comes to domestic affairs, the Labor Government and Labor Ministers, from the Prime Minister down, are totally unable to say or do anything that might in any way deny the ACTU leadership or, for that matter, the left wing unions of this country taking away from the Government the power to direct its foreign and trade policies. The significance of all this is that this Government, more than ever, is showing that within the third Hawke Ministry there is not only a splitting apart of the factions but also the Government no longer has what we were told was a euphoric relationship with the trade unions which was epitomised by the nonsensical words `consensus' and `accord' which, according to the Prime Minister and the Treasurer, were symbolic of their success in their first two ministries.

The Minister for Industrial Relations has been weak and ineffective. The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade has spoken to Simon Crean twice, but it is a bit like being hit across the wrist with a feather. It has had absolutely no bearing on the decisions which the leadership of the ACTU has taken with respect to trade bans and the airline bans, about which I will speak in a moment. As to the Prime Minister and the Treasurer, there has been continued silence from the mountain-tops. I do not think they even realise the significance to Australia, to Fiji or to the whole Pacific region, of this Government's inability to exercise the sorts of controls that are possible over the trade union movement with respect to the maintenance of our trade with those countries.

The airline situation is as alarming in itself as the whole of the shipping bans. We should recognise that about 90 per cent of Fiji's air links are with Australia. Qantas Airways Ltd and Air Pacific are the main carriers to the island. A significant part of Fiji's traditional links with the world comes through its association with Qantas and Air Pacific. The whole of the establishment of its airport facilities has been because of the involvement of Australia's Department of Aviation in the island. Yet because of the ineptness, incompetence and inadequacy of the Australian Labor Party there is no ability for the maintenance of those communication links.

We should remember that those air links are similar to others that have been severed with South Africa. I am quite sure that the result will be not just a temporary cessation of those air links once the bans have been imposed but a search for other airlines to resume that airline traffic.
