Singapore Airlines will be the major beneficiary, both from the severing of the links with South African Airways and also from the potential trade union ban on air traffic to Fiji from the first of next month.

The character of Australia's trade with Fiji and Fiji's trade with Australia has been totally ignored in the Government's failure to act with respect to the trade unions. I do not know whether the Ministers of this Government understand that within the whole package of goods exchanged with Fiji there is a favourable trade balance, something that unfortunately does not occur with enough countries. Roughly $175m worth of goods is sold to Fiji and about $50m worth of goods is bought from Fiji. Components of the trade to Fiji are manufactured products, petroleum products, which form a very significant element, and a number of agricultural products which at the moment are extraordinarily sensitive to the difficulty of achieving international sales which are very adversely affected by the trade union bans.

I am told, for example, that Australia has been the traditional supplier of rice to Fiji. Instead of proceeding, as would normally be the case, with negotiations for the current term of contract, Fiji has turned to Thailand. The loss of the rice trade is worth about $5m a year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shame.

—The honourable member for Riverina-Darling, who is particularly concerned with the Riverina rice industry, has raised with me his worry that this decision alone could drive a significant number of rice growers off their rice farms. So the trade unions, in usurping the exercise of the foreign policy and trade decisions of the Australian Government, are driving rice growers in the Riverina off their rice farms.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia has traditionally been the major supplier of wheat to Fiji. The Australian Wheat Board, I am told, sends a ship to Fiji each month. The last ship left just before the ban was imposed. Since the bans have been imposed Fiji has already been looking for alternative markets. We all know the problems there are in the wheat industry. The wheat trade is worth $8m a year. So in two trades alone, thanks to the actions of the trade union movement and the inability of this Government to do anything about it, primary producers have lost about $13m a year.

The point of all this is that the Government is not without some power to do something about it. There are actions and procedures which this Government could and should undertake. Indeed, part of the problem of this Government is that it walks away from any sort of a confrontation with the trade union movement. We heard this morning about how worried the Government is about small glass sizes in hotels. We have heard from the Treasurer and the Prime Minister about how seriously they take actions by overseas countries. But they totally ignore the fact that to maintain trade with other countries one must start by looking in one's own backyard. In our own backyard, this Government has to be prepared to excercise the same discipline against trade union leadership as it pretends to exercise against the governments of other countries. Unless the Government does so, countries other than Australia will benefit.

I have already mentioned the prospects in terms of the competitors of Qantas. In the Australian earlier this week there was a suggestion that both France and Israel are upgrading their representation in Fiji. There was also a suggestion that the Soviet Union is doing exactly the same, as my colleague the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) canvassed in Question Time today. We all know that unless Australia's industrial reputation can be lifted it is pointless for any of us to think that we will be able to overcome our chronic economic problems. All this has a real relevance in a week when so many are apprehensive about their savings because of the downturn in stock markets.

There are steps which this Government can and should take with the trade union movement. It has an ability to enter into negotiations, not just a mere wrist slapping exercise or a couple of telephone calls from the Foreign Affairs and Trade Minister, but a conference. We have a summit about some sort of consumer credit but there is not even an ability on the part of the Government to exercise normal and proper negotiations with those who seek to usurp its proper policy function. Any cry that the Government exercises major control is put into its proper perspective when we see the Government's inability to act. Today I am told that there is a move by Garry Brack, the Executive Director of the Employers Federation of New South Wales, to seek an urgent conference to ensure that the ACTU bans on exports to Fiji are lifted. We are told that in petroleum products, cereals and cereal products, iron and steel, and chemicals, there is a very serious and imminent consequence for a whole range of employment in this country. The Federation points out that Australia is not a monopoly supplier, that the effect of the bans is simply to force Fijian businesses to source their stocks elsewhere, and that this is already happening. So we are not only losing trade, we are losing status and influence, and we are prejudicing the ability of Australia to have any say whatsoever in restoring democracy to Fiji.

But more importantly, there are other powers available to this Government. Section 45d of the Trade Practices Act gives this Government the power to intercede, together with those affected, to ensure that there is an ability to get the unions to return to work. But let me, beyond that, point to section 30k of the Crimes Act, which, under clause (d), makes it an offence to `obstruct or hinder the transport of goods or the conveyance of passengers and trade or commerce with other countries or among the States'. There are powers. There is an ability to call the trade unions and the exporters together. There is an ability within the Trade Practices Act and the Crimes Act to take action against the trade union leadership. Any pretence that this Government is running the affairs of this nation is put totally in perspective when we realise that it is unable even to stop the trade unions from maintaining bans against Fiji which are seriously injurious to Australia's foreign policy and trade interests.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALKER.NAME: Mr WILLIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations)

TALK.START.PARA: —What we have just heard from the Opposition is the usual exercise of hypocrisy, particularly from the person who submitted this matter of public importance. We have been told that there is a serious situation in respect of bans in relation to Fiji and that there are actions available to us which we should use. One should perhaps note at the outset what the Fraser Government did when it was faced with similar trade union bans in relation to political activities in other countries, particularly Chile and South Africa. What was the reaction of the Fraser Government? Did it use the Crimes Act, which the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair) suggests we should now use? Of course it did not, although it had the power to use it. Nor did it use the Trade Practices Act, although it had the power to use it. Did it utilise any other legislative form of approach in respect of those bans? No, it did not, although it perhaps had the power to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: At the outset we should note the enormous amount of hypocrisy which encompasses this matter of public importance. In other words: `Do not do as we did when we were in government; do as we say you ought to do'. What the Fraser Government did was to try to talk the trade union movement into removing those bans, and, to a substantial degree, that was successful. That has been the approach taken by this Government.We have made it clear to the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) that we believe that these bans are inappropriate, that they are possibly counterproductive and that it would be unfortunate in the extreme if they were to be maintained-for several reasons. It is not really appropriate for me to state what those reasons are, but we have told the ACTU, in detail, why we believe its actions are inappropriate and counterproductive and are not likely to bring about the results which it seeks.

We believe that the process of discussion with the ACTU and the trade unions is one which can lead to a productive outcome. Let us get matters clear at this point. We have a union decision about prospective airline bans, but we have no airline bans applying at present. Maritime bans are in place. To my understanding, so far they have affected two shipments. The prospective impact of the continuance of the maritime bans and the imposition of airline bans could be quite severe. That, of course, lies behind a lot of our opposition to them, because we believe that they will be severe in a way which will be counterproductive to the concerns of the ACTU and of this Government.

We share the concerns of the ACTU about the rights of trade union officials to conduct their affairs within the law of Fiji. The freedom of association and the freedom of trade union officials in that country to conduct their legitimate business has been curtailed by military might; that is, there has been a detaining of union officials. The Secretary and the Treasurer of the Fijian Trade Union Congress were detained for some time after the second coup. There has been closure of offices. There has been close surveillance of union officials. Some have gone into hiding for fear of being detained, or worse. There has been very close surveillance of unions, including all communications and other activities. That has meant that it is impossible for there to be free trade union activity in that country. That is a deplorable development. It is just one example of the loss of democratic rights, and that is of great concern to us. We understand the ACTU's concern about that. Perhaps it should also be noted that its actions have been taken after specific requests from the members of the Fijian Trade Union Congress to assist them to regain their rights to operate as free trade unionists.

With all of that said, however, we have made it clear that we do not believe that the actions being pursued are likely to bring about the kinds of results that the ACTU wants to achieve. For that reason, we believe it would be sensible for there to be a lifting of the bans now in place and a non-imposition of the proposed bans. Discussions have been held between ourselves and the ACTU, and there will be further discussions in an attempt to bring about that result that I have indicated the Government would desire. If we are unable to achieve that result, we will have to consider what else we can do to try to bring about an appropriate result. But I think it should be noted that it is absurd for the Opposition to be suggesting that we should be rushing around and throwing around the Crimes Act, which it never used, or that the Trade Practices Act should be used for bans which are apparently prospective. That is an absurd suggestion. We will not be taking that kind of extreme action until it is quite clear that reasonable action cannot take place. We will then consider what other action can be used.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just like you have acted towards the waterside workers.

—I am happy to look at industrial relations records. I would like to hear the honourable member's response to that, because those who wander around threatening the big stick attitude-which the Opposition is delighted to do most of the time, and of course in government it tried to implement this-usually finish up with a disastrous situation, with high levels of industrial disputation.

SPEECH.PARA: It should be noted that since we have been in office there has been a 60 per cent reduction in the level of industrial disputation. That is an enormous reduction, and one which demonstrates that this Government does not need advice from a failed previous government which showed itself hopelessly incompetent in the area of industrial relations and whose members are in no position to give advice to this Government, or indeed to anybody else, about the appropriate way to conduct industrial relations. The last group we would be listening to about what we should do in respect of this or any other industrial relations matter would be the Federal Opposition, because it is the least qualified group in this country to give advice to anyone about how industrial relations should be conducted. When it had its seven years in government, it showed that it was totally incapable of bringing about any degree of consensus or compatibility between the industrial relations parties. Its whole approach was one of `Hit them with a big stick as much as you can', and when that led to further confrontation it would throw up its hands and face a situation of very substantial loss of production through heavy levels of industrial disputation.

At the same time, the Opposition faced much higher levels of wage increases than have applied under this Government. Labour cost increases were much higher under the Fraser Government than they have been under this Government-about double the rate. So we do not need any lectures from the Opposition about how to conduct industrial relations. We have shown, on the basis of diminished industrial disputation and on the basis of much better labour cost outcomes, that we do not need the Opposition's advice. Indeed, the position that has prevailed under this Government has been infinitely better than that which prevailed when the Opposition was in office.

The action in relation to Fiji is one which we have discussed in detail with the ACTU. The process of discussion which has taken place is one which will lead to the possibility of the withdrawal of those bans. I think that is so because the logic of the position which we have put to the trade union movement is one which is very compelling in terms of attempts to achieve the ACTU's objectives in relation to the trade union movement in Fiji, in terms of Australia's position in the South Pacific and in terms of Australian trade at a time when we need all the trade that we can get, particularly where it is a plus for us in net trade considerations.

In all of those respects the bans on trade and communications with Fiji are not likely to be very helpful to this nation. They are not likely to be helpful to those who seek to obtain a particular result. However, at this stage the ACTU has not given us a considered response on those issues. We await that considered response and we are prepared to have further intensive discussions with it. The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden) and I have had separate communications with the ACTU and have indicated that we are quite willing to meet jointly with the ACTU in the near future to discuss this matter in depth and, hopefully, to bring about a resolution of the dispute. As I have said, the bans that have been proposed are in the maritime area only.

TALK.START.PARA: —Neither here nor there!

—What a stupid comment that was. That just shows how much intelligence the honourable member brings to this debate. I was saying that the bans are in the maritime area only and, to this stage, have affected only a couple of shipments, so the impact has been small. Much greater and more damaging bans were imposed, under the previous Government, in respect of Chile and South Africa. We did not see the response from the Government then that the Opposition seeks to have us make on this issue. We certainly would not wish to take up the Opposition's invitation to rush around with a big stick and produce a much worse situation, which would be the most likely outcome of pursuing the activities that the Opposition suggests we should undertake.

SPEECH.PARA: The position of the Government is quite clear. We have demonstrated fully to the ACTU why the imposition of bans is not an appropriate course to take for a number of reasons. The ACTU is giving consideration to the reasons that we have put to it. We expect a full and reasoned response from it in the near future. If that response is the one that we expect, eventually we will have a decision by the ACTU which is the appropriate one in respect of these bans.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government won't do anything about it.

—I say to the Leader of the National Party that we will do much more about it than the previous Government was able to achieve in respect of removing bans of a similar kind against Chile and South Africa. We will certainly be more effective than the previous Government was in that respect, as we have been in all other respects in industrial relations matters. We do not need the Opposition to lecture us about how we should go about dealing with this issue.

SPEECH.PARA: We agree that this matter is important. We agree with the Opposition in the sense that the imposition of bans on trade and communications is an important matter. It is one that the Government is not taking lightly. It is one that the Government agrees must be taken up, and it has been taken up, with the ACTU. We agree that all efforts must be made to have those bans lifted. Those efforts are being made. They will continue to be made in the most appropriate way and we have confidence that we will get the appropriate response. If that appropriate response is not forthcoming, we will certainly give consideration to what other actions we would need to take in order to bring about a desirable result. But we will certainly not be rushing into a Rambo-type reaction which the Opposition would have us undertake, a reaction that it never utilised in government for the same sensible reasons that we would not wish to pursue it now, which is that such action would be counter-productive. Only an extremist would wish to utilise the kind of action which has been suggested here today. I believe that this matter of public importance is properly brought before the Parliament. I say to the Parliament that the Government is responding adequately and appropriately to this situation. For a host of reasons we believe the bans should be removed. All appropriate actions are being taken to remove them and we are confident that we will get an appropriate response in the not too distant future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —What we have just heard is a gutless, unprincipled and pathetic surrender by this Government to the trade union movement in the management of a vital area of foreign affairs and trade policy. The Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) came into the House-he is the wrong Minister; the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden) should have been here-and tried to say that this is an industrial issue and that it has to be handled as such. It is not; it is a trade and foreign policy issue. He has raked up ancient history dealing with Chile and South Africa. But this is a special problem in our own region.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me remind the Minister of some of the history of this matter. Maritime bans against Fiji were originally imposed after the first coup. They were there for two months. The second coup took place on 25 September. On 28 September the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia imposed shipping bans and the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) supported them. What happened then? On 29 September, the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade protested, which was reported in the Australian Financial Review on 29 September as follows:
But the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Mr Bill Hayden, returning to Australia, spoke strongly against both imposing trade sanctions and severing diplomatic relations.
Mr Hayden yesterday telephoned Mr Crean to say he believed trade sanctions against Fiji were neither helpful nor effective.
He said trade bans would jeopardise Australia's $175 million trade with Fiji ``if not permanently, for a very long time''.

That was a very strong warning and a very strong statement. In fact, we have learned from Mr Brack of the Employers Federation of New South Wales that we are talking about $200m. As he points out, we are talking about $200m of trade which can easily be substituted from other sources. The Minister's telephone call to Mr Crean back in September was the first of a series of humiliating telephone calls by him to Mr Crean.

Let me just note in passing that we have seen an intellectual somersault in the Government's approach to the question of sanctions. The Government believes that sanctions should be imposed against South Africa. It believes that sanctions should not be imposed against Fiji. We agree with the Government when it says that sanctions should not be imposed against Fiji. But mark this: what concerns us is that in Fiji we are seeing the proposition advanced, and to be entrenched, that a racial group should have special political powers. What is the difference in principle in those two countries? The Government has been unable to tell us that, but plainly it has done an intellectual somersault. Regardless of the Government's motives, it has at least come to the right conclusion about Fiji.

What was the next move after the shipping bans? We know that two ships have been prevented from going to Fiji and that nothing has happened. The Minister appears to think that this is of no consequence. Well, on 20 October Mr Simon Crean, the President of the ACTU, announced that there will be bans on airlines going to Fiji as from 1 November unless certain action is taken. What was the Government's response? Once more, it was a telephone call. Yesterday, the Minister was asked in this House about the action that he had taken. He said:
I have spoken to Simon Crean on this matter on two occasions in the last two days.
He said later:

We have registered our concern very firmly. Our opposition to those sanctions has been expressed on a number of occasions, and will continue to be expressed. I will continue to make very strong representations to the trade union movement to withdraw the sanctions.
I ask honourable members to note that the Minister is talking about representations by a government to the trade union movement. He continued:
The Minister for Industrial Relations has also been associated with this matter.

He would be a very strong ally to have around the place! The Minister concluded by raising the industrial dispute alibi. That alibi is the argument that what the Government has on its hands is an industrial dispute. On can imagine what will take place in the Cabinet room when the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) comes back and he runs through the agenda. It will go something like this: `First of all, fellows, I have to tell you about my success in Ireland. By the way, Bill, what is happening in Fiji? Do we have a policy?'. `Yes, Prime Minister, we have a policy. The policy is that there will be no sanctions'. `Good, Bill. What does Simon say about it?'. `Well, I spoke to him, Prime Minister. I telephoned him and he took my telephone call'. `Good stuff, Bill. What did you do?'. `I made very strong representations on behalf of the Government to allow the Government to run its foreign and trade policy as the Government sees fit'. `What did Simon say, Bill?'. `Well, Simon can be a shade colourful, Prime Minister, but, in fact, he said no'. `Bill, I think you have handled it pretty well. Just keep on telephoning Simon and don't worry about the cost of the telephone calls; this Government is good for them'. That is really what it amounts to. It is just extraordinary to have this Government advancing, as a serious proposition, the notion that it should go as a suppliant to the ACTU, to Mr Simon Crean, requesting him to allow the Government to conduct its foreign and trade policy as it sees fit. What about, for example, the real concerns that we have? Take what Mr Brack said today in an urgent telex. After outlining the exports amounting to $200m that go to Fiji from Australia every year, he said:
Australia is not a monopoly supplier. The effect of the bans is simply to force Fijian businesses to source their stocks elsewhere. This is already happening.
Once lost, many of the markets we now enjoy will never return.

Mr Brack is in agreement with the Foreign Minister. They are both saying the same thing, that once these markets are lost they will never be returned. The bans will lose these markets for us. Leaving aside for one moment the foreign policy consequences, the trade bans are going to damage irreparably our trade with Fiji if they are allowed to go on. The Government's answer is: `Let's hope it works itself out. We do not get ourselves precipitately involved in action against the ACTU'. There would be no doubt about that. Can honourable members ever see the Government taking the ACTU to court? Can honourable members ever see the Government taking the unions responsible for these bans to court? Can honourable members ever see the Government invoking section 45d of the Trade Practices Act? It wants to get rid of section 45d. Can honourable members ever see the Government invoking the common law remedies that it has? Of course they cannot. Can honourable members ever see the Government moving for the deregistration of the Waterside Workers Federation or the Transport Workers Union for imposing these bans? No chance at all. Can honourable members ever see the Government considering the ultimate sanction-and it is an ultimate sanction, it would not be needed-under the Crimes Act? Never.

So what has happened? We know that the maritime bans have been imposed and that they are in place. Only two shipments have been held up; that is, two shipments have not gone. That is neither here nor there. We know that unless Mr Crean is good enough to change his mind, to take a few more telephone calls from the Foreign Minister, or somebody else as suppliant on behalf of the Government, the bans proposed by him are going to go into force. What are the consequences? The consequences are, of course, first, that we will see this Government placed in a client relationship with the ACTU. The Minister let it out so beautifully when he said that the consequences would be `severe in a way that will be counterproductive to the concerns of the ACTU', and he added `and the Government'. I would add, `and Australia's traders'. Second, it is plain that the ACTU and Mr Crean are taking a position on the conduct of foreign and trade policy. Third, it is plain that Mr Crean gives himself the right to exercise a veto, not only over domestic decisions made by this Government but also over foreign policy and trade issues, generally and in this particular case. I ask the House to mark one of the consequences: it is a risk-I put it only as a risk-that as a result of what is now taking place, the Soviet Union or Libya may be able to enlarge its influence in Fiji. It is certain that if these bans continue our trade will be badly damaged and the risk is there--

TALK.START.PARA: -Order! the honourable member's time has expired.
—Of the Soviets or the Libyans moving in place of Australia--
—Order! The honourable member for North Sydney will resume his seat. The honourable member knows that he should not continue to speak after his time has expired.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I would never disregard an injunction from you.
—That would be a first step. I call the honourable member for Charlton.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it was probably fortunate that the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) chose to extend the comments that he was making because, had he finished at the time he was supposed to finish, he would have finished on the note that a takeover of the southern Pacific by the Soviet Union was a possible result of the coup in Fiji and the actions that have been taken by the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU). It is a completely absurd proposition. I am surprised to have heard it presented to this Parliament and, through this Parliament, to the Australian people. The honourable member for North Sydney is now escaping from any further criticism.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no question that the Government has determined a very clear attitude not only in relation to the circumstances that developed in Fiji when the Government repudiated the actions of Colonel Rabuka, when the Government appealed for an early restoration of the democratic processes and democratic procedures in Fiji, but also in relation to the position that the Government has adopted as far as trade union decisions are concerned in Australia. The Government has not endorsed those sanctions. I know that the Opposition has not endorsed those sanctions. There is no chance at all for the Opposition to be successful in what appears to have been an appeal to the Government to adopt some sort of macho industrial relations response to these circumstances.

Of course, the purposes of the Opposition are completely transparent in relation to this alleged matter of public importance. They do not involve a concern, as it has suggested, about the implications of the ACTU ban against Fiji on Australia's trade and foreign policy. That is not the purpose of this at all. The purpose is simply to engage in another political exercise and to attempt to restore the macho response from the Opposition as far as its industrial relations policy is concerned. If we put all this into objective context we can examine the extent to which these trade bans are affecting the level of Australia's trade.

In the last financial year, 1986-87, the total value of exports from Australia to Fiji was $174m. Australia's total exports were almost $36,000m. Would it be a catastrophic effect on Australia's export performance if even all those exports disappeared? Our imports from Fiji would be about $28m. Total imports would be $37,000m. I have heard expressions here today from the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair) to the effect that the bans are seriously injurious to our trade and foreign policy. Seriously injurious to our trade? No. Seriously injurious to our foreign policy? How could the ACTU bans be seriously injurious to the foreign policy of a government which has been clearly and explicitly stating a balanced and sensible approach which has been endorsed not only by the Australian community at large but also by the Opposition? Indeed, it has been endorsed by spokesmen for the Opposition who purport to speak for those people who are attempting to interject now. Those honourable members attempting to interject are not even aware of the position which their leadership has adopted. Their leadership and the Government are as one in relation to the attitude towards those sanctions.

The Leader of the National Party also said that the approach of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden)-in contacting Mr Crean and indicating to him that the Government did not endorse those sanctions and appealing to the trade union movement to reconsider the decisions-was like hitting Mr Crean on the hand with a feather.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course it is.

—It seems the honourable member for Mitchell endorses that sort of attitude and the sort of macho response that the Leader of the National Party was trying to present. The Leader of the National Party went on and said, `Let's be courageous; let's show a little bit of strength. Let us not hit these people on the hand with a feather. Let's use the trade practices legislation. Let's hit them with the Crimes Act'. This is typical of the punitive, confrontationist and provocative sort of approach which honourable members opposite always take towards trade union questions and questions of industrial relations in Australia. This simply reflects the attitude which members of the Opposition-and the interests which they represent in the community-have adopted to this question and similar questions on other occasions.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not know whether honourable members opposite expect us to conscript labour in Australia in order to ensure that the trade continues. I do not know whether they expect that the Government will take action to send out the army and force labour to perform as they would expect it to perform. Would they expect, then, that we would repudiate the conventions of the International Labour Organisation which we have ratifies? I refer in particular to convention No. 105, article 1. Having ratified this, we are bound by it. We are committed to endorse it and to act according to it. Article 1 says:

Each member of the International Labour Organisation which ratifies this Convention undertakes to suppress and not to make use of any form of forced or compulsory labour . . . as a means of political coercion.

Where do we stand? The honourable member for Mitchell thinks that this is a great joke. He should be ashamed of himself. The article goes on to say that the members will avoid the use of forced or compulsory labour `as a method of mobilising and using labour for purposes of economic development'. That is what honourable members opposite are allegedly talking about now-trade. Of course, they are talking about nothing of the kind. What they are talking about amounts to a series of circumstances that they are taking advantage of in order to continue their vendetta against this Government and against the trade union movement. Their motives are absolutely and completely transparent and we repudiate them absolutely. We can go on to convention No. 29, which we have also ratified and which I believe had bipartisan support in this Parliament. It is another convention concerning forced or compulsory labour. Article 1 states:
Each Member of the International Labour Organisation which ratifies this Convention undertakes to suppress the use of forced or compulsory labour in all its forms within the shortest possible period.
Article 2 says:

For the purposes of this Convention, the term ``forced or compulsory labour'' shall mean all work or service which is exacted from any person under the menace of any penalty and for which the said person has not offered himself voluntarily.

Let us not be confused about the purposes for which this matter of public importance has been raised. Let us not be confused either about the motivation which lies behind the arguments that have been presented here this afternoon. I would just like to ask one question of the members of the Opposition, and perhaps at some time in the future they will take the opportunity to respond to it. I ask: Why, in deciding to attack the trade union movement in the way that they have, did they not also earlier this month take the same opportunity to attack Britain which was threatening then to cancel its sugar contracts with Fiji? We heard not a whimper from them. At the same time, why have they not taken advantage of the opportunity to criticise the insurance companies in Australia which have refused to write cover for people who travel to Fiji? What a serious act against the tourist trade of Fiji! Why has the Opposition been silent on that matter? I will tell honourable members why they have been silent on it. It is because that action taken by insurance companies was designed, of course, to support and protect their corporate profits. Let us not criticise any action that a private company in Australia might take, for any purpose and in any form, to protect its corporate profits! But let us scream and howl and kick the communist can as soon as a trade union decides to take action which is designed to protect trade unionists in Fiji. Even the Age newspaper earlier this year said:
That the ACTU should be disturbed by recent events in Fiji is right and proper and perfectly understandable.

Of course it is perfectly understandable to all those people who have ears to listen, to all those people who want to take an objective attitude and to all those people who are responsive to reasonable argument. In conclusion, I repeat that the Government has made its position perfectly clear.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired. The honourable member for Charlton nearly incurred my wrath in the same way as the honourable member for North Sydney did. But I think I was a bit harsh with the honourable member for North Sydney before. The discussion is now concluded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Mr H.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the first report of the Publications Committee sitting in conference with the Publications Committee of the Senate. Copies of the report have been circulated to honourable members in the chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: Report-by leave-adopted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duncan The Hon P.

TALKER.NAME: Mr DUNCAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House consents to termination by the Commonwealth of the Airlines Agreement 1981.

After 35 years of detailed economic regulation of interstate aviation by successive Australian governments, I today place before the House of Representatives a motion which will bring the two airlines policy to an end, and open Australia's interstate air services to free competition.

The 1981 airlines agreement, a copy of which is set out in the schedule to the Airlines Agreement Act 1981, was put in place by the previous Government. It requires three years notice of termination. The motion now before the House, which was introduced into the Senate by the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) on 7 October, seeks to enable the Government to serve that notice and to bring the existing arrangements to an end in 1990.

In essence, the Government's major objective in bringing the two airlines policy to a close is to create an environment which will foster an increased responsiveness by airlines to consumer needs; a wider range of fares and types of services to provide enhanced travel opportunities; increased competition and pricing flexibility leading to greater economic efficiency in the industry; and a continuation of Australia's world renowned aviation safety record.

To achieve this objective, the Government has decided to withdraw from aviation specific economic regulation and to allow the market to operate within the constraints of the established competition policy controls applicable to industry generally. I emphasise that this withdrawal is from economic regulation, and not the regulation of safety. The airline industry in Australia is now well developed by world standards. The aircraft and facilities used are of the highest standard, and the expertise and safety achieved in Australian operations are of world renown. Given the size and established position of the trunk airlines, there is simply no longer a need to continue the absolute protection from domestic competition. In fact, the development of the aviation industry has now reached a stage where detailed economic regulation can no longer help, and may be hindering, the achievement of the broader economic and social objectives which have previously underlined the two-airline policy.

The question of the Commonwealth's role in the economic regulation of the industry has recently been subjected to the most detailed and public scrutiny in the industry's history by the Independent Review of Economic Regulation of Domestic Aviation-the so-called May Review. The May Review was critical of existing arrangements and drew attention to significant public dissatisfaction with the current policy, including the widespread view that it works to the disadvantage of consumers and encourages the airlines to serve the high yield, that is, business, markets to the detriment of the leisure market. It found that in comparison with its overseas counterparts, the Australian aviation industry is characterised by relatively low labour productivity and relatively high and stable profit levels. Public comment on the May Review generally favoured substantial withdrawal by the Commonwealth from economic regulation of the industry.

We have decided to adopt the broad thrust of option 5 proposed by the Review. What this means is that the Government will, upon termination of the airlines agreement in October 1990, withdraw from the detailed economic regulation of four matters. First, controls over the importation of aircraft will be removed. These controls have provided the threshold underpinning of the legislative and contractual arrangements which currently regulate the industry. Secondly, the detailed determination of the amount of passenger capacity that may be provided by each trunk airline, and each regional airline which uses jet aircraft larger than 30 seats, will cease. Thirdly, the Independent Air Fares Committee which currently sets all air fares will be abolished and the Commonwealth will withdraw from the determination of air fares. Fourthly, the existing constraints on the entry of new domestic operators to trunk routes will be removed.

Let me make it clear what this deregulation decision does not mean. First, as I have already stated, economic deregulation does not mean that the Government will in any way withdraw from, or lessen the effectiveness of, air safety regulation. On the contrary, a series of new initiatives are proposed that will significantly further strengthen Australia's already outstanding aviation safety record. They are spelt out in full in the detailed statement I shall be tabling at the conclusion of this speech. Secondly, it does not mean that there will be any abdication of the Government's responsibility for consumer protection, or any lessening in our commitments to ensuring that effective competition prevails in the Australian aviation industry. On the contrary, we have taken the view that there is a need to apply the Trade Practices Act to the new aviation industry environment, to maintain a limited degree of price surveillance of the kind that applies in many other deregulated industries, and to ensure that in the operation of the airport infrastructure under the Federal Airports Corporation new entrants will not be excluded from effective access to terminal usage.

Thirdly, economic deregulation does not mean that an open skies policy will prevail domestically insofar as foreign airlines, and in particular those operating international services to Australia, are concerned. There is a close interrelation between the position of domestic and international carriers, with the viability of each depending to some extent on how the boundaries are drawn between them. The Government has made decisions and formulated guidelines on all these matters, and they are set out in full in the statement I am shortly tabling. Fourthly, it does not mean that we will abdicate our responsibility to ensure that the Government's own domestic airline, Australian, is well equipped-both managerially and in terms of its capitalisation-to succeed in the robust competitive environment that will prevail from 1990 onwards. Again, the steps we are proposing to follow in this regard are set out in full in the statement I will be tabling.

The Government has been acutely conscious of the difficulties that have occurred in the United States following deregulation there in 1978, and our policy is designed to avoid the undesirable effects of the kind of economic deregulation that occurred in that country. We have also had the benefit of the Canadian experience, where the industrial relations framework and market size and characteristics are closer to Australia's and where economic deregulation has not in fact resulted in the significant problems experienced in the United States.

What is involved in the Government's economic deregulation policy is not a simple, or simple-minded, lifting of existing controls, but a complex group of interacting policies involving a number of internal checks and balances. The key elements of that total policy are, in summary, as follows: First, withdrawal from detailed economic regulatory controls over aircraft imports and capacity, air fares and route entry; second, continuation and enhancement of regulatory controls over aviation safety and security; third, watchdog protection for consumers through the application of the Trade Practices Act, appropriate fare scrutiny by the Prices Surveillance Authority, and assured access to terminal facilities by new entrants to the industry; fourth, action to strengthen Australian Airlines to confront the post 1990 environment, including immediate incorporation, removal of a number of public service controls immediately with a review of others to follow, and a full review of options for generating necessary capitalisation and enhancing managerial effectiveness; fifth, neither Qantas Airways Ltd nor any other international airline to carry domestic passengers or freight on regular services; international operators into Australia to be confined to less than 15 per cent equity in any Australian domestic carrier; and Qantas to remain Australia's sole designated international carrier; and, sixth, as interim measures to encourage competition before 1990, Qantas's interlining rights to be restored, and restrictions on large aircraft passenger charters by domestic operators to be modified; arrangements for the approval of commercial domestic charters by Qantas to be subject to review on termination of the airlines agreement.

The Government has not taken in isolation its decision to terminate the two-airline agreement. The deregulation policy we have developed is based on a comprehensive approach encompassing sweeping changes to the Commonwealth's role in Australian aviation, including new approaches to the provision of infrastructure and services, safety regulation and the role of Government aviation business undertakings. The policy is designed to take the domestic aviation industry into the 1990s and beyond.

I table a detailed statement by the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) in support of the resolution to terminate the airlines agreement 1981, and commend this motion to the House.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Beale

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I sought, and obtained, from the Minister an assurance that he would facilitate a debate on this matter next week. I want to express my appreciation. I move:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the debate be now adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: MANAGEMENT AND INVESTMENT COMPANIES LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Willis, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALKER.NAME: Mr WILLIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: The the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill will amend both the Management and Investment Companies Act 1983 and the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 by permitting a management and investment company (MIC) to raise non-tax concessional capital in conjunction with tax concessional capital as well as enabling an MIC to exit the program without triggering the tax clawback arrangements by surrending its licence. The proposed amendments follow the Government's consideration of the Bureau of Industry Economics (BIE) review of the MIC program.

The MIC program commenced in early 1984 with the objectives of encouraging the development of a viable private sector venture capital market and providing management support and equity capital to young export oriented businesses using innovative technology and having the potential for rapid growth. This followed the report Developing High Technology Enterprises for Australia, prepared by a committee of the Australian Academy of Technological Sciences, chaired by Sir Frank Espie. The Espie report found that the lack of risk capital and a widespread lack of management and commercial skills within new high technology enterprises were obstacles to the development of those enterprises.

Since the inception of the MIC program there has been a rapid increase in the availability of venture capital and continued strong growth is expected. The BIE in its review estimated that at 30 June 1983 only some $2m of venture capital had been available; by 31 March 1987 this had increased to approximately $310m with a further projected increase to about $570m for 31 March 1988. This rapid expansion in the availability of venture capital is indeed significant, and represents not only the activities of the MICs but also reflects growth in the availability of venture capital outside the MIC program. To 30 September 1987 the MICs have invested and committed almost $140m in 129 businesses across a range of industries, including computer hardware and software, medical equipment and products, scientific and technical services and industrial products and machinery. This is a clear indication that the program has gone a good deal of the way towards demonstrating the viability of a venture capital market.

However, despite the increased availability of venture capital, the Government remains unconvinced as to the durability of the venture capital market if the MIC program were to be terminated at this time, the danger being that premature termination of the program would not only place the MICs and their investee businesses at risk but could also lead to a lack of confidence in the venture capital market as a whole. The Government has therefore decided to continue the MIC program until at least 30 June 1989.

In reaching this decision the Government has taken a number of factors into consideration, which include the following: firstly, many of the new non-MICs are still a good deal smaller than the MICs and with only a limited amount of capital available; secondly, the MICs, unlike the non-MICs, focus their investments primarily at the more risky start-up and early growth stages of business development, with emphasis upon technology-based and export-oriented industries; thirdly, MICs appear to devote more time towards providing management support than the non-MICs. It was also felt that while financial deregulation had resulted in greater flexibility and competition within the financial system, this had not yet, to any great extent, flowed over into the high risk venture capital market, but had mainly benefited the more traditional areas of financial activity.

The Government believes that the key to the long term viability of the venture capital market lies with its ability to attract funds from the major financial institutions. The institutions have begun to show an increased interest in venture capital but it is still very tentative. Indications are that institutional investors are reluctant to provide ongoing investment in venture capital as they regard the market as still being immature. The financial institutions are looking for an established track record in portfolio management of venture capital investments. The MICs, with their spread of investments across the venture capital spectrum, are well placed to show that such a track record can be achieved.

An integral part of the MIC program is the 100 per cent tax concession which is provided in order to encourage investment in the MICs. The Government has therefore decided to refer the program to the Review of Business Taxation announced by the Treasurer in his recent Budget Speech. The future of the program beyond 30 June 1989 will be determined in the context of the Review's findings, with due regard being paid to the program's objective of encouraging the development of a viable private sector venture capital market and assurance as to the long term viability of that market.

The Government has decided that the upper limit of $20m per annum as the cost to revenue of the program will be retained for the life of the program. On the basis of a marginal tax rate of around 50c in the dollar, the $20m of revenue forgone will result in about $40m of tax concessional capital being available to the MICs per annum. In addition to the continuation of the MIC program the Government has recognised the need for a suitable mechanism by which MICs could exit the program. This is required so that individual MICs are allowed to exit the program voluntarily in an orderly and non-prejudicial fashion. The raising of non-tax concession capital provides such a mechanism. At the moment MICs can raise only tax concessional capital. By allowing MICs to raise non-tax concessional capital in conjunction with tax concessional capital, they will become less reliant upon the tax concession in order to attract funds, assisting in an orderly exit from the program.

Apart from providing a suitable exiting mechanism, the raising of non-tax concessional capital will also increase the amount of venture capital available to these young innovative businesses without any additional cost to revenue. In order for the exiting mechanism to function, MICs must be able to voluntarily surrender licences without triggering the tax clawback provisions. To do otherwise would be prejudicial to interests of both the individual investors in the MICs and the businesses in which MICs have invested.

The clawback provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act operate to withdraw the 100 per cent tax concession for shares in an MIC which are disposed of within four years of the MIC becoming licensed or the shares being paid up, whichever is the later event. The clawback provisions are designed to encourage patient investment in the MICs while at the same time preventing abuses of the tax concession by investors. This Bill proposes to amend both the MIC Act and the Income Tax Assessment Act to enable a MIC to voluntarily surrender its licence without triggering the clawback provisions provided investors do not dispose of their shares in that MIC within the statutory four-year period.

The Bill also proposes a number of minor amendments to the MIC Act. These amendments are necessary to clarify certain provisions, to remove a number of unnecessary restrictions and to resolve other administrative difficulties. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill, and commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Smith) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: SEA INSTALLATIONS BILL 1987[COGNATE BILLS:SEA INSTALLATIONS LEVY BILL 1987SEA INSTALLATIONS (MISCELLANEOUS AMENDMENTS) BILL 1987]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 7 October, on motion by Mr John Brown:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand it is the wish of the House to debate this Bill concurrently with the Sea Installations Levy Bill and the Sea Installations (Miscellaneour Amendments). There being no objection, the Chair will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mr W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The House is debating cognately three Bills: the Sea Installations Bill 1987, the Sea Installations Levy Bill 1987 and the Sea Installations (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 1987. This legislation has come back to the House because its passage was interrupted by the intervention of the early election. There have been some amendments to the original proposals put forward by the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mr John Brown), which will be discussed today. We in the Opposition do not oppose the Bills and we will join with the Government to ensure that they have a speedy passage through this House. We recognise that their main purpose is to clarify the legal status of off-shore installations, which may become increasingly numerous, particularly on the Great Barrier Reef. We also recognise that these Bills seek a balance between the protection of unique environmental and often fragile ecosystems and the development of off-shore installations in Commonwealth waters.

SPEECH.PARA: Some of the installations covered by the Bills will enhance our tourist potential, and we recognise that tourism is an increasingly important sector of the Australian economy. The shadow Minister with responsibility for tourism, the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp), will be making some remarks about that later. When this legislation was first introduced it received quite a deal of publicity, some of which appeared in the Australian newspaper. It referred to the installation which will be the first to be subject to this legislation, the $40m luxury motel that will be lodged, if that is the right word, or secured, on John Brewer Reef, which I think is about 72 kilometres off Townsville. This will be the legislation that applies to that. I am sure my colleague the honourable member for Gilmore will expand on that point.

As I have said, we recognise that tourism is an increasingly important sector of the Australian economy. But this legislation refers to off-shore installations such as historic shipwrecks, commercial fishing boats, fish aggregation devices, maritime platforms, off-shore drilling rigs and vessels, defence installations and navigational aids, which are already covered by other Acts but which under this legislation will be exempt from the present provisions. The Opposition believes that the installations covered by the Bills, such as floating hotels and installations which exploit the resources of the sub-soil of the sea bed, which are not already covered by other Acts, should be subject to the same levies and taxes that they would attract if located on the mainland. In other words, the Opposition is as keen as the Government to see that off-shore installations are not used as tax avoidance measures.

The Opposition welcomes in particular the attempt to clarify Commonwealth and State responsibilities and arrangements. In general terms, the States are to administer the regulation on a practical day to day basis, for which the Government will pay an administrative fee. The Sea Installations (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill will bring to bear the existing provisions of the Customs Act, the Excise Act, the Migration Act and the Quarantine Act to have application to these sea installations. We hope that the Bills will eliminate unnecessary duplication by the Commonwealth and the States.

I have raised a number of points which I now wish to pursue. They pertain to the legal status of off-shore installations, environmental issues, the levies that will apply, and Commonwealth-State arrangements, all of which are inextricably linked. In regard to the legal status of off-shore installations, the legislation extends Commonwealth law to adjacent areas-that is, the area between the territorial sea, which is administered by the States, and the limit of the continental shelf or the Australian fishing zone. While the legislation is primarily aimed at recent proposed developments on the Barrier Reef, an amendment now includes Heard and Macdonald islands and the Australian Antarctic Territory.

As shadow Minister for science and energy, I have a particular interest in the Antarctic and I would be concerned about any off-shore installation in that area. Any proposal to establish an off-shore installation, particularly a floating hotel, off the cost of Antarctica should be examined very carefully by the Opposition, and will be. The Antarctic represents one of the few remaining true wilderness areas in the world. The entire marine ecosystem relies on the krill found in the area. Any pollution which affects this organism which may destroy the delicately balanced ecosystem would attract international concern. The coalition parties will be vigilant in monitoring any proposed developments in Antarctic's off-shore regions.

It was interesting at the time this was brought forward that the Minister referred to the possibility of the development of floating resorts in the Antarctic; indeed, this matter was referred to in the Canberra Times and also in the Australian Financial Review. If one looks at the Antarctic Treaty system, one sees that it was never envisaged that there would be activities for profit in Antarctica. Perhaps with a view to the fact that the Antarctic Treaty is soon to be renegotiated, Australia should be looking far more carefully at what it is doing in that area. We must ensure that in signalling to the rest of the world that we see potential commercial activities there we do not transgress the spirit of the original Antarctic Treaty system which was set up in the late 1950s. Indeed, it might be a good idea to say that we want floating hotels in the Antarctic, but it might be a product of the Minister's undoubted enthusiasm for tourism.

Perhaps there are other considerations before we run holus bolus into developing activities of that type in that area. There would be opportunities to develop staging points at Heard and Macdonald islands for tourists to embark from there on excursions to Antarctica; but the environment there is delicate and there needs to be a great deal of consideration before we embrace such a concept. I urge the Minister to look at this matter carefully and to keep in mind the difficult complex international relations, defence and other issues pertaining to our activities in Antarctica. It is a shame that more honourable members do not take an interest in Antarctica. Australia claims a very large area of Antarctica. I know that the member for La Trobe (Mr Milton) has visited Antarctica and has expert knowledge. Perhaps he will comment about it. More honourable members on both sides of this Parliament should take a greater interest in Antarctica. I think that we will need to do so in the years ahead because many interesting topics will need to be addressed.

I also want to deal with environmental issues. I have already alluded to the fact that legislation should take into account a reasonable balance between environmental and development issues. The Opposition values the variety of ecosystems and environments found in Australia, both on-shore and off-shore.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the rainforests?

—I shall mention that point. The Opposition is keen to see that these attributes are protected by legislation. Under the legislation it will be necessary for the operators of sea installations to obtain permits from the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. The Minister will have the capacity to permit or refuse the granting of a permit. That is a great deal of power and we trust that the present Minister and future Ministers will use it wisely. The Minister is now somewhat constrained by a recent amendment under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act. A consequential amendment provides that the time limits in which the Minister must finalise an application is subject to, inter alia, whether or not an environmental impact statement is required. I am not sure whether that is mandatory, and perhaps the Minister in his reply could elaborate.

SPEECH.PARA: In respect of the proposal for the John Brewer Reef an extensive environmental impact study was undertaken by the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority. The Minister also has it within his power to take action if an installation has an adverse effect on the environment, or where improvements so directed have not been completed within the time specified. As long as the Minister treats all such cases on an individual basis and is not arbitrary in his decision making, we regard this power as reasonable-so long as the prime objective is to protect the environment rather than to raise revenue from those who could be described as miscreants.

The subject of levies and taxes always creates some interest. The Government, quite rightly, extends the scope of the income tax law and sales tax law to include income derived by non-residents from commercial activities conducted in certain island territories and from fixed tourist and other installations in the waters surrounding Australia and those islands. The legislation will raise a levy from the operators of sea installations, except those for which an exemption certificate is in force, and those which fall into a class declared by the regulations to be exempt. The legislation now specifies a maximum of 20 per cent of the valuation of the installation or 20 per cent of the gross revenue derived from the installation, whichever is the greater. It is interesting to study the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills report which looked into the first set of legislation. It is an extensive report and raises some concerns about the levy. The legislation formerly did not provide for a ceiling in relation to the percentage of levy that would be payable, and as the rate was to be set by regulation the Senate Committee considered that this was inappropriate.

It is also interesting to look at the speech in which the levy was introduced and which contains the reasons for it. It is important to understand why the levy has been imposed. It will ensure that the administrative costs of the States and Territories are met and the general revenue can benefit as it would if similar installations were located on the mainland. Quite rightly, the States have pointed out that the development of off-shore installations for commercial purposes should not be at the expense of the mainland economy and should not provide a basis for evasion of State and Territory legislation. The Commonwealth accepts this, and the intention is that the levy be set with these factors in mind. It is also interesting to note that the first legislation had no ceiling on the levy and that this legislation does have a ceiling. Those who are contemplating commercial activity by introducing sea installations will be pleased to note what amount they should be factoring into these calculations.

It is now an offence to fail to pay the levy within 28 days of its becoming due. I hope that this provision will not be dealt with in a summary way. I also hope that there will be no retrospectivity. Looking through the legislation I saw a reference indicating that this would not be the case, and I believe that the Scrutiny of Bills Committee so recommended. Most elements of the legislation will commence on 15 October. It is just as well that this legislation goes through with the support of the Opposition and, I believe, the Australian Democrats.

As shadow Minister for science and energy, I am pleased that certain research facilities are exempt from the levy. It is very important that Australia continues to take the lead in fundamental research which has no known immediate application. Australia already has a fine reputation internationally in the area of marine research and any measures which can ease its carriage are welcome. An amendment will permit exemptions from the legislation to be made by the Minister, whether or not an application for exemption has been made. This is eminently sensible. It will simplify the operation of the provision so that individuals will not be put to the trouble of applying where this is unnecessary to achieve the desired result and where the understandings which Australia has with Antarctic Treaty countries can be pursued effectively.

I draw attention to what happened in Senate Estimates Committee A on 19 October when members of the Australian Institute of Marine Science appeared before that Committee. The Institute is established in Townsville and it has, as its charter, an overview of marine research right around the country, but because of budgetary constraints which have existed under the present Government and coalition governments it has the ability to look at only tropical areas. Dr Baker, the Director of that Institute, in his evidence to the Estimates Committee and following questioning revealed an important point about the crown of thorns starfish phenomenon, of which many honourable members are well aware. We know that unless it is controlled and understood it could ravage the Barrier Reefs which is probably our biggest single natural phenomenon of world note. Dr Baker said:

. . . the important aspect is to be able to maintain a survey program over a large number of years. Research has indicated that the life cycle studies, and the way in which the crown of thorns affects the reef, requires a study period of at least 15 years. The incidence of crown of thorns outbreaks apparently is in the 15 to 30 year phase.
He went on:
The funding, which goes through the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority, is guaranteed only until next year.
I hope that the honourable member for La Trobe heard that-that the funding for the crown-of- thorns starfish program is guaranteed only until next year. Dr Baker then said:
I have discussed with the Chairman of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority a joint approach to our two Ministers to draw attention to the importance of the continuing survey.

Whilst this is important to the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority and the Institute of Marine Science, it is also very important to those people who want to set up sea installations because one of the ways in which they attract people is to get them to come and have a look at the fantastic Barrier Reef. To put the debate in its simplest form, if the starfish eat the coral we would want to understand that and take steps to overcome it. Perhaps in this debate about research we should ensure that we are not looking at everything in terms of getting money or results back very quickly because there are some problems, such as starfish in Australia, which, because of the 15- to 30-year-cycle, need research now. But research done today will not produce benefits or knowledge until way down the track. Let us not close our minds to the problems that exist there.

I turn to the question of Commonwealth-State arrangements. States have responsibilities and can raise revenue from installations in the area defined as `territorial sea'. Beyond this-to the limits of the continental shelf or the Australian fishing zone-the responsibility belongs to the Commonwealth. The legislation sensibly avoids unnecessary State-Commonwealth duplication and the consequent expense to taxpayers. The legislation extends State regulations out to the Commonwealth boundary. Even though it is Commonwealth territory, the States will administer the regulations on a day to day basis. Recent amendments include Norfolk Island in the consultative processes and a new clause consolidates consultations with the States and the Northern Territory in relation to the granting, renewing, varying and revoking of permits. Recent amendments also include the islands that I mentioned earlier-Heard and Macdonald. As a Tasmanian, as well as the shadow Minister for science and energy with an interest in Antarctic matters, I wonder who will administer these areas. It is not particularly clear at the moment.

A number of concerns have been voiced by the States, primarily Queensland. Queensland has objected to the definition of the `territorial sea' and consequently of State and Commonwealth jurisdiction. For example, Queensland has argued that floating hotels on the Barrier Reef are de facto extensions of the Queensland territorial sea because they are serviced by the mainland. We see little merit in that argument. Another concern voiced by Queensland is that the State might lose revenue-for example, from liquor licences which it otherwise would have obtained had the off-shore installation been in territorial waters. We view this as an invalid argument, given that such installations under the present legislation are in no way avoiding their responsibilities and, by and large, they are in a location determined by environmental features and not by considerations of State-Commonwealth taxes.

I turn to the States' lack of veto over the provision of a permit. Once again, we regard this as an invalid concern. The legislation specifically requires that the Commonwealth Government consult with the States on the issuing of a permit and that the administration costs of the State are fully met. As yet, I know of no formula to ensure that the States obtain full recompense for their services. It is important that the States be fully recompensed for their administration of the installations. We will follow with interest any such negotiations between the Commonwealth and the States to see that the Commonwealth does not short-change the States in any way.

There is also another concern which I will raise in committee because there are two amendments to this legislation, which we support. The concern involves the definition of `aircraft' given in the legislation. I point out that there are no pirate radio stations in Australia-that is, stations that are set off-shore-but, under this Sea Installations Bill, it is conceivable that that could be the case. Someone could go off-shore, anchor something there and beam signals into Queensland. We all know the controversy over the auctioning of radio licence systems. If one missed out on a licence one could apply to the Minister for a permit, perhaps obtain it, go off-shore and set up a radio station. I do not think that this legislation envisages that problem and I do not know whether any consideration has been given to it, but it is interesting to note that the amendment refers to `aircraft' and the definition of `aircraft' is a little different from that in the Federal Airports Corporation Act. I would like to know how the advisers were able to change the definition; perhaps they did not go far enough in the first instance. The amendment refers to dirigibles, or what are commonly called airships. Perhaps one could describe this amendment as the Bond amendment, because basically it will mean that an airship anchored on the John Brewer Reef will be deemed to be a sea installation and therefore required to pay a levy. Under this amendment it will also be required to have a permit. Perhaps someone has been thinking about the consequences of setting up pirate radio stations and having those signals beamed out of Bond's airships. It will be interesting to see whether anyone from the Department or any of the Ministers will give us more information as to why this amendment has been presented and why this was done only this morning.

The number of permits issued and the location of those permits are other concerns. The whole thrust of the legislation balances conservation and development. There is hope not only that the legislation will provide for consideration of all the issues involved, but also that the Minister will be able to deal sensitively with the inevitable conflict resulting from differing values, beliefs and attitudes. If the northern Queensland rainforest issue is an example of how the Minister for the Environment and the Arts (Senator Richardson) deals with sensitive issues, then this is indeed a matter of concern. The power vested in the Minister is considerable. One only hopes that his Department will provide the necessary rein. In conclusion, as I stated earlier, the Opposition will not oppose this package of legislation or the proposed amendments. In theory we regard it as a sensible and practical approach to a sensitive problem of State versus Commonwealth responsibilities and environmental and development issues. We will, of course, be vigilant in overseeing the operation of this legislation in practice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —In supporting the Sea Installations Bill 1987 and the accompanying Sea Installations Levy Bill and Sea Installations (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill, I take the opportunity to add to the remarks that I made when the earlier Sea Installations Bill was debated in the House because this Bill now covers sea installations which might be put in place in the Australian Antarctic Territory.

SPEECH.PARA: It was refreshing to hear the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith) and to find that there is so much agreement between the two sides of the House on this Bill. That does not often happen in this place. I did not quite agree with some of his comments about the Minister for the Environment and the Arts (Senator Richardson) and the rainforests; nevertheless, I heartily agree with his comments about the Antarctic Territory and the crown-of-thorns starfish. I think it is absolutely vital that research on the crown of thorns starfish continue and I will certainly do my utmost to prevail upon the Minister to ensure that he supports more funding being made available. I commend to the honourable member for Bass the report which the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation, as it was previously known-it has a different name now-prepared on the crown-of-thorns starfish. We made recommendations to the Minister--

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a good report.

—Yes, it was a good report, as the honourable member for Dunkley said. He took part in its preparation and I was the Committee Chairman. We will try to ensure that the recommendations that we made at that time are acted upon. As a result of our recommendations, money has been spent on this research and it is absolutely vital that the funding continue, as the honourable member for Bass said.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 7 (6) of the Bill refers specifically to the Australian Antarctic Territory and defines the area covered by the Bill in respect of that Territory. Clause 7 (7) deals with all those territories not previously mentioned and would include Heard Island and Macdonald Island. I am not sure whether the honourable member for Bass was thinking that, because Macquarie Island is part of the jurisdiction of Tasmania, it should also have Heard and Macdonald islands. It is highly unlikely that would happen. I am quite sure that the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck) would be very happy if they were included, as Macquarie Island is also part of his electorate. It is an indication of the immense responsibilities Australia has as a nation that the seas adjacent to the Australian continent and our external territories, including the Antarctic Territory, cover many thousands of square kilometres. The Bill has been specifically introduced at this time, I presume, to enable monitoring of the environmental consequences of a floating hotel which is to be installed on the John Brewer Reef and which is to be opened very shortly. Proposals have also been made by some entrepreneurs that a floating hotel be installed off the coast of Antarctica, although I understand that that proposal has not yet been put to paper.

I am most pleased, therefore, that the present Bill covers the Australian Antarctic Territory as it gives me the opportunity to say something about the problems which could affect any sea installations which might be put in place in the coastal seas adjacent to Antarctica. It also gives me the opportunity, publicly, to thank the Antarctic Division and the Director, Jim Bleasel, for giving me the opportunity to join the 1986-87 Antarctic voyage No. 5 on the Nella Dan from last November to February and to experience, at first hand, the awesome grandeur of frozen Antarctica. It is a pity that the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer) is not in the chamber because he has often asked me when I was going to talk about the Antarctic. I am now speaking about the Antarctic and he is not here.

The Antarctic Division has now been moved from the Department of Science to the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. I must say that I was disappointed to read, in an article about the transfer of the Division in the September issue of the ANARE Club journal, Aurora, comments by Ian Bird which referred to `another round of junket tours of Antarctica by yet another wave of bureaucrats and parliamentarians set to become instant experts'.
