On behalf of the honourable member for Banks (Mr Mountford), the honourable member for Farrer, the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) and the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl), who have all been to the Antarctic, as have a number of honourable senators, I can only say to Ian that not all expeditioners or Division officers consider that parliamentarians who visit Antarctica are junketing. I hope that the report I produced in February, after my seven-week extensive tour of our bases in Antarctica-the only one I did not visit was Mawson, unfortunately-will prove a useful contribution in support of the valuable work of the Division.

Having established my credentials to talk about sea installations in the coastal waters of Antarctica, I note the interpretation of such structures as set out in clause 4 of the Bill. A sea installation is defined as `any man-made structure, partly or wholly constructed or the remains of such a structure that, when in, or brought into, physical contact with the seabed or when floating, can be used for an environment-related activity'. An environment related activity under the same clause includes any activity relating to and including a scientific activity and a transport activity.

The Bill makes it clear that a sea installation covers a wide range of structures, including floating hotels, oil rigs and diving platforms, but not off-shore installations such as jetties and harbours. The Bill also refers to a number of existing Acts which will also apply to sea installations, such as the Crimes Act, the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act and the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act. I propose to deal mainly with the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 and to say specifically how pleased I am that the Act applies to sea installations. Clause 33 of the Bill gives the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories the power to require within a specified period an environmental impact statement in relation to obtaining, renewing or carrying a permit to operate a sea installation.

In this respect it would be interesting to sight the memoranda of undertaking which I understand the Minister's Department has prepared in relation to sea installations. The memoranda are used to set out the procedures which are to be followed to give effect to the Environment Protection Act. I imagine that the memoranda would be very different for a sea installation to be put in place in Antarctica compared with the floating hotel which will be put in place at the John Brewer Reef on the Great Barrier Reef. Whilst, as I have indicated, I am pleased that the Sea Installations Bill applies to the Antarctica, it amazes me that anybody could consider constructing a sea installation such as a floating hotel in such a hostile environment.

Imagine the scene: a floating hotel in a totally frozen sea in mid-winter, with temperatures as low as minus 60 degrees centigrade and fierce winds sometimes gusting to 250 kilometres per hour. As the glaciers flow off the great ice desert continent, which is almost twice the size of Australia, huge ice shelves and ice tongues are formed from which icebergs, some as large as 100 kilometres long and 50 kilometres wide, drift through the pack ice. It is incomprehensible to me that anybody could contemplate constructing a sea installation in Antarctic seas subject to such adverse conditions. An environmental impact statement would make it very clear to anybody contemplating such a venture that it was folly of the highest order and also a potential risk of pollution to one of the most unpolluted places on our planet.

How could a floating hotel or an oil rig avoid a crushing collision with even a small iceberg, and how could such a structure withstand the hurricane force winds? Even the pack ice can be dangerous as I found when, as passengers on the Nella Dan last summer, we were trapped in the pack ice for eight days. The pressure of that ice caused the hull of the Nella Dan to be forced upwards and large icebergs were moving slowly towards us as the days progressed. Fortunately, we were rescued by the Soviet ship, the Mikhail Somov. Thus we were fortunate, as in another 20 days, some of the expeditioners on board calculated, we could have been crushed to pieces by one of the icebergs.

An oil rig would be an even greater hazard in Antarctic conditions because of the possible spillage of oil. Many millions of seabirds, penguins, seals and fish abound in Antarctic waters. An oil spillage would be a disaster of inestimable proportions. I would like to quote from a letter I received from the Wildlife Preservation Society of Queensland Inc.:

It should be noted that even `state of the art' semi-submersible accommodation facilities such as the Ocean Ranger drilling rig and accommodation platform in Newfoundland, Canada, are very dangerous facilities for which employees are paid high risk wages. In the case of Ocean Ranger, `despite its size, its reputation for invulnerability, and the regulatory control over its design, construction and operation, the Ocean Ranger and its entire crew were lost less than two years after the rig arrived on the Grand Banks'.

The final words enclosed in quotation marks came from a royal commission report of 1984. With reference to the requirements in clause 33 of the Bill for an environmental impact statement in relation to a sea installation permit, the Antarctic Division has developed, in consultation with the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service, a set of guidelines for the environmental assessment of human activity on our Antarctic bases. The guidelines, suitably adapted for any proposed sea installations in the Antarctic would, in my view, be appropriate for the application of the Sea Installations Bill in relation to the Antarctic. I certainly hope that the Minister gives consideration to those guidelines if permits should be sought to construct a floating hotel in Antarctic waters.

With regard to oil rigs, we probably have some time up our sleeves. The Government has already commented that the possibility of mineral exploitation of the Antarctic is extremely remote. Oil exploration is complicated by political questions of sovereignty, resource control and environmental protection. Some 32 nations are signatories of the Antarctic Treaty. There is considerable co-operation and a free flow and exchange of scientific data amongst those nations. No provisions are in place to deal with mineral exploitation and Treaty nations have urged a voluntary restraint on exploration and exploitation until a minerals regime has been established to control those activities. The construction of oil rigs in our Antarctic seas is unlikely to occur until a whole range of complex political problems has been solved. I hope that a 30-year moratorium is introduced at the very least.

Nuclear weapons and minerals and other military activities are banned in Antarctica. Why not mineral exploitation also? Hopefully, one day Antarctica will become a world park. But in the meantime, a conservation strategy should be adopted by the Treaty nations which bans all mineral exploitation activities.

To refer again to the floating hotel proposal, whilst I am not aware that a floating hotel might be located in the Australian Antarctic Territory, it is possible that a site close to the Davis Station might be considered. However, even if constructing and locating a floating hotel at Davis were technically feasible, it is not a proposition which would gain my support. I am glad to see that the honourable member for Bass agrees with me. Whilst the possibility of an airstrip at Davis might be considered, I do not believe that our activities at the stations are sufficiently advanced to deal with an influx of private tourists. The airstrip could be built on the flat land area on the seaward side of the Vestfold Hills, provided that no disturbance occurred to the penguin rookeries on the outlying islands and there was no pollution from the jet engines, which might adversely affect the many lakes in the hills. An airstrip could provide an important boost to our support facilities for expeditioners in Antarctica, and is a project which I understand is under consideration. A floating hotel with private tourists could prove to be a hindrance to our scientific activities and I doubt that such a presence would be welcomed by expeditioners.

The political complexities of the Antarctic Treaty system and Australia's presence in Antarctica have an integral relationship to the legislation before the House. It is vital that we control the developmental and environmental consequences of sea installations located in the Antarctic coastal waters, and our legislation assumes that we have sovereignty over 42 per cent of the Antarctic continent. I would like to quote the following passage from my own report, which I submitted in February 1987 to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation:

Four claimant countries mutually recognise each other's claims to Antarctic Territory, namely, Australia, France, New Zealand and the United Kingdom; the three remaining claimant countries, Argentina, Chile and Norway, do not recognise the other claims and the remaining 25 Treaty members, including the USA and the USSR do not recognise any sovereignty claims to Antarctic Territory. In fact, the USSR maintains 4 permanent stations and 4 summer stations in the Australian Antarctic Territory. Many other Treaty countries also maintain stations in other claimant areas.

It can be seen that the sovereignty issue is complex, but one thing is clear: Australia has a responsibility to the international community, and particularly to Treaty nations, to ensure that the environment of the Australian Antarctic Territory and the surrounding seas is fully protected in respect of our own nationals, regardless of the sovereignty issue. In that respect, the present Bill is an important piece of protective legislation, and it is to be hoped that other treaty nations will follow Australia's example and introduce similar protective legislation.

I would now like to add to the remarks made earlier in this speech with regard to proposed floating hotels on the Great Barrier Reef. The John Brewer Reef floating hotel is presently being constructed in Singapore. I understand that it is a seven-storey structure and has 200 rooms and suites, which will have outstanding views of the reef. It also has world class amenities, including telephones with international dialling, and so on. There are three dining options and a fine a la carte restaurant, a coffee shop, an outdoor barbecue facility and other facilities. I understand that, since the original proposal was submitted to the Government, it is intended that it will be modified by the promoters. Indeed, even the proposed location of the hotel may be changed. If such modifications are to occur, it will be important to ensure that the proposed floating hotel be subject to all the provisions of the present Bill, including an environmental impact statement. Perhaps the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mr John Brown) could comment on what would happen if such modifications were to take place.

In common with the Wildlife Preservation Society of Queensland and the Australian Conservation Foundation, I have strong concerns about the potential impact which floating hotels and other structures will have on the Great Barrier Reef. As I mentioned in my previous speech in this House, on 5 May, in relation to the present legislation, the prospect of freehold real estate on the Great Barrier Reef, and the consequent uncontrolled development of both private and tourist facilities, could present a great threat to the fragile environment of the reef. It is vital that stringent monitoring studies should be undertaken of the impact of the John Brewer Reef floating hotel tourist facilities on the Great Barrier Reef as a whole.

Another proposal is also in the pipeline for the construction of a $20m floating hotel to be anchored in the Fitzroy Reef lagoon off Gladstone. This proposal includes a five-storey hotel accommodating 360 beds and includes an underwater restaurant and facilities for day trippers. It seems to me that it is absolutely vital that consideration of this proposal should be deferred until a satisfactory monitoring study of the John Brewer Reef floating hotel has been completed.

Another problem is the fact that a third proposal for a floating hotel, accommodating 100 overnight guests and 100 day visitors, proposed for the Lady Musgrave Island lagoon does not come under the provisions of the present Bill, because it is in waters under the control of the Queensland State Government. However, the proposal also comes under the provisions of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act and its accompanying regulations. The reef is also part of a World Heritage area and, therefore, Australia has a responsibility to the international community to ensure that the reef is protected from environmental damage, and that includes controls on tourist development.

It is important for both tourism and conservation that the Great Barrier Reef is not irrecoverably damaged by overuse or inappropriate development. The immediate responsibility lies with the officers of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority, whose job it is to ensure that such damage does not occur. The Authority is led by the Director, Graeme Kelleher, and I have seen some of their very valuable work. I want them to ensure that the fragile beauty of the Great Barrier Reef is protected.

I now refer briefly to one omission from the Bill, which gives both me and conservation groups a number of concerns. Clauses 20, 26 and 31 deal with applications for a permit or renewal or variation of an existing permit. I would suggest that consideration be given to a requirement that preliminary environmental advice be included as part of the application, so that the Minister is alerted to possible environmental matters which could necessitate, or negate possibly, the need for an environmental impact statement under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act, as is provided in clause 33.

I hope that the Minister will take into account the comments I have made. I have much pleasure in looking forward to the implementation of the provisions of this most important Bill. I note that the Opposition is supporting the Bill, and I understand that the Australian Democrats are supporting it in the other place, so it has every possibility of passing through both this House and the other chamber in prompt time. That is very important, as we need to get this legislation operating as soon as possible, because there are proposed sea installation developments, particularly those concerning the Great Barrier Reef, which are moving forward. We need to get this legislation set so that we can apply it to all those proposals. In my view, that would include the John Brewer Reef floating hotel proposal also.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad to see that the Sea Installations Bill, the Sea Installations Levy Bill and the Sea Installations (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill have been reintroduced after they became invalid as a result of the Federal election held on 11 July. When this legislation was introduced in May of this year, I spoke as shadow Minister for the environment and conservation. I said then, and I repeat now, that the Opposition welcomes this legislation. We most certainly support it, because it is simply recognising a changing situation on the Great Barrier Reef and in off-shore areas generally around Australia. The legislation puts forward very constructive and practical solutions to the problems that will be brought about by having various floating structures anchored off the coast of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: These Bills basically attempt to clarify the legal status of off-shore installations around Australia. These installations are going to become an important part of the tourist assets of this country. In principle there would be practically no honourable member of this House, if any member at all, who would be opposed to that form of development to enhance Australia's tourist potential. But what has happened with this legislation, and what differentiates it from its predecessor introduced in May, is that it also addresses the issue of Antarctica. I have been particularly interested to see that. It had not occurred to me that anybody was planning some sort of tourist related off-shore installation in Antarctica.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been talked about.

—That interests me. The honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith) said that far too few members of this House were interested in Antarctica. I can claim to have a very real interest in it, having been for eight years a member of the Department of Foreign Affairs and, during that period, having served in Brussels where we played a very important part in negotiating the Convention on the Conservation of Antarctic Marine Living Resources.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Deputy Speaker, I hope that you will bear with me in this slight digression when I say, to be party political, that that Convention was one of the real achievements of the Fraser Government in the environmental and Antarctic area. I do not doubt that the present Government would have done the same thing, but it was certainly one of our achievements. We had enormous difficulties in negotiating that Convention-difficulties of which few people would be aware-which related to the status of the European Community, a status which the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics was not willing to recognise. At one stage, in about 1978 or 1979-I forget precisely when-the whole prospect of this very important Convention was in doubt because of this log-jam between the Soviet Union and the European Community. It was a great tribute to Australia that we were the country which eventually found a formula which broke that log-jam.

So I have a great interest in Antarctica. I envy the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Milton), the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) and others who have had the opportunity to go there. I hope that the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mr John Brown) will one day extend to me the same opportunity as has been extended to my colleagues, because I am interested in the reports that they have brought back from Antarctica, and I very much agree with many of the points that they have made.

I must say that I have some reservations about the Antarctic Division in Hobart, which I have visited, being transferred from the former Department of Science, where it sat very snugly, to the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, where I suspect it will be given a much lower priority. I pay tribute to the Minister for Science and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) for his interest and enthusiasm for the Antarctic Division when it was part of his portfolio. I wonder whether-I hope I am wrong-the Minister for the Environment and the Arts (Senator Richardson) will accord it the same priority and bring to it the same enthusiasm and interest.

Also, I have been concerned by the controversy that has surrounded the future of the Antarctic Treaty of 1959. That Treaty is basically an extraordinarily important and valuable document. The honourable member for La Trobe spoke of some of the inconsistencies over claimant states and who recognises claims and who does not. This Treaty is one of those curious examples of international compromise and common sense where the issue of claims has really been set aside so that everybody is somehow or other happy about the issue of claims. If, however, we were to anchor off-shore installations off Antarctica-installations that would be covered by this legislation-it would raise some questions about how non-claimant states would feel about the status of those installations.

The Antarctic Treaty has really managed to progress over the years in a very pragmatic and intelligent sort of way. Of course, the Convention on the Conservation of Antarctic Marine Living Resources was something which, effectively, came out of that Treaty.

I regret the approach that the Malaysian Government has taken to that Treaty. It has been a little headstrong and I suspect it is motivated by things other than practical common-sense solutions to foreign policy issues. I do not want to wander into that and spend the time of this Parliament attacking Dr Mahathir, but I must say that the attitude of the Malaysian Government has been of real concern to me.

Some people-again the honourable member for La Trobe alluded to this-have spoken to me about the need for Antarctica to be turned into a world park. I suppose that prima facie that is not an unattractive idea, but it would raise very fundamental questions about the legal status of Antarctica and about the Antarctic Treaty itself. I really feel that in the end, but certainly in the short term, it might be better to go on with the few achievements we have in Antarctica rather than run the risk of unscrambling the whole of the omelette and ending up with just a lot of egg on the floor-if that metaphor works. In any case, this legislation is an interesting aspect and an interesting extension of Australia's approach to Antarctica. I would be interested to hear from the Minister, when he winds up the debate, what he believes to be the legal status of this legislation in the case of Antarctica. But I am happy to support that aspect of the legislation.

Of course, in the short term the legislation applies primarily to the Great Barrier Reef. Others have spoken of the Reef Link proposal, to establish a floating hotel on the John Brewer Reef. This is a $31m floating hotel, seven storeys tall with 200 beds and so on. Provided it is environmentally responsible-environmental impact statements have been done and it is believed that it will be-I think it is quite an interesting idea. But let me say that I am sorry that the ship, if one can call it that, or the installation, is not being built in Australia. It is an interesting point that the new policy of the Government on shipbuilding bounties would, in fact, discriminate against this sort of project being built in Australia because, as the Minister told me some two weeks ago, these bounties are not to be used to support ships which are part of the tourist industry. They are really simply to support the building of ships in the field of other aspects of international trade in particular. That is a rather short-sighted way of applying the bounties. Anyway, it is a pity that the ship is not being built here in Australia. But, there we are; it is not and it is too late to worry about that. The particular proposal on John Brewer Reef will enhance the tourist attraction of the Great Barrier Reef. As I have said, it is being done environmentally responsibly and so from that point of view I am satisfied.

The Great Barrier Reef is without doubt one of our greatest national assets and we are happy to have it on the World Heritage List. The Fraser Government did a great deal to ensure that the Great Barrier Reef achieved the status that it has today. I am proud of that achievement of the Fraser Government. We do not want, and nor, I am sure, does anyone in this House want the Great Barrier Reef in any way to be abused. There are two very obvious abuses that need to be avoided and which this legislation ensures are avoided. Of course, the first is the preservation of its environment-its unique beauty and its enormous ecological significance and, in a way, its importance as a tourist asset. If we start to destroy or denigrate the environment, we will not get the tourist potential from that asset.

In any case, this legislation ensures that the Commonwealth's approach to responsible environmental policy is applied to the Great Barrier Reef and to any off-shore installations on the Great Barrier Reef. As I said when I last spoke in a similar debate back in May, I have had a concern that the result of these proposals to place off-shore installations on the Great Barrier Reef-there are several proposals, and there are some pontoons there already-will be that one day we will end up with a great flotilla of off-shore installations, what I described last time as a naval review of off-shore installations. That would be terrible. But this legislation gives the Minister the discretion to issue or not to issue permits, so presumably the Minister would be able to stop that happening. The legislation does not explain how the Minister would necessarily apply that; that does not necessarily matter. But I simply say that I hope no Minister of State in Australia would allow a great flotilla, a naval review, of off-shore installations to clutter up and destroy the natural beauty of the Great Barrier Reef and threaten its ecological importance.

The second aspect of this legislation, which overcomes a major problem, is that these off-shore installations could be used as a massive tax avoidance device. This legislation addresses that. If we did not have this legislation, a whole series of off-shore installations would be established to avoid State and Federal taxes, customs duty and so on. One can imagine the pressure then for a flotilla of off-shore installations to be established. But this legislation, in applying State and Commonwealth taxation laws and other laws to these off-shore installations, ensures that that tax avoidance angle is well and truly overcome. So I am glad that that has been achieved.

My colleague the honourable member for Bass raised a number of concerns which I will simply repeat, which were brought to our attention back in May by the Queensland Government. I will run through those again, really on behalf of that Government, in support of the Government. I will refute its concerns because I do not think it has any need to worry in the way that it seems to have worried. First of all, the Queensland Government expressed concern about the definition of the territorial sea. Under the legislation, the territorial sea is defined as extending three miles off shore. But, if there is an installation which is a direct extension from within that three-mile limit, the extremity of that installation becomes the territorial sea of the particular State. The Queensland Government has argued that off-shore installations would be part of the territorial sea. I do not think that argument carries any weight whatsoever. The installations are not connected directly to the mainland. They are not connected at all to the mainland. They are not connected, therefore, to the territorial sea. As that is the case, they should remain within Commonwealth jurisdiction and not under the jurisdiction of the States. I am happy with the legislation on those grounds. I do not think the objection of the Queensland Government has a great deal of substance.

A second objection that has been put forward is that this legislation will ensure that the States will lose revenue. If the States had had control of these off-shore installations and not the Commonwealth, the argument goes, they would have been able to issue liquor licences, which are obviously a form of tax. They would have been able to issue a whole series of licences, and what-have-you, in order to raise revenue. They argue that the levy which is imposed on the installations in this legislation is to raise money to cover the administrative costs to the States of simply administering those off-shore installations, which is correct, but that the levy does not have a component to compensate for the lost revenue if those installations had instead been within the territorial sea or part of the mainland of the State. That whole argument is predicated on the assumption that the installations would have been created on the mainland of the State rather than off-shore had it not been possible to install them off-shore. That is simply an unreasonable assumption. In any case, the States get the benefits of these off-shore installations through a multiplier effect. People who want to go to the John Brewer Reef will first fly to Townsville, I suppose, and then get a motor boat, hovercraft or hydrofoil to the reef. Therefore, the city of Townsville will benefit from the additional influx of tourists, and to make the concession that the States should control the off-shore installations is to change the whole legal basis of the Commonwealth-State relationship in regard to the territorial sea and beyond the territorial sea.

The third concern of the Queensland Government is one that needs to be thought about fairly carefully by the Commonwealth, but one which I do not think requires an amendment or change to the legislation. It is that the Commonwealth, under this legislation, could grant a permit without the agreement of a State. For example, this could be a problem for Queensland in the case of Townsville where there is a casino. The State has given an undertaking-I would imagine but I am not sure-to the operators of the casino in Townsville that other casinos will not be able to spring up all around that city. Therefore, if the operators of the casino were suddenly to find that a new casino was floating just outside of the territorial sea, the operators of the Townsville casino may have very good reason to be concerned about the implications for the financial viability of their casino. That is a reasonable concern. I urge that, where the Commonwealth is considering granting permits, there be proper, effective and sensitive consultation with the relevant State. It is Commonwealth territory beyond the territorial sea, but let us ensure that when the permits are issued an intelligent assessment is made of the implications for facilities on the mainland.

A fourth problem that the Queensland Government raised with us back in May was the question of the levies and the administrative payments. I do not want to go into the details of the levies as I see that the Government has amended this particular piece of legislation, placing a ceiling on the levy. Before there was no ceiling on the levy. Presumably, the levy could have been at any level. The levy is designed to collect money in order to make the payments to the States for the administration of the State and Commonwealth regulations of the off-shore facilities.

Let us ensure that the Commonwealth covers the administrative costs of the State and does not short-change it. Certainly, the Queensland Government, in relation to other administrative payments made to it in respect of the administration of the Great Barrier Reef, has expressed concern that it has been short-changed. I have not investigated those allegations. I do not know how correct those allegations are, but it is going to be important that the full administrative cost to the State is covered by the levy, otherwise, as anybody in this House would agree, the system would be seen to be a system by which the Commonwealth used the levy simply to raise additional tax.

Let me make the point that there has to be a reasonable levy in any case. If the levy was set at too low a level-and I know the operators of the John Brewer Reef project probably would not like to hear me say this-it would create an effective tax haven with the off-shore installations. So the levy has to be at some reasonable level. It has to be at a level which reflects the cost of the administration of the various regulations.

In conclusion, I come back to the point I made earlier: how many permits does the Commonwealth intend to issue on the Great Barrier Reef? I repeat: I do not want a naval review of off-shore installations running down the Great Barrier Reef. It is one of the world's greatest environmental assets and future generations will never thank us and never forgive us if we do silly and greedy things which will simply destroy that asset. This legislation is good legislation and it is nice to see the Government doing something constructive in introducing positive legislation to help with the development of our country. I only wish that it could do that sort of thing every day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chynoweth Mr R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with much pleasure that I speak on the Sea Installations Bill, the Sea Installations Levy Bill and the Sea Installations (Miscellaneous Amendment) Bill. The Sea Installations (Miscellaneous Amendment) Bill is a piece of intelligible legislation that seeks, not to part the calmed waters, but to calm part of the waters in Australia where man-made sea installations may be located.

SPEECH.PARA: Remarkably, 200 years ago, almost to the day, one of the world's major overseas package tours was preparing to undertake the final leg of its voyage to our Australian wonderland. At the conclusion of some meticulous preparation and provisioning in South Africa, and at the coming of the high tide, the First Fleet of 11 ships set sail on a hazardous and exacting journey across the great Southern Ocean.

Clearly, their passage from Capetown to Australia's primary overseas visitor destination could have been made considerably more comfortable had a luxurious floating accommodation and recreation centre been anchored in the uninhabited waters of the Great Australian Bight. Hence the Sea Installations (Miscellaneous Amendment) Bill seeks to atone for the inadequacies of history by paving the legislative path with the necessary mechanisms of regulation and control for the proper development in Australia of off-shore resorts and floating hotels.

I was interested to hear the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith) talk about a pirate radio station possibly being established on these installations. I am not certain whether he is aware that one of the directors of the company establishing the floating hotel on the John Brewer Reef is one Doug Anthony, a former member of this House, who I believe has made quite a bit of money out of his family's radio stations. Maybe we should call this amendment the Anthony amendment. Hopefully we can stop National Party propaganda being beamed into Queensland from this off-shore spot.

Australia is a nation of ancient mariners, and its people still go down to the sea in ships to seek pleasure, relaxation, education and a living. The passage of this Bill will allow this facet of our life to be enhanced, not only through the utilisation of this vast aquatic playground, but also by reinforcing some very special guidelines that guard against misuse and abuse, and ensure the protection of our environment. Unreservedly, I state that this latter purpose must be the aim of members of the human race who are the present custodians of this beautiful planet. To this end and with regard to this Bill's forebear, the Sea Installations Act 1987, I have already issued a stern warning that our environment must be protected at all costs. There should be no reason, given the wonders and the achievements of marine technology in the space age, why a predominantly land loving creature cannot enjoy the waters off the Australian coast, in harmony, of course with the sea creatures that live there. But we must approach this issue with extreme caution.

The concept of floating hotels as a part of our tourism industry deserves success. However, the future generations of Australians and overseas visitors who may one day wish to inspect the Neptunian majesty of our bays, shipwrecks, reefs and oceans deserve an assurance that these barnacled aquariums will exist unspoiled forever. This Government sought such an unconditional guarantee from the owners and operators of the world's first floating hotel resort which is soon to be situated within the lagoon of the John Brewer Reef in the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park.

The opening of the complex in February of next year will signal not just the availability of a 24 hours a day room service amongst the beauty of the world's largest living and extremely fragile thing but also the beginning of one of the most thorough and enduring tests that any Australian industry has ever seen. The test is: Can human beings, without gills, live in a habitat which until now has been beyond their natural domiciliary environment? Can the marine life that currently inhabits the John Brewer Reef satisfactorily share its home with a greedy, thoughtless and overpowering creature? Is this complex really the best blend between development and conservation? Clearly, this is an examination that no participant in what is taking place can afford to fail. There is no supplementary examination or second chance to allow for atonement when the unique and precious life forms of nature are exterminated by ignorance.

For this reason I am still concerned that the development at John Brewer Reef may precipitate a flurry of aquatic real estate activity. We do not allow pilots to fly unless they have passed their examinations and have been presented with their wings. We do not allow mechanics to work unless they have passed their examinations and been presented with their indentures. We do not allow medical practitioners to practise unless they have passed their examinations and been bestowed with a degree. So, why should we allow the practice of further floating hotel complexes when we are still uncertain of the outcome of a thorough examination of the results of our first experience with pollution control mechanisms and the strain it may place upon the environment?

Australia's hydrous property should be seen as a part of the crown jewels of this nation. Such off-shore real estate is a priceless resource that must never be subdivided or auctioned to the highest bidder. Of course, as time passes and this world teeters more precariously on the brink of urban holocaust, the value of beautiful coral cays, crystal clear waters and magnificent marine life appreciates dramatically. But such wealth presents a fundamental dilemma. That dilemma is in essence at the centre of this Bill. Should Australia's off-shore treasures remain locked away forever to gather seaweed in a vault where the light is filtered, or should the intricacies and beauties of Australia's marine culture be displayed for all to see and admire? What purpose is there in holding a valuable and beautiful pearl if no one can see it? What purpose is there in displaying a valuable and beautiful pearl if everyone, in viewing or handling it, destroys it? Perhaps the lapping of the sea against the hull of the Four Seasons Group's seagoing pleasure palace will provide the right answers. It is imperative that the most precise monitoring occur and that when comprehensive results are available they be made known to all sections of society for further analysis and deliberation.

I maintain that certain key elements of this installation's operation are crucial to the survival or extermination of the environment in which this seven-storey holiday-maker's paradise is to be anchored. What will happen in the likelihood of one of the following accidental events occurring? Are contingency plans in place for the following possibilities? Firstly, in the unlikely event of the malfunctioning of the sewage treatment plant, will the life-giving water upon which the hotel is buoyant be threatened with contamination? Secondly, in the unlikely event of the spilling of diesel fuel as a result of a fuel hose rupture or some other accidental event, will the rich environment in which so many unique kinds of fish and animal life live be threatened with a black murky mask? Thirdly, in the unlikely event of a fire on the gently swaying hotel convention centre, will the entire lagoon be threatened by a fiery phenomenon that has never been known before in this type of environment? Fourthly, in the unlikely event of a loss of moorings and the subsequent grounding of the complex on the reef, will the delicate balance of nature be threatened by an unnatural and non-compatible man-made structure crashing on to fragile coral reef? Finally, in the unlikely event of an accident occurring to the vessels servicing this giant changing room anchored on top of one of nature's perfect swimming pools, will the unspoiled beauty of the location be stained irrevocably?

Perhaps I am being pedantic to go so far as to suggest that one of these unfortunate outcomes may occur. However, I would prefer to describe my concern as justified in the light of the huge fire on the resort of Hamilton Island. I would prefer to call my uncertainty wise when read in conjunction with the recent breakdown and fire on one of the giant Reeflink Resort Pty Ltd ferries in the waters beyond Townsville. I would prefer to label my hesitation and concern as constructive criticism. I could quote many examples of oil spillages and sewage disposal to back up my argument.

Essentially, my basic premise remains unchanged. The advancement of mankind into a vacuum devoid of the elements necessary to sustain the human life form without breathing apparatus and flotation devices must be a very careful and calculated step. My purpose in highlighting the floating complex at the John Brewer Reef has been to illustrate some of the basic problems that may impede the harmonious integration of any sea installation in Australia with the environment in which it is placed. We will never outrun the inescapable fact that human beings were not made to live on, or in, the water. Hence, the presence of homo sapiens in flippers and floating fun factories is, and always will be, an artificial creation. Man is simply seeking to become a tenant of the seas. Unfortunately, his stay will incur an ecological price.

In considering the introduction of further floating hotels off the coast of Australia, we must assess the price of a room and who is going to pay. Our answer to the question on tariff must be tempered with an understanding that once nature has been violated it cannot be truly redeemed. Similarly, our answer to the question of who foots the bill rests with our desire and ability to enjoy the beauties of this planet.

Clearly, from a tourist developer's viewpoint, John Brewer Reef is the ideal location for the development of a holiday haven. I have been there. I have swum in its crystal clear waters and I know its beauties. A myriad of features, from the colourful coral to the tempting temperatures, should lure tourists by the boat-load and the helicopter-load. But what about elsewhere? Perhaps the tempestuous seas of Bass Strait or the ferocious waters of the Great Southern Ocean could display to tourists the true ruggedness of the Australian coastline and the abundance of marine life that shares a dislike of warmer waters. Even the coral reefs of the Indian Ocean would be a delight to explore.

However, I am most intrigued and disturbed to learn of the proposal to site a floating hotel and other shore-based tourist resort facilities within the boundaries of Australia's Antarctic Territory. I am intrigued because I had no idea that penguins, fur seals and, indeed, blue whales had any need of a five-star international watering hole at the South Pole. I am disturbed because I suspect that the locals will be driven away from the facility by the high prices, sophisticated service and, above all, an influx of human tourists. The proposals may represent novel thinking. However, their enactment could spell disaster. Obviously, Antarctica's land and sea attractions are many-huge glaciers, teeming penguin rookeries, seal colonies, whales, towering ice cliffs and icebergs, and stunning white wilderness and mountain scenery. It is a truly unique part of our planet.

Surely there need be no better reason why the unspoiled continent at the base of the world should not remain untarnished by the stain of the tourist dollar. Of course, some people believe that unique and fragile ecosystems are no match for foreign currency and that endangered species of penguins are no substitute for the $20,000 per day that, it is rumoured, some wealthy tourists are prepared to pay to feast in the delight of Antarctica. These suggestions are part of an array of arguments that may hold the affirmative cause for the rape and pillage of the land of the midnight sun.

This Government must never allow this biological oasis of Antarctica, particularly at Davis base, to be plundered. Already a large ice free area near Davis has been assessed as a suitable area for an airstrip. We must be aware the developers are lobbying for part of the polar action and, in some instances, they have already convinced certain people that a sea-based tourist development is preferable to air-orientated tourism. That is because tourists and waste disposal may be better controlled.

It is shameful that whilst Australia has no biological inventory of the species in Antarctica, many sources can catalogue at least two proposals to scatter the wildlife and explode the human population by constructing tourist developments. Will we allow waste materials from a floating hotel to be dumped at sea when a major clean-up campaign of Australia's Antarctic garbage tip has just been completed? If honourable members think environmental problems that occur at the John Brewer Reef are difficult they will pale into insignificance when compared with Antarctica.

Without a doubt, any degradation of the Antarctic environment will cause untold harm. Clearly, any action on Antarctica will be expensive in monetary and environmental terms. Therefore, it is essential that the continent be protected until a correct proposal is formulated. Similarly, it is fanciful to suggest that Antarctic tourist facilities would have a strategic appeal. Certainly they would add to the impression of a permanent presence and legitimate territorial claims. However, Antarctic redevelopment must take on a new form beyond the current station rebuilding program, for unless many of the scientific projects receive increased funding there is a danger that Australia's stance in the Antarctic will be seen as nothing more than token. Maybe this proposal would be the catalyst for the construction of our very own ice breaker, a much needed piece of equipment. Hence, the siting of further floating hotels within Australian waters presents society with a number of stark value judgments that must be carefully made. Will the lure of the wealthy tourist be all pervasive? Will the muted voice of nature be heard?

The purpose of the Sea Installations Bill is not to make these complicated and loaded value judgments. Its purpose is to create the necessary legislation to control sea installations and any ships, aircraft, persons, or goods arriving at, or departing from, the installation once a decision has been made to integrate man and the watery world beyond our coastline. Once again, with the exception of Antarctica, I cannot pre-empt any decision on where floating hotels should, or should not, be installed. However, I can urge further study, careful monitoring and increased funding for a type of research that is vitally concerned with our future.

Surely to add large quantities of tourists to this unknown area would be a recipe for disaster. The nations that have bases in Antarctica have not yet collated the facts that need to be analysed to enable a true picture of the Antarctic environment to be drawn. The unknown content of one the world's largest continents must not be ignored because of the lust for tourist dollars. Hence, we must think carefully about floating hotels and holiday resorts upon the high seas. This Bill allows such caution. We must also think carefully about our marine environment, how we use it now and how we leave it for future generations. In the end, floating hotels are here to stay. I hope that the environment in which they are installed remains too. Sadly, I suspect that in an increasingly money-orientated world, the patrons of such lavishly appointed half-way houses will be the kind a travel writer described last century when he wrote:
The owl and the pussy-cat went to sea
In a beautiful pea-green boat.
They took some honey, and plenty of money
Wrapped up in a five pound note.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition gives its approval to the Sea Installation Bill, the Sea Installations Levy Bill and the Sea Installation (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill. I address a few comments particularly to the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth) who, in his very thoughtful address, pinpointed a lot of the problems that could eventuate in a pioneer venture such as this. I am sure that the aims in relation to the Great Barrier Reef and the permits that are involved in this program are regarded as being a pioneer effort and that every care will be taken.

SPEECH.PARA: The concept of a floating hotel off Townsville is the type of innovative and creative vision which is characteristic of the best in Australia's tourism industry and which has made this legislation necessary. All Australians should be doing all they can to provide the incentive and to encourage developments such as this to take advantage of our diverse, unique landscape and seascape. Next year it will be some 200 years since Australia was settled and while this has taken place on land, it is as though those 200 years have meant nothing as far as the discovery of the sea and the reefs around Australia are concerned. It is almost as if Captain Cook could come back to the islands he sailed around in the 1770s and remark that the human race has found out very little about what exists in the sea. The honourable member for Dunkley quite correctly drew the attention of all Australians to the nature of this project and this legislation.

At present resorts built beyond the three-mile territorial sea of Australia, but still within the outer limits of the Australian fishing zone, would not be subject to State or Federal laws. This package of legislation ensures that sea installations outside the territorial seas are made subject to Australian law. The legislation requires that permits will be needed and that a levy will be imposed. It also prevents the evasion of Australian laws, such as those relating to customs and taxation, by requiring contact and entry to off-shore installations to be made from within Australian territorial jurisdiction. It provides within the maximum levy of up to 20 per cent of the capital cost of construction or of the annual gross income, whichever is the larger, potential licensing as a casino. The honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) has already mentioned that this legislation must be very sensitive to how permits are distributed so far as casinos are concerned. Queensland law guarantees to the licensee that no other licences will be permitted within a certain area.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you mean the Prime Minister's friends and that sort of business?

—I would hope so but I can assure the honourable member that the people who are involved in this project are very politically naive in that regard. I understand that the levy takes the place of local government rates-I hope that is understood-and other fees that will be forgone because of its being outside the control of State or local authorities. At this stage the legislation will affect only Barrier Reef Holdings' proposed floating hotel. However, further developments are expected around Australia outside the territorial seas. The legislation will ensure that a sea installation such as the proposed floating hotel will make the Barrier Reef more accessible to tourists without threatening the reef's delicate ecosystem. The $40m Four Seasons Barrier Reef Hotel, which has been constructed in a shipyard in Singapore, will be towed to its location in a lagoon of the John Brewer Reef about 72 kilometres from Townsville. Like the previous speaker, the honourable member for Dunkley, I have also had occasion to visit Brewer Reef, but that was some 35 years ago on a boat that was so slow it took three or four hours to get there. I recall that the sea was so rough on the way that I wished I could die, and on the way back the sea was so rough that I wished I was dead. It just goes to show that in the space of 35 years we have been able to develop transport which will make such a facility available to tourists so quickly, as if it were just another tourist destination.

SPEECH.PARA: It is planned to open the hotel on 1 December this year. The resort will allow a greater number of people to enjoy the Barrier Reef from a unique position upon a world class floating hotel. It is yet another investment in north Queensland, one of Australia's most popular tourist destinations. The hotel will have seven storeys and 200 bedrooms of an international first class standard. The main feature of the hotel is the fact that people will be able to stay out on the reef for lengthy periods. Facilities in the hotel will include a restaurant, nightclub, wine cellar, conference facilities, swimming pool, gymnasium, tennis courts, sauna, speciality shops, a submarine and a helipad. It has been designed to withstand the most severe weather conditions, and under extreme conditions evacuation will occur under procedures to be approved by the Marine Park Authority. The hotel is the first of its kind to be allowed by the Federal Government to be positioned on the Great Barrier Reef, and it represents further growth in Australia's tourist and leisure industry. Already there has been interest from overseas since promotional campaigns in the United States and Europe have commenced.

These types of developments will have far reaching effects for the Australian tourism industry, and for north Queensland in particular. In fact, I know the accountant who was initially responsible for the financial studies into this venture, and have followed him through the venture.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who was that?
—Trevor Butler, from a firm of chartered accountants. He is a very good accountant, too.
—A great north Queenslander.
—Yes, he is a good north Queenslander. The fact that he was a partner of mine at one stage is quite incidental.
—He won't hold that against you.

—No, I hope he will not. He was a very good accountant and, apart from that, he has the vision that many north Queenslanders possess, and have to possess, to develop the type of ventures that will capture the imagination not only of the rest of Australia but of the rest of the world. The project reflects the innovation, the imagination and the risk that Australian entrepreneurs are prepared to exhibit, and demonstrates that people are still prepared to pioneer in the exciting new world of north Queensland tourism. The Boeing commercial aircraft company's report on Queensland tourism reflects the glowing prospects of north Queensland and northern Australia. The report said that by 1990 Queensland would have 45 per cent of total inbound international tourism to Australia, and by 1995 north Queensland would have 40 per cent of that market. It is expected that by 1990 Queensland will have more than one million overseas visitors, and that figure is expected to reach 1.5 million by the year 2000, when Queensland will have 47 per cent of all international visitors to Australia. This will mean that by the year 2000 north Queensland could have around 20 per cent of Australia's international tourism. This reflects the need for the type of developments we are talking about.

SPEECH.PARA: The economic benefits of a north Queensland boom in international tourism will help redress Australia's balance of payments. The balance of payments deficit to the September quarter was $1.35 billion, and our foreign debt to June 1987 was about $110 billion. These figures demonstrate that there are still deep-set structural problems with Australia's current account as a result of the present Government's policies. One benefit of the devaluation of the Australian dollar is that it has increased Australia's popularity as an international tourist destination. In this context the development of the floating hotel must be considered an exciting project and of major benefit to all Australians. There will also be employment benefits, not only from increased international tourism but also from increased interstate and intrastate tourism.

This legislation provides the mechanisms for regulation and control while also taking into account environmental matters. The resort has been subjected to environmental assessment by the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority, and I am delighted to see that the Federal Government has started to recognise the fact that progress and development in the form of a floating hotel can co-exist with the Barrier Reef without resulting in detrimental consequences for the environment. Not only that, but also the establishment of the floating hotel will enable a much wider appreciation of the reef and will provide a base for marine research. A marine research laboratory will be established on the resort for research purposes, as well as to monitor the hotel to ensure it does not affect the reef itself.

The development of the resort is a major step in technology and tourism ideas generally. A recent report puts private research in Australia at a much lower level than public research, so this research provided by Barrier Reef Holdings will be a great bipartisan effort with the Australian Institute of Marine Science (AIMS), as well as the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority, governments and civilians. While talking about AIMS, I mention particularly the work of the Institute's Dr Joe Baker, who comes from Townsville, and the manner in which he has endeavoured to bring to the attention of all Australians the necessity to know what the sea, the reef and the surrounding waters of Australia contain as far as our future is concerned. The honourable member for Dunkley put forward constructive criticism in relation to several aspects of this development, and those matters are all part and parcel of the work of the dedicated professional. Australia gains a lot by having him work in AIMS and in conjunction with projects such as this.

The concept for the floating hotel originated from technology developed by the off-shore oil industry, such as that used for the Bass Strait rigs. I had an opportunity only last year to visit and inspect one of those rigs. A single buoy system will be used to moor the hotel, similar to the design used to moor supertankers when loading off-shore oil. The floating hotel will be fully self-contained and self-supporting. It will have its own desalination system and its sewerage and waste water plants will be of a standard the same as or better than those of other marine facilities around the world. Again one can only say that the research that has gone into this has provided technology that will be vital to Australia in the future. The benefits from this will be that there will be no direct pollution of the waters of the Barrier Reef. Waste will be off-loaded regularly on to a service barge. The company, in conjunction with the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority, has developed a comprehensive resort management plan which will include strict controls on activities to ensure that the environmental impact of operating the resort is minimised.

The smooth passage of this legislation will enable a regulatory system to be established in time for the resort to open and other proposals of this type to be considered. There has been an increased interest in recent years in establishing sea installations such as floating hotels off the coast of Australia and elsewhere and, as has already been suggested in this debate, an Antarctic resort is also at the planning stage. The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mr John Brown) has given his full approval and endorsement of that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that is on ice.

—It is on ice; it is being held under control. The legislation also covers Antarctica and areas adjacent to the Heard and Macdonald islands. Some installations will be made exempt from the legislation, such as platforms used for petroleum exploration, as they are already subject to sufficient regulation. Commercial fishing and pearling operations, navigational aids and historic shipwrecks will also be exempted.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia has tourist attractions which are far superior and have much more to offer than many popular destinations elsewhere in the world. However, our ability to cater to this standard has been somewhat lacking. I draw the attention of the House to an Australian Associated Press report of only yesterday, which indicates that the standard of Australia's facilities was attacked by Japanese tourist operators at the Australia-Japan Business Co-operation Committee conference in Perth. It was suggested that Japanese tour operators would take over some duty free and souvenir outlets and tourist resorts to ensure that Japanese tourists received the best of service. The Chairman of the Japan Travel Bureau was particularly critical of Australia's hotels and the lack of Australians who spoke Japanese. He said that hotels located inconveniently did not suit the requirements of Japanese travellers, who expected the best and were willing to pay for it. He went on to say that in Australia there is a lack of first class facilities generally.

That is interesting because in the gallery today we saw quite a number of Japanese tourists, and one often wonders what satisfaction they are getting from their visit here. Those comments only reiterate the need for people in the tourist areas catering particularly to the Japanese tourist trade to take Japanese as a second language and provide for those visitors as much as possible. It is all very well to say that we must maintain the uniqueness of Australia's characteristics and the resources that are available-and let us hope that that is what the tourists come to expect when they visit our country-but we must also put ourselves in their shoes and make sure that we ensure, to the best of our ability, that their requirements are taken care of. In my own city of Mackay a lady called Hilda McLean has recently set up Japanese teaching facilities and interpretation services for those who might require them. That is the type of facility we must try to offer. The major source of tourists to the resort on Brewer Reef is expected to be Japan. One hopes that the new facilities of the standard of the Four Seasons Barrier Reef Hotel in north Queensland will prevent bad publicity. Again, it is in the hands of the entrepreneurs.

The Managing Director of Barrier Reef Holdings, Malcolm Clyde, has also been quoted in the papers as criticising the corporate finance sector for having difficulty in coming to terms with such an innovative concept. Apparently, the finance sector cannot come to grips with this novel type of security. He said that the corporate finance sector's grasp of tourism lagged a long way behind developments in industry ideas generally. Tourism particularly requires innovation and risk, and the service sector must keep in step with these methods if we are to develop Australia and north Queensland as an attractive and exciting tourist destination. As the financial industry in Australia has been deregulated, let us hope that that sector can keep in step with the potential that Australia offers to the rest of the world.

We should not take for granted that our tourism boom will continue and that world tourists will naturally be attracted to Australia. While Australia is fortunate to have a natural wonder like the Barrier Reef, anything we can do to develop its tourist potential, without damaging the reef's natural attributes, should be considered. It is time that we looked into more unique concepts such as the Four Seasons Barrier Reef Hotel and the newly developed Great Barrier Reef Wonderland Aquarium in Townsville to attract the tourist dollar. I wish to quote from a speech by Dr Graham Saunders, Director of the Queensland National Parks and Wildlife Service, given at the Northern Australia Development Council meeting in Bundaberg last week. He said:

Since World Heritage Listing of the Great Barrier Reef . . . and the resultant promotion of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park we are being inundated by individuals and groups who wish to exploit its resources ahead of all others, getting their own slice be it whole islands, leases of parts of island national parks and even floating hotels on the reef itself.
So he even gave the floating hotel a mention. He continued:

I should stress the fact the Commonwealth's Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority is one of the few highly successful Commonwealth/State co-operative exercises ever undertaken-both at the political and bureaucratic levels. Day to day management is carried out by Queensland National Parks and Wildlife Service officers on behalf of the Authority. There is no duplication of expenditure as responsibilities are clearly defined and accepted.
The boundaries of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park are fixed over its length of 2000 kilometres.

Queensland has its area defined. It has sovereign rights over its terrestrial resources and over its defined offshore resources of tidal lands and tidal waters along some 7400 kilometres of coastline.
In the wet tropical rainforests region, the Queensland Government is clearly the responsible land and resource management authority.

What it comes down to is that, with some co-operation, great things can be achieved, as they have been in this regard. The Chairman of Barrier Reef Holdings, Mr Doug Anthony, not only was a visionary leader of the National Party, and a visionary Deputy Prime Minister, but also he now leads the way in new concepts for the tourist industry. His vision, dedication and commitment when in politics has now been carried on to work in the tourist industry. His company will be one of the few Australian listed companies to offer a direct investment in tourism. Although I have no pecuniary interest in the venture, I have a vested interest in projects that will provide benefits for northern Australians and all Australians. It is tremendous that these Australians who form Barrier Reef Holdings have such faith in not only Australia but, in particular, the part of Australia I like, north Queensland.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sharp Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek the indulgence of the House to make a short announcement. A few moments ago I returned from the Australian Institute of Sport where I was privileged to witness a national record set by our men's relay swimming team. The members of that team set the record in the short circuit 4 x 100m event. On behalf of every member of the House, I wish to congratulate the team members at the Australian Institute of Sport. I am sure that they will go on from this event to represent Australia at the Olympic Games and I am quite sure they will win a gold medal.
—Did they train in Townsville?

—They may well have trained in Townsville. I specifically address myself to the Sea Installations Levy Bill 1987. As shadow Minister for sport and tourism, I point out that the Bill deals specifically with the tourist industry. The reasons honourable members are present today is to pass legislation that will ensure that a tourist facility will be able to operate some 72 kilometres from Townsville off the Great Barrier Reef. I congratulate the company which has been the driving influence behind the establishment of this floating hotel. Reef Link Resort Pty Ltd is the firm that has carried out this work. It is setting up for the first time in our history almost an experimental operation, which I think will lead the way in the future to similar operations around our coastline.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to congratulate not only the company but also the Government on the sensible way in which they have dealt with this matter. The Government has tackled some very difficult problems and it has to consider the issue of the environment. There has been a great deal of concern from conservationists about the establishment of floating hotels on the Great Barrier Reef. All the concerns about the environment have been addressed not only by Reef Link but also by the Government. I thank those concerned because by addressing the matter sensibly we are laying the groundwork for the establishment of an additional feature in our tourist industry.

The creation of a floating hotel is a magnificent concept. This is the first of its type but it will also be a feature which Australia will be able to publicise overseas as an added attraction for our tourist industry. As I have said, it is an experimental exercise and therefore nobody can be sure that the whole operation will be profitable. Therefore, it is important that the Government consider the charges and fees to be levied on organisations such as Reef Link which will operate this floating hotel.

A number of additional costs are associated with the operation of a floating hotel. For example, the operators will have to make their own fresh water. A desalination plant will be installed in the floating hotel project. The process of converting salt water to fresh water is very expensive. Not only has water to be made but also electricity has to be generated. Once again, this is a cost over and above those which normal hotel operators on the mainland have to deal with. The sewage treatment system is an additional problem for the operators and again is an expensive exercise. There is further expense in that the staff who operate the hotel must be flown the 70-odd kilometres each day in a helicopter or taken out in vessels. All these additional costs will mean that those who run the hotel in its first few years must be careful to ensure that it will be a viable and profitable operation.

After seeing those additional costs, I believe that there is no great financial gain from having a floating hotel as opposed to having a hotel on the mainland. I have heard it said that because it is cheaper to build a floating hotel than a hotel on the mainland, the Government should establish charges on the floating hotel proprietors so that there is not some excessive advantage in having a floating hotel. From the points that I have made today, it can be seen that the additional running expenses remove much of the advantage of having a cheaper floating hotel built.

Bearing in mind all these considerations, I was very surprised to see that in this Bill the Government has outlined what it will charge as a levy for the hotel operators. The Bill indicates that a levy will be imposed upon the hotel or installation operators which will be either up to 20 per cent of the market value of the installation or 20 per cent of the gross revenue of that installation, whichever is the higher. A levy of 20 per cent of the market value of the installation each year could work out to be of the order of $7m a year. While I am sure that the Government will not charge up to the 20 per cent limit, I would say that what we are setting in place here is the potential for future governments to set charges for that levy up to the 20 per cent and, as I said, 20 per cent could be $7m a year. I have just done a few calculations. If the hotel had an average occupancy rate of 70 per cent, and in the first few years that would be a fairly optimistic occupancy rate, and if the price per room were to be around $150, and I would say that that was not a bad guess, total revenue from room sales for the hotel would be around $7.6m a year. The potential maximum levy could be up to $7m a year, so obviously the economics of that are not too good.

The Government must be very aware of the viability of this operation. It cannot, in any way, move towards charging hotel operators anything like 20 per cent of the market value of the operation or of the gross revenue. If it does, it will kill this enterprise off in one fell swoop. It will not only kill off this operation but also will put a hurdle in front of any similar developments that may be considered by any other business operators in this country. When they look at the potential charges that could be levied upon them by governments, they will say, `This is just horrific; it is just too much and we will not go ahead with this type of operation'. The important point which I wish to drive home to the Government today is that this levy cannot ever be taken up to its maximum. It should never be taken up to its maximum because if it is this project will be finished off and a major asset to our tourist attractions will be knocked out.

I wish to talk about the Sea Installations Bill, not just in terms of this hotel but also in terms of our tourist industry. This Bill presents us with an opportunity to discuss tourism because it deals with a new installation in our tourist industry. I cannot resist this opportunity. I wish to take up a point that was mentioned by the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite). I am concerned about the many Japanese tourists who will come to this floating hotel. Services in this hotel must be up to the standard that Japanese tourists expect. It is not just services in this hotel that must be up to standard. Throughout Australia we must be able to ensure that Japanese, American and European tourists receive the standard of service and sophistication that they would expect, not just in Australia but also throughout the world.

I take this opportunity to say that the shopping hours review announced by the Minister for the Arts, Sports, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mr John Brown) yesterday in the Parliament may well be nothing more than a window dressing operation unless the Government is prepared to address the real issue in the tourist industry-that is, work practices within that industry. I assure the Government that unless that issue is addressed this floating hotel and all our tourist facilities throughout Australia will not be able to capitalise on the full potential that exists in the years ahead to make dollars for Australia. I know that the potential is there for five million tourists to come from overseas. If we do not attack the issue of work practices within the tourist industry we will not capitalise on that potential. If we do not address the issue of levies and charges on operations such as floating hotels, I am afraid that we will not realise the full potential that the tourist industry offers for Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duncan The Hon P.

TALKER.NAME: Mr DUNCAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to conclude the debate on the Sea Installations Bill and cognate Bills by thanking everyone who involved himself in this discussion for the constructive way in which the contributions were made. With the support and co- operation of everyone in the Parliament, this Bill will lead to improvements which should mean that in this aspect of the government of the nation we are able to have a very effective set of regulations to ensure that the hopes expressed by honourable members can be met. I look forward to the Bill passing this Parliament quickly and coming into effect so that some of its proposals, which have been dealt with by honourable members in the debate tonight, can come to fruition. I note in passing the number of proposals that exist in various areas around the nation which will be affected by the legislation and if half of those referred to this evening come to fruition, it augurs well for this country's tourist industry.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duncan The Hon P.

TALKER.NAME: Mr DUNCAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 4, page 2, after the definition of `affected Territory' insert the following definition:
`` `aircraft' means a machine or apparatus that can derive support in the atmosphere from the reactions from the air or from buoyancy;''.
(2) Clause 40, page 21, lines 23 to 26, omit subsection (1), substitute the following subsection:

``40. (1) Subject to this Part, the Minister may, on his or her own motion or on an application made by a person under section 41, give a certificate that a specified sea installation may be installed at a specified location in an adjacent area without a permit.''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Each of these Bills relating to sea installations was debated in a slightly different form in this place on 5 May 1987. The Bills lapsed on the dissolution of the House of Representatives and are now being reintroduced. I spoke at length on these Bills when they were debated previously so I do not intend to repeat the statements I put forward on that occasion.

SPEECH.PARA: However, I wish to make a brief comment on the Sea Installations Levy Bill 1987. Clause 6 of that Bill provides for a levy to be paid by a permit holder in relation to the operation of a sea installation. The levy has been designed to meet the administrative costs of the States and Territories in the application and enforcement of the relevant laws and regulations applying to the operation of the sea installation. The rate of levy to be imposed is expressed as a percentage of the valuation of the sea installation. The valuation of the installation will be calculated annually in accordance with the valuation practice adopted by valuers of the Australian Taxation Office. Their valuation may be reviewed on application to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

I have some concern in respect of clause 8 (3) of the Sea Installations Levy Bill. This clause provides for a maximum annual levy of 20 per cent of the market value of the sea installation. There is no doubt that if the maximum levy were to be applied it would render unviable the economic operation of the sea installation. I cannot understand why the clause has been phrased in this way. I know that the Government intends that the levy should have regard to State taxes and local government charges for the relevant activities provided by government. The concept of the levy is designed to avoid duplication by the Commonwealth of the State taxing and charging laws that ordinarily would apply if the operation were land-based. I am informed that the Government intends that the levy should approximate such costs as would normally be levied on a land-based project.

This clause has caused concern to the owners of the proposed seven-storey Four Seasons Barrier Reef Hotel, which is to be located on John Brewer Reef about 73 milimetres north-east of Townsville. The 200-bedroom floating hotel has been constructed in Singapore and will be in place on John Brewer Reef in November 1987. The concept of a floating accommodation facility, as has been said by previous speakers, is well proven, having been introduced by the off-shore oil industry in the mid-1970s. The floating hotel is a further development of this concept to provide luxury standards of accommodation. It will be approximately 90 metres long by 27 metres wide and is designed to accommodate up to 426 guests. I am certain that this hotel will, in time, constitute one of Australia's great tourist attractions. The hotel will accept its first paying guests on 1 February 1988.

I believe that most honourable members would be opposed to the construction of additional floating hotels on the Great Barrier Reef.
