As the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) indicated, a naval review of floating hotels along the Great Barrier Reef would be a disaster. The Government must be resolute. It must make it clear that only one floating hotel will be permitted on Australia's Great Barrier Reef. The honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp) advocated other sea installations similar to floating hotels. I would support that suggestion as long as it did not apply to the Great Barrier Reef.

I applaud the speech made by the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth) during this debate about the sacred trust put in this Government to preserve, protect and defend the integrity of the biggest and greatest living creature on this planet, the Great Barrier Reef. Notwithstanding the fact that all environmental impact studies required by the Government have been carried out by Barrier Reef Hotels Ltd and that this new facility will give us one of the best known tourist attractions in Australia in the years to come, I reaffirm my earlier suggestion that it would be a tragedy if the Minister, this Government or any future government were to permit any additional floating hotels on the Great Barrier Reef.

I take this opportunity to record the outstanding contribution of Mr Trevor Butler, referred to by the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite), and Mr Kel Griffith towards the development of this fantastic facility. Above all, I would like to record the gratitude of the people of north Queensland to the former Minister for Arts, Heritage and the Environment, the honourable member for Robertson (Mr Cohen). His efforts in convincing the Government, guiding this legislation through and, on a ministerial basis, his assistance to many people associated with this wonderful project will earn for him the enduring gratitude of the people of north Queensland. He has ensured that the new facility of the floating hotel at the John Brewer Reef will be environmentally compatible with the Barrier Reef. It will not only provide accommodation but also it will serve the interests of science in the investigation of the marine environment.

Finally, once again I stress the fact that most honourable members, whilst appreciating that accommodation facilities such as a floating hotel may be compatible with other off-shore areas in Australia, believe that only one should be permitted on the Great Barrier Reef. This Government and future governments should be diligent in protecting the Great Barrier Reef from the intrusion of other floating hotels.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sharp Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay) on his remarks. The point he made was a point I had made in relation to concern about the viability of the operation if the 20 per cent maximum were ever applied. I appreciate that the Government is saying that the figure is absolutely and utterly a maximum and that there is no likelihood at this stage of the maximum ever being applied. But I make the point that we are setting in place the potential for that to happen. It has to be inscribed in concrete here in the Parliament and in the eyes of this Government and future governments that it is never the intention of this House to see that 20 per cent maximum reached. The whole purpose of the levy is just to cover the cost of local government, State government or even Federal government services that may be provided for the floating hotel.

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps in a wiser moment it would have been better to have written into the legislation a provision for the costs of the various tiers of government to be totted up each year and the bill sent to the hotel proprietors rather than the way it has been written into the legislation today. At any rate, the Opposition supports this legislation on the basis that the operation will not be made unviable, that it will not be taken up to the 20 per cent maximum. If it does, it will kill off a unique and an attractive addition to Australia's tourist industry, to the economy of Townsville in the electorate of the honourable member for Herbert. It will certainly be a great addition to our tourism industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duncan The Hon P.

TALKER.NAME: Mr DUNCAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate the sentiments raised by the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay) and the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp). I am advised that, if anything, the maximum has been put into the legislation to calm fears that might exist in the industry that the originally drafted proposal which did not have a maximum might have led to excessive levies. It is a maximum and it will be seen as such. I assure the honourable member for Herbert and the honourable member for Gilmore that the Government, in administering the levy, will be sensitive, not only to the comments that are being made by honourable members this afternoon, but also to the needs of local projects in particular areas.

SPEECH.PARA: If a need for an amendment is seen, in some time to come, the Government will certainly bring back this matter to Parliament. I stress that this is new legislation. It is experimental legislation to that extent. As such we are sailing into what I might describe as uncharted waters. In light of that I give honourable members an assurance that we will be sensitive to the sorts of concerns that have been raised.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mr W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of this Committee is to consider two amendments proposed by the Government for consideration. We support those amendments as we support the original legislation, as I mentioned when opening this debate. I thank the Minister for the comments he made a moment ago about the levy. Considerable concern has been expressed about this matter by honourable members on both sides of the chamber, by the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp), the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite), and the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay). One cannot walk away from the point about viability which was made by the honourable member for Gilmore. There is now a change in the legislation. It differs from the original legislation that was proposed because of a decision by the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills to insert a clause providing for a maximum levy of 20 per cent. I would, however, point out to the honourable member for Herbert that to suggest that there ought to be only one floating hotel on the Barrier Reef might be a little bit much to ask. The Barrier Reef covers an exceedingly large area. A future Minister will perhaps be put in the position of at least having to consider issuing other permits for similar installations. I share the concern of the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) about there being eventually a whole string of them. We have in this Bill vested discretion in the Minister and we hope that he will exercise it sensibly.
—The whole environmental movement will be opposed to it.

—I have talked in some detail about the environment. One of the things I mentioned is the concern than many of us have about the crown-of-thorns starfish. If they are not kept under review and if research does not continue, they will play havoc with the reef, and all the tourists who are going out there to see the beauty of one of the world's major environmental assets will be faced with not much to see. I made a plea earlier that the two Ministers concerned make sure that they make a commitment as soon as possible, as has been asked for by the Director of the Australian Institute of Marine Science in Townsville, Dr Baker, when he was in Canberra this week for the Senate Estimates committee hearing. I hope that those on the other side of the chamber will join with me in pushing the Government to make a decision on that.

SPEECH.PARA: I return to the two amendments. The first amendment relates to a definition section within the Sea Installations Bill concerning the definition of aircraft. It is unfortunate that the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mr John Brown) is not here. He has deputed the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support (Mr Duncan), who I understand does have some role within that portfolio relating to sea activities. The point I want to make is that the definition of `aircraft' reads:
. . . means a machine or apparatus that can derive support in the atmosphere from the reactions from the air or from buoyancy.

Quite clearly, it is referring to airships. But if we go to the Federal Airports Corporation Act 1986 an Act which the Minister at the table now has ministerial responsibility for, we will see that there the definition of `aircraft' is quite different. It leaves out the words `apparatus' and `buoyancy'. I would have thought that the definition would need to be the same, so perhaps someone ought to spend a little time ensuring that an aircraft is an aircraft for the purposes of both Acts, and that it is described in the same way. I do not think we ought to start off with having separate Acts of this Parliament with different definitions of aircraft, because that will lead to confusion. We know what lawyers are like; I am one myself, and we can find all sorts of reasons to argue. In the basic definition, we ought at least to have consistency in the legislation.

It is interesting that that definition has been put in and that now aircraft, so defined, will be subject to the Act, and that it brings in airships. As I said earlier with the furore about radio licences-and this is another area in which the Minister at the table has some interest-if radio licences are not awarded to those currently seeking them, will they go off-shore and set up pirate-type stations, which we have seen in Europe? We would need to have a much closer look at that. But the thought occurs to me that someone could anchor an airship out there and broadcast radio signals into Queensland. The mind boggles, but perhaps we ought to give some consideration to that. I wonder why this definition has been put in the Act and why this amendment has been made at such a late stage.

The second amendment will permit exemptions from the legislation to be made by the Minister, whether or not an application for exemption has been made. The proposed change will simplify the operation of the provision, so that individuals will not be put to the trouble of applying where this is unnecessary to achieve the desired result, and the understandings Australia has with Antarctic Treaty countries can be pursued effectively.

We have heard a lot this afternoon about the importance of Antarctica from both sides of the chamber. Many of us are very concerned about what is happening in Antarctica. We all know that the 1959 treaty is coming to an end after 30 years, and it needs to be renegotiated. Our presence in Antarctica is extremely important, given that we claim so much of that continent. I think it is important that when this Bill came forward on the first occasion, the then Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, who was very enthusiastic about his job, made mention of the fact that these floating hotels may be set up in Antarctica. Several of us from both sides of the chamber have expressed caution about that proposal. There needs to be a lot more thought put into it. We do not want to do anything in Antarctica, as we move into those very sensitive treaty negotiations, to jeopardise our position. There are many issues with regard to the sensitive ecosystems that must be considered, the minerals regime and the scientific program that must be considered. All this is happening at a time when we have seen the Department of Science abolished after 15 years. We have a Minister for Science and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones), whose Department is not responsible for this area. The responsibility for Antarctica now falls under the Minister with responsibility for the environment.

This amendment at least recognises the significance of Antarctica. I think the Government has thought about it afterwards. Obviously there has been some discussion within the Government to see that this amendment is made. It is reasonably significant, not for the amendment itself, but for the fact that it recognises the importance of Antarctica. I hope that is a first step from the Government towards recognising that we still have a long way to go, and very little time to get there, in terms of convincing the rest of the world that we are very serious about what we want to do in Antarctica now and in the future. Once the new treaty system is renegotiated, we will then again be sitting, I imagine, for a 30-year period.

There was some discussion about Antarctica being made a world park. Before we rush headlong into that, we need to look very carefully at the matter. The honourable member for Mayo spoke quite eloquently about the difficulties and problems of that from a foreign affairs point of view, and I think we need to be sensitive about those issues.

The Opposition supports both amendments, as we do the Bill. We are pleased that it is going through. It is a significant Bill. It is one that I think will be looked at very carefully over the years as Australia's off-shore areas are developed in terms of tourist and other potential that perhaps we are not currently aware of. But the Bill certainly is significant and we support it wholeheartedly, with the reservations that have been expressed by the many speakers here, particularly with regard to the levy. I think this issue was raised by the States. They pointed out that the development of off-shore installations for commercial purposes should not be done at the expense of the mainland economy. The Government has had a bit of a change of mind, as I mentioned, and has put a maximum there. We hope that it will be a maximum. We do not want in any way to put detriments in the way of the viability of economic activity in this country, especially in the tourism industry, which all of us, from both sides of the chamber, know is particularly important to us. With those few remarks, I think we can gladly see this Bill go forward with those amendments included.
Amendments agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments; report-by leave-adopted.

DEBATE.TITLE: SALES TAX (EXEMPTIONS AND CLASSIFICATIONS) AMENDMENT BILL 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 23 September, on motion by Mr Holding:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aldred Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill 1987 seeks to make a number of amendments to the sales tax laws. Included in the amendments are exemptions from sales tax for certain tourist publicity and tourism promotional materials acquired by overseas national tourist organisations, certain television transmitters operating in the ultra high frequency (UHF) band that are purchased after 30 April 1987 and before 1 January 1993 for use in regional areas, and certain items to give effect to the proposed Status of Forces Agreement between Australia and Singapore. This Bill further seeks to remove anomalies currently existing between the sales tax law and customs and excise laws in relation to vice-regal exemptions. Finally, it seeks to make minor amendments in consequence of amendments of the customs laws.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn, firstly, to the matter of tourist publicity and promotional materials. I note that the cost to Consolidated Revenue of the proposed exemption, as provided by the inclusion of a new item, item 72b, is estimated to be between $50,000 and $100,000 in a full year, commencing in 1987-88. Of course, Australia is obliged, under the international tourism policy agreement adopted by the Council of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development in November of 1985, to provide freedom from import duties and taxes in respect of certain tourist advertising materials supplied by other member countries. The exemption in this legislation is a fulfilment of that obligation.

It is heartening in this instance to see that the Government has taken steps to see that local industry will not be greatly disadvantaged by taxation laws that favour imported items by applying the sales tax exemption to locally manufactured goods as well. This will help leave open the opportunity for production orders for the Australian printing industry, an industry that has been particularly heavily battered in recent years by the high costs that this Government has imposed upon manufacturers generally. It is these high costs that have forced so much printing off shore, with subsequent business closures and job losses being acutely felt back here in Australia.

I turn to the next matter dealt with by the Bill relating to UHF transmitters. For too long country audiences have suffered a dearth of choice in electronic entertainment and information dissemination. As the Government has said, the exemption as it relates to UHF transmitters is an incentive to licensees to fulfil the Government's policy objectives, sooner than prescribed, of introducing new commercial television and radio services to country areas. The estimated cost to Consolidated Revenue over the period that the exemption is in force is $14.5m in June 1987 prices. Whilst this is not an inconsiderable sum, we on this side of the House believe it to be money well spent, although frankly we remain unconvinced that transmission of television on the UHF band rather than on the very high frequency (VHF) band is the most desirable option. There is some technical data available to support the proposition that the VHF band provides for greater ease of reception than does the UHF band. However, the doubtful technical choice the Government has made for the UHF band is not sufficient cause for the Opposition to oppose this aspect of the Bill. We accept it, with reservations about the quality of the technical decision.

I turn now to the matter of the Status of Forces Agreement with Singapore. The Opposition welcomes the decision to provide certain sales tax exemptions in accordance with the proposed Status of Forces Agreement between Australia and Singapore. The exemptions, which mirror those provided under Australia's status of forces agreements with the United States of America and Papua New Guinea, can only operate to strengthen the already good relations that exist between Australia and Singapore. Good relations with our near neighbours are a vitally important factor in ensuring not only our own future security but also that the future security and stability of our geographic region is enhanced.

There is much more that remains to be done by the Government in strengthening Australia's relations with the other countries in our region. However, the exemptions provided under the proposed Status of Forces Agreement with Singapore are a step forward. It is a positive legislative action that will enhance the goodwill towards Australia of the limited number of Singapore military personnel who attend the Royal Military College Duntroon, the Staff College at Queenscliff and other training courses, plus those who on exchange schemes take up various staff postings in Canberra and elsewhere. It is a pity that this Government has not been more positive about its other military and diplomatic responsibilities to this region, and thus played some part in preventing the calamitous crises now besetting several island states in the Pacific area.

I turn next to the matter of vice-regal exemptions. The Opposition recognises that the decision on the vice-regal sales tax exemptions is simply to remove anomalies currently existing. The similar provisions that previously existed in the customs and excise laws have now been amended by the Customs Tariff Amendment Act 1986 and the Excise Tariff Amendment Act 1986, which removed the allowable exemptions. This Bill will therefore bring the sales tax law into line with the customs and excise laws in this area by removing the existing sales tax exemptions available in respect of articles for the personal use of the Governor-General, a State governor, their family members and staff. In the view of the Opposition this legislative rationalisation is a reasonable course of action. Let me briefly comment on the matter of consequential amendments. Following changes to the customs laws, the Opposition acknowledges that certain sections of the legislation now contain incorrect references. We therefore have no objection to the technical corrections to the sales tax laws made in this Bill.

In conclusion, it is worth noting that sales tax realised a total of $6,348m, or $394.60 per head, in the financial year 1986-87. In the financial year 1987-88, it is estimated that revenue from sales tax will increase to $7,110m, or $440.10 per head. This is an increase in revenue of $762m, or $45.50 per head. Sales tax, like every other tax, is a major growth area for this Government. Small business continues to be stifled under the onerous burden of high taxation. Australian families, especially the single income families, are suffering now as never before. Whilst we on this side of the House reject the Government's overall taxation policies, we do not oppose the purposes of this Bill.
Sitting suspended from 6.29 to 8 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill should be welcomed by any person interested in tax, especially when it is appreciated that the Government is exempting further categories of goods from sales tax. Most people would join with me in saying that no one likes paying tax. But we have to understand that if governments are to provide the facilities, the amenities and the services that people need and demand, they must have revenue. The choices are limited. They have to earn that money, have it given to them, which does not happen very often, borrow it or take it from the people, the taxpayers. The Hawke Labor Government has repeatedly reviewed the tax system, especially in the income tax area and also in the sales tax area over the last 4 1/2 years.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been a simplification of the tax system. We now have three levels of tax: a 10 per cent level, a 20 per cent level and a 30 per cent level. There has been an effort to bring some sanity into the tax system. I believe that this Hawke Government has adopted the idea that the user should pay but has moderated that principle with the ability to pay. Exemptions have increased. The amount of tax applying to certain products has been varied. In some cases it has been increased and in other cases it has been lowered.

There is also the principle that the more expensive item should attract the higher tax. This is certainly true of the luxury products. One would expect that the people who are buying these luxury items would have more money. Therefore, the principle of the ability to pay applies, yet it still means that the user is paying. Likewise, those who are able to pay should do so. However, those who are working for a charitable cause or for some organisation that is performing a community role in hospitals and so on should have exemptions. This is the policy, the principle, pursued not only by this government but also by previous governments. Yet for all this, there are still anomalies. Whilst I welcome the amendments that have been brought forward, I urge the Minister Assisting the Treasurer (Mr Holding) to consider the anomalies I am about to raise. I refer specifically to senior citizen's organisations in comparison with pensioner leagues. The Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act allows senior citizens to be exempted from sales tax, but the pensioners in pensioner leagues are not. The same is true for police youth clubs in Queensland. They can buy goods exempt of sales tax, but the scouting movement cannot. We have another anomaly whereby certain purchases by charitable and community groups are sales tax exempt if those goods are gifted or donated. But if the same organisation uses the same type of product for its own purpose, be it a charitable purpose, sales tax still applies. I will develop this point.

It does not matter whether the organisation is a non-profit one. It does not matter whether the organisation is carrying out or pursuing a charitable purpose; if it uses the product for its own purposes tax must apply. I give full credit to this Government for the courageous way it has tackled the taxation system, for the simplification it has introduced, for the streamlining, but I suggest that there are still some loopholes and there are still some anomalies. Why should a senior citizens organisation be sales tax exempt but not a pensioners league? I ask the House to make a comparison. Senior citizens draw their membership from all walks of life: the rich and the not so rich; the semi-employed and even the employer. So if we start to question the idea of the ability to pay we must start to wonder whether the membership of senior citizens organisations is in the limited ability to pay group. I do not want to take away that exemption but I want to argue for the pensioners leagues.

In contrast, the pensioners leagues, by their own rules, can attract to their membership only those persons on the pension, be they aged or be they invalid. They are not able to get anyone who walks in. They can have honorary membership and they do this for community leaders, politicians and so on. But the actual voting membership, those who run the organisations, are people who are aged, invalid and on a pension. In other words, they are in the low income bracket. They have a lower capacity to pay, yet regardless of the fact that they are non-profit organisations, regardless of the fact that they are promoting the needs of the pensioners, of low income groups in our society, they do not have sales tax exemption.

Apparently, the problem is not so much what the organisations do; it is what they say they do in their objectives and in their constitutions. I have checked the Act and I find that there are many exemptions. To get this type of sales tax exemption it seems that an organisation, in the categories of which I am talking, would have to be a public benevolent group or institution. That is under section 80 of the Act. I suggest that it should not be what they say they are; it should be what they do. There are 1.4 million pensioners in Australia. The pensioner leagues do a mighty job not only for their half a million members, who are the paid up members, but for all pensioners.

As I said, I do not want to take away any tax advantage that the senior citizen groups have, but I argue for the rights of pensioners. As the pensioner leagues have similar roles and a similar purpose, as they are more for the aged and for the less privileged and as they have a massive task in raising funds because many of their people are very elderly-many are infirm-they do not have the money to spend to raise enormous amounts of money to pay for their services. They have to draw from their own membership by way of donations, raffles and so on. We need to look at the present rules. As I have written to the Treasurer (Mr Keating), the constitutional objectives are different. To change the constitutions and the objectives of all these leagues would be a very expensive exercise. I ask the Treasurer and the Ministers involved to take a broader look at the Act and apply a broader interpretation. I suggest that an amendment is necessary.

As I have said before, a similar problem besets the scouting movement. It was to be reviewed, but to my knowledge there has been no change. It is difficult to understand why the scouting movement should not be sales tax exempt when organisations such as the police youth clubs are. If we are going to make the comparison, both are working for youth, both are broadly community based, both are non-profit, both depend very much on volunteers, families, parents and community people-although I point out that the police youth clubs usually are supported financially by the police departments throughout the nation and therefore have another advantage-and they both carry a very important role in the development of personal values, in the self- esteem of individuals and the enhancement of skills. Yet we do not seem to be able to break through. This is anomalous and there needs to be a review.

Another anomaly is that clubs carrying out a charitable purpose can get sales tax exemption if they donate the item, but if they use it for themselves or for a charitable purpose sales tax must apply. As an example, my own Rockhampton Community Service Club, which has raised something like $1.5m since it began 14 years ago, is an incorporated body under Queensland law. It is registered as a charitable organisation under the Queensland Charitable Funds Acts. It is also registered under the Art Unions and Amusements Act to allow it to raise funds. It has the legal right-it is the only one outside groups such as the Heart Foundation of Australia that has-to conduct door to door appeals. It is bound by rigid and very strict auditing rules by the Attorney-General in Queensland. If it buys something for itself to carry out its purposes, its objectives, in a charitable community manner it does not get sales tax exemption, but if it purchases something and gives it away it gets that exemption. I appreciate that governments must have taxes, but I question whether the application of that tax on such community groups is proper. I suggest that there needs to be a review.

I want to refer also to an issue that may not at first seem to be within the terms of the Bill, but I intend to prove that it is. I refer to low alcohol beer. For a long time there has been an ongoing campaign to change the drinking habits of Australians. This Government-I give it full credit-has initiated a campaign across the nation to try to do that. The Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett), through a number of organisations, has appropriated $1.4m which we hope, over a period, will turn around people's drinking habits-I suppose to get them to drink less but, importantly, to take away the social and other consequences of the abuse of alcohol.

I praise that campaign. The Government deserves full credit for bringing forward a massive amount of money when times are difficult. But I suggest that the target should be very clearly low alcohol beer. The objective should be to encourage drinkers to switch to low alcohol beers. About 8 per cent of the total beer consumption in our nation is of the low alcohol variety. I think that is pathetic. In fact, it is quite frightening in some ways. I refer to the variety of beers of 2.2 per cent alcohol or less. One might well ask why consumption is so low. I have seen tests carried out-and hoteliers have proven this-that show that after a person has had three or four beers one could almost bet the person anything that he could not tell whether he was drinking a 5.6 or a 2.2 beer.

A question of attitude is involved. A lot of fellows think that they should drink only the heavy beer. But mostly it comes back to the pocket; it comes back to price. The real issue is not the alcoholic content but the price of the beer. One could ask: why should anyone pay the same price for 0.9, 1.5, 2.2 or whatever as one pays for the heavy beers? Regrettably, hoteliers do not pass on the very small price difference at the wholesale price level. The breweries are to blame for this because they are not providing enough price difference between the low alcohol beers and the heavies. The hoteliers of Queensland, particularly central Queensland, want a nationwide campaign to change drinking habits, to get people to drink low alcohol beers. We have had the support of the Federated Liquor and Allied Industries Employees Union and we have had some indication of support from others in the brewery industry. But this campaign will be successful only-and this is where I come to the relevance of my comments-if governments, breweries and the hotel industry combine and work together to bring about that contrast in price.

The Government draws considerable revenue from beer. It has, for instance, an excise duty of 70c plus per litre on all alcoholic beverages of between 1.15 per cent and 3.8 per cent alcohol content. The excise then rises from the 70-odd cents to a figure of over 80c a litre-I am not sure of the exact figure; it has just been increased-for beer above the 3.8 per cent alcohol content. Below that level of 1.15 per cent that I mentioned there is no excise duty but there is a sales tax of 20 per cent. I would not suggest that we remove the sales tax because I believe that that would be totally unfair and would create some problems.

The Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) joined me in Brisbane when we met with hotelier groups and also union representatives to discuss this issue. No one suggests that we suddenly exempt beer from sales tax when fruit juices, soft drinks and other such beverages attract sales tax. But what we suggest is that in the first instance we change the levels of alcoholic content at which sales tax is attracted. At the moment the cut-off point is 1.15. So beer with an alcohol content of between zero and 1.15 per cent attracts no excise but has a sales tax. If we are to create that contrast in price to give an incentive for people to drink the low alcohol beer, the sales tax application has to be changed. Instead of applying only to beers of up to 1.15 per cent content it has to apply to beers of up to at least 2.2 per cent.

So on the one hand we have to remove the excise and on the other we have to allow the sales tax to apply. If that happened and if the breweries came to the party and were prepared to cut their profits, which are massive-we talked about them in terms of hundreds of millions of dollars-I believe we could achieve that difference and create a 10c per glass incentive for the drinker to take up drinking low alcohol beer.

Madam Speaker, as you would appreciate, there would be a cost to government. There would be a loss in excise duty. But I suggest that that could be made up in part-I suggest most of it-by an increase in the sales tax application. But the advantages may not be able to be measured in money terms. What would be the advantages to the Australian community in road safety terms? What would be the advantages in terms of having to spend less money on hospital care and on trying to combat alcohol abuse? We are talking about multi-million dollar campaigns and multi-million dollar appropriations to meet this social need. In respect of road safety, I do not know what the cost is for having to repair just the cars let alone the people who are the victims of accidents that occur because someone has abused drink and then got behind the wheel.

I put it to this chamber that there are many advantages if we can move to more sensible drinking. From a sheer monetary point of view, I suggest that there could be greater income for government because hotels could sell more beer of a low alcohol variety. This could mean more jobs in the hotel industry, which means more pay as you earn tax, so the Government would gain on that. Of course, if a greater amount of beer is sold there would be higher taxes on the profits of hoteliers. But, more importantly, there would be better community drinking habits. So, to achieve this, we need to rethink the revenue base in the alcohol area. As this is an issue involving sales tax, I suggest that we have to rethink the application of sales tax on alcoholic beverages.

There is surely a need for investigation. We do not know the full effect on government revenue. But I suggest to honourable members that the full effect on the community would be amazing. If we could get people to drink a low alcohol beverage it could be something that changes our society. Therefore, I say to the Treasurer and those other Ministers who are involved in these matters: congratulations on spending the $1.4m on this changing of drinking habits campaign, but let us use that money in what I believe would be a more positive way; that is, to lower the tax structure on low alcohol beer so that people would change their drinking habits.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps I could serve both this chamber and the listening audience well, without reflecting unkindly on my friend the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright), if I were to draw both your attention, Madam Speaker, and that of the listening audience to the Bill before the House and currently being debated in this chamber-the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill. The Bill seeks to make a number of amendments to the sales tax laws. Included in the amendments are exemptions from sales tax of three categories of items: first, certain tourist publicity and tourist promotional material acquired by overseas national tourist organisations; secondly, certain television transmitters operating in the ultra high frequency (UHF) band that are purchased after 30 April 1987 and before 1 January 1993 for use in regional areas; and, thirdly, certain items to give effect to the proposed status of forces agreement between Australia and Singapore. Also the Bill seeks to remove anomalies currently existing between the sales tax law and the customs and excise laws in relation to vice-regal exemptions and to make some minor amendments in consequence of amendments to the customs law.

SPEECH.PARA: My colleague the honourable member for Bruce (Mr Aldred) has already drawn the attention of the House to the impact of these amendments and the legislation currently before the House. I would like to address two areas that directly affect rural Australia. The first of those areas, and the principal one, is that of the exemption for certain television transmitters operating in the ultra high frequency band that are purchased after 30 April and before 1 January for use in regional areas. The vast majority of Australians who live in part of the eastern seaboard, or on any seaboard in Australia, have no idea of the remoteness of central Australia. Given the speculative nature of many of the programs we watch we may well say to colleagues in central Australia, `Well, what are you missing out on?'.

We need to appreciate the fact that they are denied not only the variety of television programs that we take for granted and the variety of radio programs and, in some cases, the opportunity of listening to Federal Parliament but also the daily newspaper that lands on our doorstep and keeps us familiar with what is going on in the world. For them there is no theatre. Their entertainment is largely the entertainment they generate themselves by travelling vast distances to inter-station functions of a social nature, to sporting functions that may be organised by schools or to the gymkhanas which are so much a part of the way of life in central Australia. The comforts, the entertainment and the variety that we take for granted are denied to them.

The Government has chosen, at a cost to revenue of $14.5m, to provide an incentive that will encourage people to erect television transmitters in central Australia and enable them to have the program variety that we take for granted. While the Opposition questions the wisdom of the Government choosing the ultra-high frequency band rather than the very high frequency band, it does not oppose any of the four areas of sales tax affected by the legislation before the House. We question the Government's motive in making the $14.5m available to increase the opportunity of central Australians, remote area Australians, to receive television programs. That motive is not necessarily the recognition of the need of remote area Australians, rather it is an incentive to allow the Government to fulfil its policy objectives to licensees within a prescribed period.

We welcome the fact that remote country areas will have new commercial television and radio services. While we imagine that remote country areas are, in some way, close to Ayers Rock, there are a number of poor television reception areas close to the seaboards of this nation. Even in my area, which encompasses the Barossa Valley, there are places known to the Minister at the table, the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support (Mr Duncan), such as the township of Angaston that have poor television reception simply because they are located within a particular range in the Barossa Valley. People within 100 kilometres or so of the city of Adelaide have had to take snowy television for granted and they too will have improved television if they avail themselves of the sales tax exemption that will encourage better transmission facilities.

I make these points because there has been too little recognition of the disadvantage that Australians in remote areas face. I point out that although this Bill provides some incentive and makes $14.5m available to improve the transmission of television in remote areas, nonetheless the Budget recently handed down by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) imposed some burdens on the people in remote areas of Australia. Take, for example, the fuel freight subsidy scheme. The threshold on the price of petrol was lifted from 6c per litre to 10c per litre before the fuel freight subsidy came into play. That disadvantage was carried particularly by people in remote areas. An excise on fuel that goes up every six months is a disadvantage principally carried by Australians in remote areas because they are mainly the people who use fuel. People living in remote areas of Australia cheerfully accept the discomforts that go with being in an isolated place; they cheerfully accept the hardships of drought, and they are entitled to this gesture from the Government which will provide them with some immediate relief.

The honourable member for Bruce addressed two other areas of the legislation before the House-the exemption for tourist publicity and the vice-regal exemptions. I briefly turn honourable members' attention to one other area and that is the exemption that gives effect to the proposed status of forces agreement between Australia and Singapore. This is a gesture of goodwill to those Singaporeans who are coming into Australia and it brings them into parity with forces from the United States of America and Papua New Guinea that are on our shores. It is an exercise in good relations with our near neighbours and we in the Opposition commend the Government for it.

Singaporean armed forces personnel posted principally to Duntroon and Queenscliff and to staff postings in Canberra and elsewhere will now be able to avail themselves of the same sales tax exemptions that exist for service personnel from Papua New Guinea and the United States. It is both timely and ironical that this week we should be discussing these provisions, that this week we should be extending an olive branch to the armed forces of Singapore who come to us, while we see in other parts of the community sand being kicked in the faces of our allies from America who currently man the Pine Gap facility. In making that statement I am not criticising the Government. I simply wish that a few more voices had been raised this week in defence of the Americans and what they are doing for us at Pine Gap.

I note with pleasure that in the Senate yesterday both Government and Opposition speakers rose in defence of what the Americans are currently doing in the joint defence facility at Pine Gap. I quote briefly from a speech by Senator Chaney:

. . . the great mass of Australians who support the cause of peace and nuclear disarmament, but who believe that both peace and nuclear disarmament require in the short and immediate term the maintenance of effective deterrence. They believe that in the longer term the capacity to achieve genuine disarmament and, hence, genuine peace should be on a phased, mutual and verified basis. These are the simple conditions which are supported by the Government, by the Opposition and by the great mass of the people of Australia.

We propose to ensure that Singaporean forces serving in Australia are given precisely the same sales tax advantages as are forces from the United States of America and Papua New Guinea. I am anxious that we restate that it is not our intention to ensure that Singaporean forces are treated in precisely the same way as are forces from the United States because I believe that we could have been much more welcoming of our American colleagues than were some members of this Parliament-principally in the other chamber-this week. I was a little affronted to hear a story from a colleague of mine about a friend of his from America who was hitch-hiking around Australia with cloth badges sewn on to his knapsack. This week those badges were ripped off his knapsack in a gesture against Pine Gap. This legislation has little to do with the Pine Gap facility but it has a great deal to do with the way in which we treat the Singaporean forces. The intention of this legislation is to bring them into line with the tax situation currently faced by forces from Papua New Guinea and the United States of America. I hope that we will welcome our American friends as we do our Singaporean friends.

Madam Speaker, I close by referring to some remarks made by the honourable member for Capricornia, who drew your attention to what he rightly saw as inequitable sales tax treatment of low alcohol beers. I simply say that the record of this Government in the taxation area in total has been a sorry one. This Government's tax take has been at a record all time high. The honourable member for Capricornia referred to the impact of sales tax and excises on low alcohol beers. I draw the attention of the House to the impact of sales tax on both wine and citrus fruit juices. I concede that the legislation before the House is a genuine effort to redress four areas to which the Government has felt it appropriate to apply an exemption from sales tax. Those areas are the tourist publicity area, the vice-regal exemptions area, the exemption for television transmitters in remote areas and an opportunity to ensure that armed forces from Singapore are treated in a manner parallel to that currently available to the armed forces from the United States of America and Papua New Guinea. While the Opposition has some reservations about the detail of the legislation before the House, it has no intention of opposing it.
