DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN NATIONAL RAILWAYS COMMISSION AMENDMENT BILL 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 18 September.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duncan The Hon P.

TALKER.NAME: Mr DUNCAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

It is now some 3 1/2 years since the introduction of legislation to provide the Australian National Railways Commission, or AN, with a charter which gave it the task of becoming a commercially oriented business operation. In the previous year, AN had recorded its highest ever loss, of $106m. Since then, AN has made considerable progress. This progress reflects this Government's approach of creating an environment in which its business authorities can get on with the job of improving their performance. In real terms AN's call on the Federal Budget has been reduced by over 60 per cent during this period. It is a record in which everyone associated with AN-the Chairman, commissioners, AN management, unions and the AN work force-can take justifiable pride. But we cannot stop there. Accordingly this Government is continuing to work with AN and its staff to maintain that momentum which will lead AN to become a genuinely commercially viable government railway.

As part of this continuing drive for improved efficiency, on 1 October 1986 the former Minister for Transport, the present Minister for Resources (Mr Peter Morris), announced a package of further initiatives including a new approach to AN's passenger services. The fact is that, like those of virtually every railway in the world, AN's passenger services are not currently commercially viable. However, with operational and marketing initiatives their future prospects can be improved. While AN's performance is better than that of many of the other Australian rail systems, particularly for its long distance services, there is room to achieve greater efficiency. The Government and AN are embarking upon the demanding approach of upgrading these services rather than allowing them to drift into a state where they are beyond redemption. We have agreed with AN a set of increasing cost recovery targets to be achieved in respect of these passenger services. From a level of around 45 per cent in 1984-85, AN now has the task of improving its passenger cost recovery level to a 60 per cent target by 1988-89.
AN has already launched a number of major initiatives to provide better, more efficient services to its customers. These include:
Upgrading the Mount Gambier service with improved transit times and on-board service, which has resulted in a 15 per cent increase in patronage;

The launching in 1986 of a new Adelaide-Whyalla Budd car service which replaced the Adelaide-Port Pirie service. This service, know as the Iron Triangle Limited, is currently running at almost full capacity;
The diversion of the Indian Pacific into Adelaide in 1986 without adding to the total journey time;
The launching of a new service, known as the Silver City Limited, between Adelaide and Broken Hill in December 1986; and
The launching of a conference car on the Ghan to cater for business functions.

AN considers that it should further extend the facilities it provides to its passengers to make train travel a far more enjoyable experience in itself. Accordingly it has refurbished rolling-stock to provide a special entertainment car, offering facilities such as video and sound booths, video games for children, tables for cards and chess, a souvenir shop, a hair salon, and a limited number of poker machines. To provide a clear legislative base for these activities it is necessary for the amendments contained in clause 3 of this Bill to be enacted. AN has consulted both the South Australian and Northern Territory governments on the proposal and both governments have raised no objections.

The second amendment incorporated in the Bill will preserve the existing workers compensation entitlements for AN employees who were transferred from the South Australian Railways in 1978. A condition of the transfer was that these employees would have the option of claiming compensation benefits under either the South Australian or Federal provisions. This was embodied in section 47 of the Australian National Railways Commission Act 1983. However, the existing South Australian Act is to be repealed on 1 October 1987. This means those employees would lose their right to claim compensation under South Australian law. In view of the Government's commitments at the time of transfer, it is only proper that the Government should continue to honour those commitments. This amendment will ensure that the right to choose between the current South Australian provisions and Federal provisions is maintained.

The third provision of the Bill will amend section 70 of the Act to expand the powers under which boards of inquiry undertake investigations into the causes of accidents involving AN. Two boards of inquiry have been established under the Act. They have proven to be extremely valuable in having an independent body examine major accidents. It is considered that future inquiries would benefit by having wider powers to allow them to consider the broader causes of accidents. The proposed powers are similar to provisions governing accident inquiries under the Air Navigation Regulations. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beale Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support (Mr Duncan) for making available to me a copy of his second reading speech on the Australian National Railways Commission Amendment Bill. The Opposition does not oppose the legislation. It will not oppose propositions which will improve the operational capability of those statutory authorities which remain under the control of the Government and which rely to a great extent upon the goodwill, as well as the managerial expertise, of the government of the day in order to bolster their services to the community.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill before the House is presented in three parts. The first part deals with the provision by the Australian National Railways Commission, trading as Australian National, or AN, of entertainment, including some limited gambling facilities, on its passenger services. The third part of the legislation will effectively extend the ability of the Commission to investigate rail accidents which involve Australian National through affording greater powers to any commissions of inquiry which may be established to look into such accidents. Both of these amendments are very similar to amendments included in a Bill which was before this House in the earlier part of the year and which the Opposition did not oppose.

The second part of the Bill, which was not included in the earlier Bill, seeks to maintain the existing right of employees of Australian National who were transferred to Australian National under the Railways Agreement (South Australia) Act 1975 to elect to claim workers compensation under either the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act 1971 or the provisions of the Workers Compensation Act 1971 of South Australia after the latter Act is repealed as of 4 p.m. on 30 September this year. I understand that the Minister has prepared an amendment to the Bill to ensure that those employees presently covered by the South Australian Act will not be not covered, as it were, when the South Australian Act is repealed as of 4 p.m. on 30 September and before the relevant section of this Bill is due to come into force-midnight on 1 October 1987. It is pleasing that the Minister's Department has picked up this discrepancy with the South Australian legislation. However, I would have thought that the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support, a former Attorney-General for the State of South Australia, could have been expected to have the inside running on ensuring that these two complementary pieces of legislation dovetailed neatly to ensure that the employees of Australian National covered by the soon to be repealed South Australian legislation would not be left in a sort of limbo should they injure themselves between the time that the South Australian legislation is repealed at 4 p.m. and the time when this legislation comes into effect at midnight.

It is always difficult to understand what goes on within the factions of the Australian Labor Party and perhaps the reason that the Minister did not have the inside running is that he is a member of the left wing of the Labor Party and the Labor Government in South Australia is more moderate in its views. This amendment to the Act has not been before this House before today and, as a result, deserves rather closer scrutiny than the other sections of the legislation, even though my colleague Senator Watson has quite rightly raised some questions which the Opposition has concerning the numbers and types of gambling entertainment to be provided on Australian National services, to which I shall refer in a moment.

Employees who are eligible to make a choice of opting for the Commonwealth workers compensation provisions or the provisions of the South Australian Act, which is soon to be repealed, are those who were transferred from South Australia's non-metropolitan railways to Australian National and who have continuous service from 1 March 1978. As of 4 o'clock on 30 September the South Australian Workers Compensation Act 1971 will be repealed by the South Australian Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1987. The amendment before the House will continue the right of eligible employees to have access to the provisions of the South Australian Act. I mention in passing that the proposed legislation to come before the South Australian Parliament is the South Australian equivalent of similar legislation in Victoria, which is labelled WorkCare. I warn the South Australian Government that the WorkCare experiment in Victoria has been disastrous; its liability in a few short years has blown out to billions of dollars. On a number of occasions the Victorian Government has acknowledged that the Work-care program is unworkable. The Victorian Government has made a series of amendments to the legislation to try to bring the costs of Workcare under control. If the South Australian Government is not careful, it will end up with its equivalent Workcare legislation in the sort of shambles in which the Victorian Government has found itself on this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have a good Minister looking after that in South Australia.

—Then the honourable member can take a message to his good Minister in South Australia. He can tell that good Minister that if he implements a Workcare program in the same way as the Victorian Minister did, he will not be a good Minister any more. He will be a very bad Minister.
—Order! I remind the honourable member that we are debating legislation within this chamber, not in the State chamber.

—Thank you, Madam Deputy Speaker. I was reacting to an interjection from the honourable member who referred to a good Minister in South Australia. I was giving him some advice so that his good Minister can stay that way. The explanatory memorandum accompanying the Bill says that it has no financial implications. Having been briefed by officers in the Minister's Department, for which I thank the Minister, I can appreciate how the complicated arrangements will work. Perhaps the only financial implication will be in additional administrative costs. I understand that the number of ex-South Australian employees eligible for this workers compensation provision is constantly decreasing and does not amount to nearly the number that it did a few years ago.

SPEECH.PARA: Turning to the other amendments which I referred to earlier as parts 1 and 3 embodied in the Bill, I point out that they have been before this House on another occasion in a similar, if not identical, state. The performance of Australian National has improved significantly since its restructuring under a Liberal-National Party Government. The amendments dealing with providing an entertainment car for some of the Australian National passenger services is a further step along the line for Australian National to become a truly commercially oriented company, capable of drawing passengers and other businesses in its own right, rather than relying on any monopoly that it may have on the transport of particular goods to certain places.

Having said that, it is still imperative that Australian National, in co-operation with the Government, continue that drive to be more commercial, more competitive and more attractive as a form of transport. I note that, like all other Australian transport industries involved with the carriage of passengers, there is considerable scope for improvement so as to take advantage of the recent rapid growth in international tourism to Australia. The Ghan railway service operated by Australian National between Adelaide and Alice Springs is one of the great train journeys of the world, and I believe that in the expansion of the tourist industry this is something on which Australian National will be able to build in the future. Australian National's performance in carrying passengers is like that of all other railways in Australia, as recognised by the Inter-State Commission's report on cost recovery arrangements for interstate land transport-that is, the worst performing sector of its operations. It is to be hoped that Australian National is doing all it can within its present charter to improve that situation as it relates to the potential of increased tourism.

I believe that the amendment before the House today dealing with the addition of an entertainment car is a step in that direction and I commend Australian National for its initiative. It is to be regretted that Australian National does not have the car operating now. The Government's behaviour in calling an early election, which meant that the previous Bill lapsed, has resulted in a delay in the passage of these amendments. Australian National can blame this Government for the delay in the addition of appropriate facilities for this car and Australian National, in common with the people in the rest of Australia, are fed up with the Government calling elections. Three elections in four years is far too many. Although the rail entertainment car has been running on the Ghan since August, it has been without the poker machines. So far as it goes, I understand that it has been at least a modest success and that the entire operation is proving worthwhile. The passage of this amendment today allowing gambling facilities on Australian National trains will further improve the attractiveness of the Ghan and other trains that Australian National may eventually decide to run with entertainment cars. However, as I said at the outset, the Opposition has some reservations about the operation of gambling facilities, although I think that the Minister in responding to this debate may be able to allay our fears in this respect.

One problem that we envisage is access to the poker machines. If they are to be all together in one car along with video games, sound booths and so on, one wonders who will regulate the use of these poker machines by minors. It is conceivable that this could involve more staff, and I would welcome the Minister's comments on this matter when he replies to the debate.

Another question that arises with the amendment of gambling facilities is that the provision of such facilities is not limited to train carriages; it is also applicable to premises owned or occupied by the Commission. Again, I seek the Minister's assurance that nothing will be done by the Commission, no matter how much it might improve its performance, which would compromise the positions of the States in relation to their laws on gambling. I would welcome the Minister's assurance on that matter at the end of this debate. I am sure that his Department has discussed this with its State counterparts to ensure that there will be no difficulties in this regard but the appropriate commitment from the Minister on the record would be worth while.

The amendment concerning the extension of the powers of commissions of inquiry into accidents involving Australian National is a sensible step which the Opposition supports. Australian National has improved its financial performance over the past five years or so, but I stress that it is still imperative that it does not rest on its laurels. Compared with other forms of transport, especially road transport, Australian National-and, indeed, this applies to all railways-is not as efficient or productive as it could be. Having said that, I should put on the record that Australian National is the leading railway in Australia in terms of financial performance, presentation of accounts and willingness to improve its image and performance. I contrast here some facts and figures in comparing Australian National with the State railways to highlight the fact that while the Commonwealth is trying to put its business enterprises at least in the right frame of mind, if not always in the proper financial state to move towards something resembling a commercial operation, New South Wales and Victoria are among those States not doing anything meaningful to improve the shambles that pass for their rail systems.

I highlight the fact that the Commonwealth is not doing everything it can to put its enterprises in the proper financial state and refer briefly to its treatment of Australian Airlines and Qantas Airways Ltd. Qantas needs some $400m over the next five years to re-equip its fleet and remain competitive internationally. Australian Airlines also needs some hundreds of millions of dollars in what will become a deregulated airline environment so that it can remain competitive. I stress again, as I have done on a number of occasions over the past few weeks, that the only way that the Government will be able to solve the financial difficulties associated with Qantas and Australian Airlines is to convert part or all of the ownership of those statutory bodies from the public sector to the private sector. The coalition parties have been pushing the Government for some time to privatise Australian Airlines by transferring 100 per cent ownership of the shares from the public to the private sector and to do the same with a minority interest in Qantas.

I return to the railways and refer to the shocking performance of the New South Wales and Victorian railways compared with that of Australian National and the railways of some of the other States. I wish to record that Western Australia has made progress in rationalising its operations, especially in terms of moving grain by rail supertrains. Queensland has just finished, or is in the process of finishing-and at some considerable cost-a series of improvements to its system by electrification of heavily used lines. Unfortunately, the days of bludging and rorts and entrenched inefficiency are not over with the State railways in New South Wales and Victoria. Last year alone, 44,836 working days were lost through industrial action on the Victorian railways. The work practices and non-productivity of the Victorian and New South Wales State rail systems are legendary, or perhaps more correctly, infamous.

For example, take the Melbourne-Sydney freight corridor, which is theoretically ideal for the interstate transport of freight. Although some progress has been made on this route with the introduction of super-freighters, one must ask why some 75 per cent of total freight on this route goes by road. On the Sydney-Melbourne freight run we have a situation that is ideal for rail transport, yet rail transport takes only 25 per cent of the total business. Clearly there are arguments which go backwards and forwards between the road freight, railways and shipping industries about subsidisation and cost recovery and how each industry is disadvantaged by the subsidies the others receive. However, the bottom line is really which industry can do it cheaper, more reliably and with less call on the public purse. The State railways do not do very well by any of these criteria, as is evidenced by the fact that on the Sydney-Melbourne route, which is ideal for train movements, the railways have only 25 per cent of the business, with 75 per cent being carried by road.

One only has to look for an explanation at some of the work practices. For example, on the Sydney-Melbourne trip the old coaling and water changes still take place at Goulburn, Junee and Albury-Wodonga. I believe that on the New South Wales side of the journey there is still a provision for a `call boy', whose job it is to wake up the crews. I hope that we do not need a call boy to wake up the Government on this matter. There is also the extravagance of crews being returned to their homes by taxi once their shift has finished, even though they may be very many kilometres from where they started the journey. These sorts of rorts are ridiculous in this day and age of government restraint and economic belt tightening.

I point out that transport is fundamental for our exports. This country desperately needs exports in order to bring our balance of payments under control and to try to get our exploding overseas debt under control. In this House today, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) objected to the word `exploding' to describe what is happening to Australia's overseas debt. I would have thought that `exploding' was not a bad word to describe what has happened to Australia's overseas debt. Since the Government came to power that debt has increased from $30 billion to more than $110 billion. That is exploding overseas debt. The railways are equal to the waterfront on this score. These two areas are the worst in the entire transport chain for inefficiency, which adds greatly to the final cost of every item which is transported-and that is almost everything. These sectors add tremendously to the cost of our exports and our imports and all this reflects on our competitiveness as a trading nation.

The total deficit of the railways system in Australia is approaching a shameful $3 billion. How can Australia continue to carry this sort of legacy when we are being subjected to every sort of pressure to become more efficient, more productive and more competitive in both international and domestic markets? The answer is straightforward. We simply cannot afford this sort of $3 billion bill for a party to which only the trade union movement is invited. The rest of Australia is paying for all the rorts, lurks and inefficiencies of our transport system and this country simply cannot afford that any more.

Our freight handling rates, whether for wheat, containers or whatever, do not approach the performance of countries with which the Treasurer likes to think we are equal. It is about time the Australian people, the Australian work force, and especially the Australian unions, woke up to the fact that the way we have done things in the past is now costing us dearly and that we simply cannot afford to pay for them any more. We have to improve our performance in the transport sector and we-when I say `we' I include the States and, in regard to railways, particularly New South Wales and Victoria-have to start now.

The previous Minister for Transport established targets for Australian National. He, and I assume his successor-as I understand the responsibilities in the Department of Transport and Communications it is the Minister at the table, the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support, who has the prime carriage for the performance of Australian National-want to lift the cost recovery rate on Australian National's passenger services from 45 per cent to 60 per cent by 1989. If this is achieved, it will make Australian National's passenger cost recovery superior to any of the States which are presently struggling to recover 40 per cent of costs. V/Line in Victoria, for example, has a cost recovery figure of around 25 per cent for its passenger services. Metrail hopes to get to 50 per cent within five years. The Inter-State Commission, in its landmark report on cost recovery for land transport, put the figure for interstate passenger rail services at around 37 per cent. That contrasts with Australian National's objective to lift its cost recovery rate on passenger services to 60 per cent by 1989.

The total deficit for Australian National last year was $70m. Of this, Tasrail's freight service accounted for $20m and mainland freight for another $20m. That leaves $30m for the remaining activities of Australian National. The progress made by Australian National in reducing its deficit, in both dollar terms and real terms, is especially encouraging as it operates in South Australia, which has a relatively deregulated transport market. In government, the coalition parties would intensify the process of exposure and elimination of rorts and inefficiencies in Australia's transport industries, especially the stevedoring industries and the railways. In government, the coalition parties would work harder to encourage Australian National and the State railways to increase cost recovery on passenger services.

It is imperative that this Government, despite its political affiliations with the trade union movement, use the only tool it has to get improvement in the State sectors of the total transport chain. That tool is exposure of the rorts and inefficiencies that are taking place within the transport chain. Ridicule is a great engine of change. Royal commissions, the Industries Assistance Commission, the Inter-State Commission and commissions of inquiry must be used to increase the awareness of the people of Australia that they are being ripped off by the inefficiencies in the State transport systems, particularly the State rail systems in New South Wales and Victoria.

TALK.START.PARA: —And Queensland.

—By that interjection the Minister is acknowledging the rorts and inefficiencies in the New South Wales and Victorian State railways and is adding another State to the list. I invite him to do what he can to encourage New South Wales and Victoria and, if he chooses to do so, Queensland to improve their performance in this area. The Federal Government has a responsibility to embarrass, cajole and help the States to improve their transport systems wherever possible. The days of being able to afford the sort of nonsense that we have in the Victorian and New South Wales rail systems are gone.

SPEECH.PARA: The total railway deficit in Australia has been put at up to $3 billion. We can no longer afford to ignore that scale of inefficiency, nor can we condone continuing restrictive work practices and mediocre productivity levels. Both the waterfront and the railways are an essential part of the transport chain. They must be made to become efficient. The coalition regards this legislation as helping in the efficiency development process and regards Australian National as setting the standard for railway operations in Australia. It has reduced its work force by 32 per cent and increased its productivity by 115 per cent since 1978. It must continue this drive for efficiency and must continue to take initiatives to ensure its share of the transport task. The Government must also continue to put pressure wherever it can on the States to improve their performance in the total transport area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Neil Mr L.R.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the Australian National Railways Commission Amendment Bill was introduced last year, the then shadow Minister for Transport, the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), was very constructive in his support of this Bill. He was very bipartisan indeed. He acknowledged the tremendous work that had been accomplished by the trade union movement to achieve the improvement in transport that has occurred in Australia. It is a terrible indictment of the Opposition that the new shadow Minister for Transport and Communications, the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale), has had to revert to the old days of bashing the trade union movement.

SPEECH.PARA: Any objective person would know that the reason we recovered from the diabolical economic situation in which we were left in March 1983, when the coalition lost government and left us with a deficit of $9.6 billion, the reason we recovered our footing on the economic scale, was the tremendous support of the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the trade union movement. I place on record the Government's acknowledgment of the superb support we have had from the trade union movement. We are certainly looking forward to its continuing support.

I am pleased to have the opportunity to speak today in support of the Australian National Railways Commission Amendment Bill 1987. As most honourable members would be aware, my interest in a sound future for Australian National (AN) stems from the fact that many hundreds of my constituents rely directly on AN for employment and many thousands of others rely on it indirectly for their well-being. So it is of paramount importance to me that AN be given the opportunity to continue as a major freight and passenger carrier. I am pleased to note that AN increased its freight carrying by 12.9 per cent, and its passenger revenue by 21.9 per cent, in 1985-86.

This Bill will help to improve the amenities available to passengers travelling with AN. This pleases me greatly, because it was not too many years ago that the future of passenger rail was less than assured. One of the reasons for AN's improved efficiency is its commitment to improving its plant and equipment. An example of this is the maintenance and upgrading of mainline tracks. The innovation of concrete sleepers, which are manufactured in Port Augusta, has allowed AN to resleeper 1,326 kilometres of track. Manufacture by contract of 700,000 concrete sleepers was begun in 1985-86 in Port Augusta, providing employment and a much needed economic boost to a depressed region in my electorate. These indirect benefits of AN are often overlooked. Cities such as Port Augusta and Port Pirie depend heavily on both the direct and indirect effects of AN.

The primary objective of this amending legislation is to allow AN, consistent with its charter, to act commercially to improve the financial performance of its passenger operations, through improving the quality of service provided-being innovative in the selection of activities offered to passengers-and to maintain and increase patronage. The three most famous rail passenger services in Australia, and perhaps three of the most famous in the world-the Ghan, from Adelaide to Alice Springs, the Indian Pacific, from Sydney to Adelaide to Perth, and the Trans-Australian, from Adelaide to Perth-all run through the electorate of Grey. I am reminded of that famous quote from John Cheever:
We travel by plane, oftener than not, and yet the spirit of our country seems to have remained a country of railroads.

The spirit of Grey remains very much the spirit of the railroad. In this age of high speed travel and communication, the humble railway still provides a service that is efficient and safe, both for passengers and for freight. Australia's railway network has played a major role in the development of our nation, although some would argue that the development of State railways with their different gauges did more to hinder the growth of the nation than it did to help.

The 1983 Australian National Railways Commission Bill provided a firm legislative base within which Australia's rail network would continue to play a role in the development of the nation. The Bill we are debating today will add to this legislative base and will provide Australian National with even more flexibility to compete in a business like manner.

At this point I must commend the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support, (Mr Peter Duncan) for introducing this Bill in this House. I am sure that the Minister will prove to be one of the most able and competent Ministers to serve this Parliament. As the Minister knows, there is a long-standing invitation for him to visit Grey, and I am sure that this invitation will be taken up shortly. He has a hard act to follow as the previous Minister for Transport, Peter Morris, was an extremely progressive Minister, with a dedicated vision for the transport industry in general. We backbenchers with a keen interest in the transport industry sincerely thank him for his co-operation, assistance and unstinting help in broadening our knowledge of the intricacies of the transport industry in general. We trust that he has the same success in his new portfolio.

As most honourable members would be aware, in recent years there has been a boom in the number of tourists visiting Australia from overseas. The vast majority come from Japan, the United States of America and New Zealand. They come here not only because Australia provides a relatively cheap holiday, but also because we have a country rich in natural endowments, which can be experienced in comfort and safety. People, when travelling overseas, travel for that experience, the experience of seeing new and exciting countries, and the experience of taking part in activities that they would not otherwise take part in. Australian National's railway network offers an experience which many overseas tourists take advantage of. The three great railway journeys mentioned earlier all offer an opportunity to see a part of Australia that many Australians do not see. The Ghan travels north from Adelaide to Alice Springs, within easy reach of the beauty of Uluru and the Olgas. The Indian Pacific and the Trans-Australian travel west across the Nullarbor Plain to Perth, surely a trip that is memorable for its length and the rugged beauty of much of the country.

These rail journeys offer a unique view of Australia and one which is very attractive to many overseas tourists. It is therefore pleasing to see Australian National attempting to provide a level of service and a range of activities which should help to entice foreign visitors to see Australia by rail. These facilities are, of course, aimed not only at overseas visitors, but also at Australians holidaying at home. The Bill before us today will provide Australian National with a sound legislative base to provide additional entertainment facilities on its Ghan service. A specially fitted out rail car has been operating since August, providing such things as private video and sound booths, video games for children and other services and amenities. This legislation will allow for the installation of poker machines, which will provide an added incentive for many travellers to make use of the rail system. Whilst this special rail car is initially intended for use on the Ghan service, it is hoped that its success will allow AN to provide a similar facility on many of its other rail services.

It is pleasing to see Australian National taking the initiative when confronted with the problem of competition. The completion of the sealing of the Stuart Highway has meant that many tourists now have the opportunity to drive from Adelaide to Alice Springs on a sealed road for the first time. The sealing of the Stuart Highway has opened up the north of Australia to many thousands of people, and I am pleased to say that it has had a marvellous affect on the economy of Port Augusta and northern towns such as Coober Pedy. In fact, I have received reports from many people in the north of my electorate suggesting that there are not enough motel units and caravan park spaces available for the influx of tourists. Such has been the effect of this Government's sealing of the Stuart Highway. The success of the highway, however, threatens to reduce the patronage of the Ghan service and this is why Australian National has decided to take positive steps to retain, and improve, its share of the passenger market.

Passenger train services world-wide are notable for the losses that they incur. Australian National also suffers substantial losses on the passenger services that it operates. However, it is committed to maintaining those services and also to improving its cost recovery performance for them. In 1984-85, AN recovered only 45 per cent of the costs associated with its passenger services. Its aim by 1988-89 is to recover 60 per cent of its costs. The inclusion of the new entertainment carriage on the Ghan run is one step in the direction of improving its passenger service and performance, and it is a step that should be encouraged.

The amending legislation also broadens the power of boards of inquiry, established under section 70 of the Australian National Railways Commission Act, to examine the causes, rather than just the circumstances, of accidents. These powers are consistent with provisions for accident inquiries under the Air Navigation Regulations. The two boards of inquiry which have been established under the Act have proven to be valuable, by virtue of having an independent body examine major accidents. It is considered that future inquiries would benefit from having wider powers to consider the broader causes of accidents.

When this Bill was debated earlier in the year there seemed to be universal bipartisan support for the approach taken by Australian National in its commitment to maintaining passenger services, with as little call as possible being made on the taxpayer for support. It is pleasing that Australian National has taken the step of expanding its passenger service in some areas such as the opening of the Iron Triangle Limited, which runs from Adelaide via Port Pirie and Port Augusta to Whyalla. This service has proved to be a remarkable success, due no doubt to innovative marketing, provision of an efficient regular service, and also the provision of a level of comfort and amenities in the refurbished Budd car, which makes for a very pleasant journey. This new service has been running at almost full capacity for well over 18 months, and I feel that perhaps some consideration should be given to providing a weekend service to Adelaide, perhaps departing Whyalla on the Friday evening and returning on the Sunday evening. I am sure that such a service would prove very popular with patrons in the three Iron Triangle cities, and I hope that serious consideration is given to extending the service in the future.

I am pleased that the Minister appears to be sympathetic to this and to my discussions with him. I must commend him for giving me a good hearing on the expansion of the service. It is indeed pleasing to see that Australian National is introducing a new service which has been embraced by the travelling public in the region. This is especially so when one considers that not too many years ago the whole future of passenger rail services looked very bleak indeed. However, one should not forget that the vast majority of AN's business is freight. In fact 85 per cent of its business is freight. Even with the remarkable advances made in the passenger rail services, it is freight that provides AN with its bread and butter. Australian National competes in the freight business against what many consider to be the world's most successful road transport industry. It is estimated that Australian National is now covering 90 per cent of full costs for its long distance freight services, with the aim of covering full costs by the end of 1988. This improvement has come about as a result of AN's recognising that railways are not exempt from economic realities and that they cannot expect governments to fund their ever-increasing deficits.

The rail unions have played a major role in assisting the restructuring of AN. During 1985-86 only 218 person days were lost through industrial disputes, which is the lowest level since the formation of Australian National in 1978. Added to this marvellous industrial relations record has been a dramatic increase in productivity amongst AN's employees involved in the freight side of its business activities. In fact, there has been a 115 per cent increase in output per employee engaged in freight transport since 1978-a remarkable achievement. These two figures are indeed impressive: the lowest number of days lost through industrial disputes since 1978 and the 115 per cent increase in output per employee. This is an impressive record which shows what can be achieved with the right attitude. Railway workers have accepted the challenge and they are producing the results. I am sure that honourable members from both sides of this House will agree that the record of the railway unions involved with AN has been a record worthy of credit.

The management of Australian National also deserves credit for many of the innovative approaches it has taken towards increasing its share of the market in both passenger and freight services. This Bill is an example of some of the innovative thinking aimed at improving the performance of the passenger services.

On the freight side, in 1986 Australian National introduced the super-freighter concept, which is a non-stop containerised freight express service with fixed schedules for departure and delivery times. The super-freighter concept operates only point to point between modern container terminals, with no shunting or marshalling required. This service operates between most of the major trade centres in Australia, Adelaide-Perth, Adelaide-Sydney, Adelaide-Melbourne, Sydney-Brisbane, and Melbourne-Sydney. By the end of 1986 alone, super-freighters in and out of Adelaide were carrying 7,000 tonnes of freight a week. This is only one example of innovation in the freight areas which has assisted Australian National to maintain a competitive position in the long distance freight business.

In October 1986 this Government announced a package of measures to improve further Australian National's competitiveness. This addressed passenger services, staffing initiatives, management and operating practices and revitalisation of workshops. Australian National can be proud of its record in staff relations. While its work force has declined by 3,000 or by 30 per cent since its inception, no one has yet lost his job. The entire reduction in staff has been achieved through natural attrition and voluntary early retirement, and with the minimum of industrial disruption.

Australian National has engaged in vigorous competition in the market-place; for example, its improved performance in piggy-back traffic, which includes its recently developed multimodal facilities at its Keswick barracks. This innovation was assisted by a government grant of $2.3m to improve terminal facilities and purchase high speed rolling stock. Australian National now has most of the freight traffic from Adelaide to Perth, and 95 per cent between Adelaide and Alice Springs. These initiatives have begun to turn Australian National into a more commercial organisation able to compete in the transport market-place. Let me reiterate: this has been achieved only by fully involving all parties in the process-government, management, employees and unions-and it clearly demonstrates this Government's willingness to achieve more efficient performance in all areas in the public arena. The Federal Government is committed to the continued development of a reliable and efficient national land transport system with each mode, rail and road, performing the task to which it is best suited.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Australian National Railways Commission Amendment Bill. I have to claim that I am not a great expert on the railways of Australia. I am a bit of a ring-in in this debate to fill out our numbers. But I speak in this debate with great pleasure because I have always had a bit of a passion for railways. The Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support (Mr Duncan), who is at the table, will be interested and amused to hear that I once owned my own railway-he may not be surprised to hear that-and in fact I still do own my own railway, although it sits in a box in the shed at the back of my house today.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, railway construction was part of the process of nation building in Australia, as it was in many of the New World nations. I suppose that in ways it helped to pull our infant nation together. Federation would not have been easily attainable in the late nineteenth century if it had not been for the fairly extensive network of railways that we had then. As everybody knows, railways in 1987 are no longer as important as they were in the last century, but they do remain a very visible government-owned trading enterprise, or series of trading enterprises. Also, because large quantities of national resources are still tied up in them, they do need significant thought to be given to them in the context of their role in the development of our nation.

We have a substantial asset in our railways, at both the State and national level. From time to time we have to think what we will do with that asset. It is ironic that, while in the early days of our railways the challenges that faced the management as well as the employees of our railways were engineering challenges, today the real challenges are nothing but financial. Engineers may have been the heroes of our infant railways, but today it is the accountants, the managers and others who are really behind the drive for greater efficiency. This is largely because the advance of technology has created a new competitor for railways far more than it has changed the face of the railways.

In the haulage of both freight and passengers, road transport competes fiercely and very effectively with the railways. It would be wrong to assume that this competition is not still evolving and becoming fiercer, because it most certainly is. For example-the honourable member for Grey (Mr O'Neil) referred to this-the recent completion of the sealing of the Stuart Highway between Adelaide and Alice Springs will mean that road operator costs in servicing the Alice Springs to Adelaide route will fall fairly significantly. That will be reflected in their rates, and that will put further pressure on the railways and on rail freight rates.

Rail freight is already struggling on that route between Adelaide and Alice Springs. Two years ago I was in the north of South Australia and I was surprised to find that many of the graziers who lived on the railway line were very concerned about what they regarded as the inefficiency of the Australian National Railways Commission freight service. At that time they were looking forward to the completion of the Stuart Highway so that they could use road transport instead. Of course, that presents a very real challenge to Australian National. As well as this, the increasing size of road transport vehicles, which enables them to carry larger loads at proportionately less cost, the liberalisation of permissible road transport axle loads and the widespread introduction of B-double combination vehicles are further manifestations of the fierce competition with which railways have to deal. All of these make road transport relatively more attractive compared with rail transport. The railways either have to respond to this or else see their market share continue to decline. If their market share continues to decline, they will continue to become less relevant and in the end we will have little choice but to abandon these national assets.

It is not good enough for rail managers to lamely point out, as some do, that the axle load of a 38-tonne pantechnicon is equivalent to that of about 2,200 motor cars and that the Government ought to legislate to protect roads from this sort of assault and so, incidentally, protect the position of rail transport. That approach will doom Australia to an increasingly high cost transport system that, in the long term, will destroy our ability to get products, whether they are rural produce, mineral ores or manufactured goods, on to the world markets at a competitive price. Transport is fundamentally important to Australia not just externally-we often talk about the problems with external transport-but also internally. Rail managers must accept and confront that challenge that these changing circumstances present to them. Railways either adapt to these changing circumstances or, as I have said, eventually they will be left to die. I hope that does not happen.

One of the greatest problems we have in our national rail system both at the Australian National level and in our State railways is the problem of work practices. The honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale) referred at some length to this. Those work practices grew up in an age when rail enjoyed a monopoly on freight and people had to be moved, and could only be moved, by rail. As I pointed out pretty clearly, the situation has changed and those work practices simply cannot be allowed to continue. The available evidence indicates that, although not at the State level, Australian National is making efforts to eliminate a lot of these extraordinarily expensive work practices, its expectation of full cost recovery in 1988 is proof of the fact that it has addressed, among other cost problems, work practices. It is, of course, an enormous improvement on Australian National's 1983 position when it made a record $106m loss. The fact that the State rail systems are still incurring annual total losses of a quite incredible $2.5 billion is more than a casual indication of how much remains to be done in those systems.

The problems in the State rail systems are obviously not being tackled with the same vigour that Australian National is exhibiting. It remains a problem that, to some extent, the progress Australian National is making is being held back by these underperforming State railway systems. Australian National, for example, has from time to time complained that the Brisbane to Adelaide corridor and, more specifically, the Sydney to Brisbane link, are being inhibited by the lack of proper infrastructure investment by the States. There is a series, I understand, of height restrictions, there is a lack of effective terminals provided by the States and, in some instances, there is a shortage of suitable rolling stock. Despite some co-ordination that exists through the Railways of Australia organisation, the State railway systems we have are managed quite differently from Australian National, in some cases with differences in objectives and relative priorities. In a way, that is understandable because they have to deal with the most difficult of all rail services-commuter rail services. This lack of co-ordination detracts from the ability of the railways to function as components in a national railway network. That is something that Australian National seeks to achieve. As Australian National mentioned in its September 1986 publication AN News, relatively low priority continues to be given to intersystem freight and passenger business by the other railway systems, that is, the State railway systems. For example, intermodal services to the eastern States are slow, outmoded and congested.

There are other aspects of State railways that I think are quite incoherent. The Government in my State of South Australia has undertaken a program, in the interests of the economy, of closing a number of rail services. I do not object to the fact that it is looking for increased economies; it must do that in a difficult economic climate. In any case, it is economically irrational to continue to pour hundreds of thousands of dollars-indeed, billions of dollars-of taxpayers' money into services that the communities apparently do not want. Certainly, in the case of South Australia, the State Government has given no clear criteria for its closure of railway lines. It has no sense of direction in the future of its rail policy. That creates a problem for Australian National which has to do its best to integrate with State rail systems, including the very important railway system in South Australia. I think the honourable member for Grey would agree with me that South Australia is the capital of railways in Australia.

We had an instance recently in my electorate of the closure of the Bridgewater to Belair railway. It was said that this railway was making a loss-it certainly does make a substantial loss-but we did not hear whether its loss was considerably greater or less than the loss made by other commuter railway services. All we heard was that it was going to close. Those amongst us who are perhaps not cynical but a little sceptical of the commitment of the South Australian Government would have to say that it may have been closed because it was convenient to close a railway into a Liberal held State electorate-it is also a Federal electorate-rather than arouse the wrath of Labor members of parliament. So it is important that States have coherent rail policies which integrate with a national policy and which give some direction to a community and to community priorities.

Let me return to Australian National. Part of the response of Australian National to the changed modern circumstances is to look at the services it generally provides. It is not just looking at cutting costs; it is looking at improving services. This is a very encouraging thing. It is very wise because mere concentration on costs and their containment would doom Australia's travellers to a standard of facilities that were completely incompatible with the great distances and long travel times that rail travel on the Australian National network invariably involve.

The legislation before the House not only is important but also comes out of the review by Australian National of the service it offers to travellers on its long distance passenger services. Its intention is to enable those people who travel on those services to be provided with entertainment, including gambling-rather controversial perhaps-provided passengers have travelled on, or are booked to travel on, a rail journey of more than 24 hours duration. There is some controversy about whether gambling should be allowed on a national train running through South Australia to the Northern Territory, the excellent service known as the Ghan, but I think it would be a naive person who would believe that this service actually introduced gambling to passengers. Anybody who has travelled on Australian National's excellent trains-and I like to travel on them when I can-knows that that practice exists already. One does not have to be brought up on a diet of American westerns featuring card sharps travelling that country's frontier railways and whiling away the hours between Indian attacks, playing a few hands of poker, to suspect, naturally, that on our own long train journeys some informal gambling does take place. However, this legislation will make available a wider range of those facilities. It will also provide other kinds of entertainment of perhaps a less controversial nature. That will have the obvious effect of encouraging more people who have time on their hands to travel on railways rather than to take the air trip.

It would be easy merely to focus on that aspect of the legislation, but it would be missing the real significance of what Australian National is trying to do. The real initiative on the part of Australian National is to provide its customers with an altogether higher quality of service so that train travel itself becomes part of Australian National's attraction in the market rather than just being something that has to be endured in getting from one place to another, in this case specifically from Adelaide to Alice Springs. So it is doing something to attract tourists to the rail system; perhaps one could go further and say, `attract tourists to Australia'.

Those of us who travel regularly in aeroplanes-that would be every member of this House, I would imagine, other than the honourable member for Canberra (Mrs Kelly) and perhaps the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow)-are used to the efforts the airlines make to satisfy their customers. It is perhaps a little surprising that it has taken the rail system so long to offer its own special services such as, dare I say it, gambling-we do not get that on planes yet-video booths, video games, souvenir shops, hair salons and so on. But, as I have said, it is a good thing that it has done that. These rail-liner or entertainment cars will greatly improve the attractiveness of rail travel and help to make some of the great train journeys that Australian National offers, such as on the Ghan, which I enjoyed travelling on two years ago, more memorable and, of course, of much greater interest to tourists.

I think that Australian National has in a way-very slowly, one would have to admit-learnt a lesson from the investment in modern, high speed, efficient and attractive trains that has been made by the Europeans. I refer, for example, to the famous Mistral train which runs from Paris to the south of France, to Marseilles and beyond, I think, to the town of Menton. It is a brilliant and fast train which has high quality facilities, which, as a result, attracts an enormous number of passengers and which is, rather surprisingly, one of the few railways in the world which are actually profitable. I know that the West Germans also have introduced many magnificent trains of that kind. Anybody who has been to Europe and had the opportunity to buy Eurail passes and all those sorts of things will know about the TEE network in Europe, the trans-European expresses, which are very much a part of the tourist appeal of going to Europe.

As with Australian National's vision for its railways, people do not travel by train between Paris and Rome, Paris and Milan or wherever just because they want to get from one place to the other; they travel by train because of what they can see and the facilities of the train-the enjoyment of the actual experience of going by train. So, those lessons from Europe-faster trains, trains with better facilities, good promotion of those train journeys and, of course, the wide range of fares that are offered in Europe, which is something Australian National is also picking up on-have very much been taken on board by Don Williams and his team at Australian National.

There is also a proposal around at the moment for a high speed train to run between Sydney and Melbourne, stopping at Canberra on the way. That will be of interest to the honourable member for Eden-Monaro, I am sure. This high speed train concept, I suspect, is being based on similar trains that operate in the United Kingdom where those trains are profitable, in Germany where a new high speed train is soon to be introduced, and in France where a very high speed train was introduced very recently.

The proposal in Australia is frankly, I think, a fairly heroic one. My recollection is that the investment needed will be in the vicinity of an incredible $4 billion and the operators will be looking at an annual gross return of some $500m. I think that is pretty heroic. They will need about three million passengers to make it pay. Their expectation, though, is that they can lure these passengers into the train service by making the journey between Sydney and Melbourne via Canberra extremely fast, and the cost of the travel will be about half the cost of an air fare. One of the advantages of this project-if it goes ahead-for me, as a South Australian, is that the town of Whyalla will be an enormous beneficiary. It will get about four years of continuous work simply making the rails for the new railway that would be built between Sydney and Melbourne via Canberra.

Although I think, frankly, that it is a rather heroic project and it is a little hard to see that it will actually work and be profitable, it is a great example of private sector initiative. It is interesting that it has gone to such an extensive stage of planning. I do not know whether it will go ahead or not. That is up to the people who are proposing to invest in it-and there are several companies that are proposing to do that. I only hope that the State and Federal governments, when they look at this proposal, will not stand in the way of these private sector entrepreneurs. It is a very exciting concept and if it does not become a reality in the next five or six years it may be the sort of railway we will move to in the next 20 or 30 years.

In conclusion, in the last few seconds I have, I say that this is good legislation, and I would like to congratulate particularly the General Manager of Australian National, Don Williams, on the outstanding job he has done for that railway system. It is interesting that he lives in the State of South Australia. It is probably the air, the wine and the good quality of life there which have encouraged him to do such a good job.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian National Railways Commission Amendment Bill lapsed at the end of the last Parliament because of the double dissolution. If one reads the Hansards of that debate it is evident that at the time there was a high degree of bipartisanship. I see no reason why things should be different on this occasion, although the somewhat churlish remarks of the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale) might lead one to doubt that. I would like to pay tribute to the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd). I think he always tries to make an objective contribution and on that occasion he certainly did.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill seeks, firstly, to enable Australian National (AN) to act to improve the performance of its passenger services and, secondly, to restore the previously existing workers compensation entitlements for Australian National employees who transferred from the South Australian railways in 1978. The workers compensation amendment is very straightforward and, I hope, not controversial, and I do not intend to devote any more time to it.

The amendments to allow AN to improve its passenger services performance are very sensible. I assume that the proposal to allow a limited number of poker machines is the most controversial aspect of these proposals, especially considering the high proportion of Methodists in South Australia. However, in this respect the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) is right: gambling has always taken place on these trains. I remember with great relish my brother taking several hundred pounds from some card sharps on the trans-Australia train in about 1963.

The proposal to establish a video library and viewing facilities, video games for children, tables for card and board games, a hairdressing salon and a souvenir shop are all to be applauded. I notice that, initially at least, it is intended to confine these initiatives to the Ghan running between Adelaide and Alice Springs. I hope that it will not be long before the same services are included on the trans-Australia train and the Indian Pacific. It is my view that railways in Australia would be much more efficient if we had a truly national service. Certainly, the Indian Pacific should be run by a single operator between Sydney and Perth. That single operator should be Australian National. I understand that talks are well advanced with Westrail in respect of having a single operator in South Australia and Western Australia, and I thoroughly commend this.

Fortunately, the second reading speech of the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support (Mr Duncan) opens the way for a rather more wide-ranging coverage of our rail system than otherwise would be allowed within the very narrow confines of this Bill. I applaud the initiatives of this Bill and suggest to Australian National that it also consider the employment of a recreational officer on the trains who is able to play the piano, point out places of interest and get people interacting. I also suggest that a searchlight be installed on the roof of the observation car so that people could see the abundant wildlife that exists across the Nullarbor at night time. Such a device could be mechanically limited in its traverse so that it could not shine up or down the train, and it could be controlled electrically so that it could not operate in towns or built-up areas. I also think that Australian National should consider a system whereby passengers could leave the train to explore points of interest and rejoin it on a later day or even at another point. This, I believe, would have an appeal across the Nullarbor, but I acknowledge that it is something that would need private sector participation and some consideration at a future date.

In discussing railways I think we have to decide just what we want from them. It is my belief that they have a community function that is not constrained by pure economics. This is not to say that they should provide totally uneconomic services. For instance, there are short lines that would be better serviced by road, and it is sensible to do this. People who live in remote areas such as the north-west of South Australia or across the Nullarbor Plain, however, have no other options and I believe that Australian National has an absolute obligation to service these people. I am pleased to say that I have been assured by Dr Williams, the General Manager of Australian National, that this obligation is recognised.

The cost of providing these community services should be separately identified by the rail systems, but I would prefer to see this obligation enshrined in their operational charters in a similar way to what was done with Telecom, rather than have AN rely on government handouts-for I have often said that the greatest danger facing this country is the growing dichotomy between city and rural Australia. I see evidence that we are growing apart, and if this trend continues it presents a grave danger. I do not think that we can survive as a nation with such a division and I do not believe that any political party fully comprehends this danger. I would certainly not like to put my faith in government maintaining subsidies in times of economic downturn.

The comments of the honourable member for Murray about the cost recovery figures produced by the Inter-State Commission were somewhat defective. I believe this occurred because the Inter-State Commission did not take into account the very high level of inter-system freight carried by Australian National. Had it done so, its figures would have been more comparable with those of the Bureau of Transport Economics and would have shown a cost recovery for freight carried on all Australian railways of 72 per cent rather than 66 per cent. The honourable member, in using the raw figures, did not differentiate between the various services. For instance, Westrail has achieved a cost recovery on freight of up to 119 per cent. Westrail is a success story, and I pay tribute to the previous Minister for Transport in the Western Australian Government, Mr Julian Grill, for it was he, not the management, who took the initiatives and the risks. The present Minister for Transport, Mr Gavin Troy, is very ably carrying on the good work, but I am sure that he would not deny the credit that I have given to Mr Grill.

Today Westrail and Australian National are without doubt the best rail services in Australia. They should look at amalgamating to show the nation the benefits of a truly national railway. Australian National has performed very well indeed by any criteria that we can use. It has achieved a cost recovery rate across its entire operations of 80.3 per cent. Its freight operations between Perth and the east have achieved a cost recovery rate of better than 92 per cent. I have no doubt that some honourable members opposite will draw attention to the Queensland railway system that has also achieved a good cost recovery rate and a substantial deficit reduction. However, this result was achieved by a massive cost increase and by operating in an atmosphere of total regulation.

Australian National carries over 80 per cent of all freight transported between the east and the west compared with about 15 per cent carried by rail between Sydney and Melbourne. This is interesting to note because Australian National operates in a totally deregulated environment, and has done since its inception. There are absolutely no regulations at all to prevent anyone from trucking goods to or from Perth. So Australian National has done very well indeed to have achieved this level of freight carriage.

It should also be remembered that road freight from east to west achieves only about 30 per cent cost recovery. Every six-axle truck that operates across the Nullarbor costs the Australian taxpayer $50,000 per year. One only has to see the enormous damage done to the edges of the roads by these heavy vehicles to know that these costs are a reality. It is rather amusing to hear the honourable member for Mayo say that we should not hold road transport to the same rigorous cost recovery criteria that we impose on rail. He talked blithely of the fact that it is estimated that a heavy truck does something like 2,000 times the damage to roads as do motor cars. He pretends that this does not matter. Of course it matters; it matters in the overall context of the cost to the Australian public. I see no reason why the private sector should be able to operate under more generous terms than the government sector. Of course that is the way of the Opposition-one seeks to nationalise all one's losses.

We should be looking at getting the remaining trucks that run across the Nullarbor on to the rail. I would have no hesitation in imposing a substantial toll on the Eyre Highway. This would be justified, for sooner or later we will have a truck and bus collision or even a bus and bus collision because of the deteriorating state of that highway. It must be remembered that overall in Australia there is about $1.2 billion lack of cost recovery from road transport. In other words, the road transport system in this country is costing the taxpayer $1.2 billion a year. This is more than the aggregate deficits of the Victorian and New South Wales railways. That figure should be kept in mind, but I would not in any way like that to be seen as any justification of the Victorian or New South Wales railways. I will come to that matter later. Let us look at some of the other criteria. Let us look at industrial relations.

In 1980 employment in the railways for all the States was 111,452. By 1986 this figure was down to 102,279, a job loss of 9,173. However, the losses were overwhelmingly on Australian National and the Western Australian railway system. In 1980 Westrail had 9,727 employees and in 1986 that figure had been reduced to 6,599. In 1980 Australian National had 11,756 employees and by 1986 that figure was down to 8,137. Westrail and Australian National combined shed a total of 6,747 workers or over two-thirds of all the jobs shed. This represents a massive increase in productivity and I suggest that the honourable member for Deakin would be hard pressed to find any private sector achievement of this magnitude. The large reduction in the work force was achieved with minimal industrial disputation and without any sackings as natural attrition and early retirements were the strategies used. This result is of enormous credit to both the rail systems and the unions involved.

If lack of industrial action is a measure of morale, Australian National and Westrail are on the right track. Last year, for instance, AN had the lowest level of industrial troubles since its inception in 1975-76. Another interesting aspect of the relative performance is the level of capital expenditure, for it must be remembered that if one accepts the Australian Railway Research and Development Organisation definition of deficit equals revenue less operating costs plus capital costs, then capital is a significant component of accumulated deficit. Westrail and Australian National had the lowest percentage of capital expenditure, which demonstrates that they gave more care and consideration to this matter than did the State systems. I did have quite a bit more to say but I understand one of my colleagues would also like to speak on this Bill. Therefore, I will confine my further remarks to the committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) for his consideration in concluding his remarks a little earlier than he otherwise would have. I will follow his good example in order to allow the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow) to make a contribution prior to this debate being adjourned. I rise to speak to the Australian National Railways Commission Amendment Bill, which incorporates a debate on changes to Australian National (AN). I want to make some references to Australian National that I believe have to date been overlooked in the debate that has occurred in this chamber. Those references are particularly about the changes that have occurred to rural Australia and farmers as a result of the changed structure of Australian National. The impact of farmers on the total transport facilities available to Australian National and the impact of AN on the capacity of farmers to cart their grain is enormous.

SPEECH.PARA: I draw the attention of honourable members to the simple truth that of the total production cost that any wheat farmer faces, 16 per cent is made up of transport costs. Land transport costs take up 16 per cent of the total wheat production costs facing any farmer. Of that 16 per cent, 3 per cent is road costs and 13 per cent is rail costs. In using that figure I do not in any sense belittle-quite the contrary-the role of AN in the movement of grain, particularly from silo to port. The Royal Commission into Grain Storage, Handling and Transport Discussion Paper No. 4 highlighted the fact that the role of road transport in moving grain is relatively small compared with the role of rail transport. For example, the paper states:
The distance travelled from farm to local silo ranges from an average of 8 kilometres in Victoria to 48 kilometres in Queensland.

Compare this with an average of 150 kilometres in South Australia and 500 kilometres in New South Wales, the distance travelled by rail. So rail has an enormous impact on the capacity of farmers to get their grain from the silo to the port, although obviously road transport is the major form of getting grain from the farm to the silo.

I want to refer briefly to the attempts made to cut the costs currently faced by AN. The honourable member for Grey (Mr O'Neil) and the honourable member for Kalgoorlie have referred to the cost cutting program AN has been involved in. This same cost cutting program has effectively isolated a number of rural communities from the AN rail services they once took for granted. I refer to two tiny towns in my own electorate of Wakefield, Hamley Bridge and Riverton. Both of these towns once enjoyed a regular rail service that is now denied them. Instead, those who wish to use public transport have to travel by bus to the nearest town that has a regular bus service. While the need to move from their town to the nearest sight of a bus depot causes inconvenience, I want to tell the House that I find that rural people generally accept this measure of inconvenience. They are not pleased about it, but they recognise that there is no such thing as a free lunch; they recognise that the cost overrun that was once characteristically a part of AN and is now being pruned, can be pruned only if they are denied some of the services they once took for granted. They accept that there will be changes in their communities as a result of the changed rail service; they accept that there will be instances in which railway stations will no longer be manned, and they will be obliged to leave parcels-you would be familiar with this, Mr Deputy Speaker-in stations that are unattended, to be picked up at a later date. These people accept that. But they find it more difficult to accept that there has been so little consultation between the Minister and their communities. My plea tonight is that there be additional consultation between the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support (Mr Duncan), the farmers and these rural communities in an effort to ensure that the Minister and AN are aware of the difficulties these farmers and these communities are facing.

I have referred to the royal commission set up specifically to look into the sort of disadvantages that some rural communities face, and particularly to look into what were seen as inadequacies in the rail transport system. I refer to comments made by the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer). He applauded the work done in South Australia by Don Williams and by AN generally in achieving efficiencies in rail transport. The Opposition applauds that. It simply makes the plea on behalf of what is the major part of its constituency that both the Minister and AN increase the level of consultation they have with rural communities. I thank the House for the opportunity to contribute to the debate.
