DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Australian Taxation Office-Sunshine Coast: Sewerage Outlets-Medicare-King O'Malley-Trade Union Membership Rules-Anglo American Corporation-Compulsory Unionism-Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd-Member for O'Connor-Australian War Memorial

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.15 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Over recent months many constituents, and others who are not constituents, but who are nevertheless taxpayers, have brought to my attention a series of complaints about treatment they have received at the hands of some personnel in the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) in Perth. Each of those who has felt the need to complain can be accurately described as a fairly ordinary or average pay as you earn taxpayer. It is necessary to mention that point, if only to avoid the accusation that critics of any aspect of the administration of tax laws are somehow friends of tax cheats. Indeed, there seems to be some justification for believing that there has been a complete role reversal in that the behaviour of some ATO personnel has assumed the mantle once perceived to be the sole property of those who were regarded as tax cheats.
—They have gone right overboard.

—Yes, and this extends beyond the boundaries of Western Australia, but certainly my experience is confined to that State. The extend of and possible reasons for that deplorable development will be the subject of a more detailed submission from me to the House on an appropriate future occasion. Tonight, I am content to give an example of my long held concerns by referring to a recent experience of a constituent. I can do no better-and I rarely do this-than quote verbatim a letter that awaited me when I returned to Canberra only this week. I shall not mention the writer's name because I do not have the authority of the gentleman concerned to do so. The letter reads:

SPEECH.PARA: I have not written to you before, mainly because I have not felt strongly enough about any topic of public interest to do so. I am writing in anger on the topic of tax investigations.

Like everyone else, I pay tax, 35-40% of my salary. I accept the necessity for this. I do not accept that in a democratic society, we should receive `threatening' letters from taxation bureaucrats, 3 months after our tax return, demanding documentary evidence to justify our claim for a rebate, these letters couched in terms which assume us to be guilty of fraud until we can prove our innocence! Moreover, as my study leave was a complex exercise, it took a whole week to prepare my tax return for presentation via an accountant. Three months later, it has taken me ten to twelve hours of hard work to find and organise all the documents, receipts and other pieces of paper the tax man requires to prove my innocence (he takes three pages of his missive to threaten me with dire penalties if I don't)-at a time when I am busy with several important research projects involving two important visitors from Canada and Sweden; I am also trying to prepare an important lecture on back pain for a conference in Brisbane, and have a heavy teaching load instructing medical students!!
He continues:

The tax bureaucracy requires me to present the evidence in a detailed way cross-referencing various documents for their convenience; this occupies days of my time in non-productive effort in tasks I am not trained for, and distracts me from the job I am good at, hindering my work with my distinguished guests by giving me deadlines for submission of my documented proof of innocence.
There is little point in my writing to the tax man, as he does what government tells him. What is required, in my opinion, is more respect for the rights of individuals-
Amen to that-
more respect for their integrity and less interference with or deflection from their legitimate productive work by bureaucracy gone mad!

In conclusion, I have been until now, a labor voter, on the grounds that social justice is a high ideal to be admired and supported, but there appears to be conflict between this ideal as labor sees it and individual freedom from bureaucratic restraint and intrusion. I am coming to value the latter more and more the longer the present government is in office. I seek your advice. . .
That gentleman will have my advice when I return home tomorrow, but I regret to say that I will not be able to give him favourable advice because of abuses of the type I have outlined.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lavarch Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address an issue of ecological significance which, although not glamorous like the Daintree wilderness, is of immense importance to a local community and has broader ramifications for the Australian coastline. The issue relates to the decision of the Landsborough Shire Council which proposes to construct a sewerage outlet at Kawana Waters on the Queensland Sunshine Coast.

SPEECH.PARA: For honourable members who are unfamiliar with the area, I will tell them a bit about it. The region stretches roughly 50 miles from Caloundra at its southern point to Noosa in the north. The two main industries are tourism and fishing. Tourism in particular generates millions of dollars for the local economy when each year thousands flock from cooler climes to the golden beaches and crystal waters for which the Sunshine Coast is famed. It is these same beaches and unpolluted waters that are now under threat from the prospect of an 800-metre long sewerage pipe pumping out partially treated effluent into local waters. The Landsborough Shire Council plans to go ahead with the proposal despite massive community opposition. Less than two weeks ago a demonstration of more than 400 people took place on a wet morning in a local park to voice sentiment against the outlet plan. A local community group, the Concerned Residents Acting Against Pollution, has collected 15,000 signatures condemning the project. The petition has been presented to the Queensland Parliament by the sitting National Party member for the State electorate, who also happens to be the heir apparent to the Queensland throne. In sharp contrast to the standard Queensland Government practice, there has been no move to intervene in the Council's decision.

I bring the matter to this House because it is one example of an environmental issue which affects every Australian living along a coastline. Along our eastern coastal boundary there has been established a network of sewerage discharge systems, stretching from a secondary system, emptying into the Barron River and Trinity Inlet at Cairns to one proposed at Geelong. Everyone is now familiar with the Bondi experience which has transformed a world-renowned surfing beach into an infamous home for floating colonies of human waste. The Metropolitan Water Sewerage and Drainage Board's answer to Bondi's problem is longer outfall tunnels. However, overseas experience indicates that pumping sewage further and further off-shore is not a long term solution and I believe the possibility of establishing alternative land-based systems of minimal environmental impact is a matter deserving of thorough, independent study.

The problems of outfall are obvious. First, the injurious effects on surrounding marine life; secondly, health risks, including eye, ear, nose and throat infections caused by swimming in polluted waters; and, thirdly, contamination of shellfish, which are acutely sensitive to toxic materials. The Kawana Waters outfall is planned in an area in close proximity to juvenile prawn grounds. Understandably, concern has been expressed by local fishermen that chemicals associated with the treatment, such as chlorine and ammonia, may present themselves in such quantities as to be fatal to the prawns at such a delicate stage in their life cycle. Furthermore, the outlet is proposed to be built in an established trawler fishing ground. Apart from the physical obstruction that the pipeline will present to boats and nets, there will most likely be strong public reaction against seafood caught in local waters for fear of contamination. Hence the Landsborough Shire Council's proposal should be questioned because of the destructive environmental impact that such a discharge system poses to marine life. Equally, the resultant downgrading of the area's allure as a tourist destination will translate into further economic loss to the region.

I call on the Landsborough Shire Council to undertake a thorough cost-benefit analysis of the alternative land-based systems as I am advised by local residents that the assessment already made did not comprehensively canvass the range of different systems available. An unspoilt environment is fast becoming a rare and precious resource and it is therefore of vital importance that such resources be safeguarded, particularly when they are coupled with the spectacular geographic beauty that the Queensland Sunshine Coast has to offer. Such an environment is an investment in all our futures and we must take care not to allow its value to be diminished by ill-considered bargain hunting planning propositions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McArthur Mr F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not only is the Hawke Government raising the Medicare levy from one per cent to 1.25 per cent for families with a total income over $15,090 and single earners with incomes over $8,980, but also it plans to decrease its service to those Australians who have private health insurance cover. It claims that this will save $1.5m in a full year. Twelve regional Medicare agencies are to be abolished in Victoria and many thousands of Victorians will be seriously inconvenienced. Since the introduction of Medicare, those Australians with private health insurance living in areas outside capital cities-in areas such as Colac and Geelong-have been able to present their Medicare claims at their fund office where their private health fund has been a sub-agent for Medicare.

SPEECH.PARA: Regional Medicare agencies were established in the first place for the convenience of clients and to maintain the level of service they had been used to prior to the introduction of Medicare. It has been a great help to people in regional areas who have had access to a one-stop shop for medical refunds. If the Government goes ahead with its plan to discontinue the service it will mean that many rural Australians will have to travel to major centres to lodge their Medicare claims or rely on the postal system.

Currently Medicare agencies receive a proportion of the fee in return for assessing the claim. They handle more than 200,000 claims in Victoria each year and more than 900,000 throughout Australia. The savings estimated in the Budget Papers amount to the commission paid to the agencies for servicing the claims only-all the accompanying work is done free of charge to the Government. The private funds, which double as Medicare agencies, not only are providing a service to Medicare customers, but also are actually saving the Government money. The paltry amount that the Government would save by cutting out the Medicare agencies would disappear in a flash if Medicare were to be saddled with the processing of an additional 900,000 claims. Medicare would need to increase its staff dramatically and probably increase its premises. This would undoubtedly mean increased government spending.

It is quite obvious that the Government's real intention is to open up Medicare-Medibank Private offices in regional areas where the agencies are currently operating. This would greatly advantage Medibank Private over the private health insurance funds. The Health Insurance Commission (HIC) has never been in favour of Medicare agencies being operated by private health insurance funds. Quite clearly the idea behind the Government's decision is to squeeze private funds out altogether and promote the one-stop Medicare-Medibank Private shop.

If the Government were realistic about cutting health costs, it would seriously consider the proposal put forward by the Voluntary Health Insurance Associations of Australia (VHIAA) that all private health funds become Medicare agencies. They provide the service to the customers, do the job far better at less cost and such a proposal would allow for the immediate closure of 264 Medicare offices.

In 1985-86 only 27 million Medicare claims out of a total of 121 million-or 22.83 per cent-were over-the-counter cash transactions. These could be handled by the private health insurance funds as Medicare agents. The Health Insurance Commission could administer the large majority of cheque and bulk-billing transactions. According to the HIC's annual accounts, it costs around $130m to administer the refund component of Medicare.

Even under this so-called free and equitable health system, 50 per cent of Australians prefer to take out private health insurance. By making private health insurance funds Medicare agents and closing all existing medicare offices, the VHIAA estimates an immediate saving of $65m. Half the population already has private health cover so it is absurd to double up on administrative costs at the expense of the taxpayer. The VHIAA proposal has great merit. It would mean a more efficient administration, it would use existing resources and it would save the Government an immediate $65m. Medibank Private would be forced to stand on its own feet and any hidden advantage currently enjoyed through sharing office facilities with Medicare would no longer exist. Private health funds would have greater incentives to provide a better service and free market forces would prevail. Above all, the customer would benefit from a better service at no extra cost to the taxpayer. The Government's claim to save $1.5m by cancelling Medicare agencies is meaningless.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chynoweth Mr R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The passage of time and, indeed, the beneficial art policies of this Government have enabled many entertaining biographies from that of Phar Lap's strapper to that of the doyen of the Australian Labor Party, Arthur Calwell, to gain prominence amongst the general public. However, the champion of one long life drama that should inspire the nation's scriptwriters remains incarcerated in a broom cupboard of the Commonwealth Bank in Melbourne-or at least his ghost and portrait do.

SPEECH.PARA: Alas, it seems that perpetual obscurity is to be the fate of the man who tried to champion the currency of banking in Australia, who was 50 years ahead of his time in working for the introduction of pensions, who moved successfully to prevent barmaids from pulling a beer until 1967, who wisely saw smoking as detrimental to the health and intelligence of all Australians, who helped to get under way a trans-continental railway, and who was a major architect of the decision to site the national capital in Canberra, having previously suggested his own State of Tasmania, patently because history has shown that all the brains and diligent workers came from frigid climates. This celebrity brought such wit and charm to the politician's vernacular and possessed such unceasing energy that one is puzzled to determine whether his life was one extremely entertaining story-undoubtedly guaranteeing its commercial success today-or a concoction of the colonial capers that characterised the day.

Nonetheless, from the moment and place of birth, his life has been shrouded in fascinating controversy and many honours. This character is probably the first person to erect a tent outside the Federal Parliament, when in 1901 he chose this course of action to underscore his point to the Speaker about the inadequate salaries of parliamentarians. He was certainly the first member for Darwin, a largely rural electorate, and was elected upon a promise to `ring-bark the cockies by putting an excise on their spuds'. It was he who proposed that Caucus, rather than the Prime Minister, select all Labor Ministers. This action precipitated our leading light's entry into a future Cabinet, although an oversight still allows the Prime Minister to distribute portfolios.

However, the real mark of the man was his all consuming desire to establish the Commonwealth Bank. He called for it more than anyone else. He even wore two guns to a Cabinet meeting to emphasise his determination over the project. He saw clearly that Australia needed a central bank of issue, deposit, reserve, and exchange, and that there was much advantage to be gained from having a government bank actively compete with the private banks. His proposals were largely innovative. His actions in gaining approval for the bank were purely ingenious. He assembled a group of factional colleagues under the banner of the `torpedo brigade' to support his plans and once sat in the parlour car of a Sydney-bound train, quietly reading a newspaper, to overhear the discussions of a delegation of private bankers opposed to the Commonwealth Bank. He even flouted legalities, when he used the signature on a letter from a colleague who was away on leave of absence, to force a proxy vote on the Bank. Whilst the Bank opened its doors on 15 July 1912, it was only a pale shadow of the vision this far-seeing, forceful and stubborn hero had.

His life should serve as an inspiration to all Australians to better this great nation. I just hope that the Commonwealth Bank trustees soon see fit to extricate his regal portrait from its broom closet in Melbourne's Collins Street and reposition it where a more appreciative audience can pay its respects to the father of our biggest bank. Moreover, I hope that those in search of a worthy story soon throw light upon this most captivating character's life. The story of King O'Malley is worth telling. Indeed, it is worth telling well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the town of Peak Hill in my electorate of Parkes lives a constituent, a Mr Dudley Francis. He has been a general foreman of the Parkes Shire Council for many years and has always carried out his job in a conscientious and thoroughly professional manner. Back in the 1970s he decided to join the Federated Municipal and Shire Employees Union of Australia. However, the union only came near him when they wanted his union dues, so he withdrew from the union by not rejoining the following year. Needless to say, the union hassled him to rejoin to get his money in all the unsubtle ways that unions usually resort to. Most workers would succumb to this sort of pressure, and I do not necessarily blame them for that, but Mr Francis is a man of unusual fortitude and, believing it was his right to do so, resisted all such attempts at coercion. After all, this was Australia, `the land of the free', and he was under the impression that compulsory unionism did not exist in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: How wrong he was. There is a clause in the rules and regulations of this union, as there is with most trade unions in this country, that one can only resign from a union if one does so in writing to the secretary of the union. The rules also stipulate that one must give three months notice of resignation and, further, one is only allowed to resign if one is a fully paid-up member of the union. This comes about because of section 145 of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act with which unions must comply if they are to be registered. If honourable members think about those stipulations for a moment I think they will agree that they are quite outrageous. Imagine if they applied to other organisations such as golf clubs or Rotary clubs. If, for example, one decides one wants to give up golf and take on lawn bowls for whatever reason, one simply lets one's membership lapse and joins the bowling club. Think of the outcry if one had to give three months notice in writing while still a member to every organisation one belonged to before one could pull out of it.

This requirement by trade unions which they eagerly enforce is totally unreasonable and un-Australian. It is indicative of the draconian means trade unions resort to in trying to keep their unwilling memberships. Because of this unjust clause, earlier this year Mr Francis was served a summons demanding that he pay union dues back for the last eight or nine years for which he was not a member. Fortunately the `statute of limitations' restricts the union to collecting only six years back dues. In the end, after considerable argument and legal fees, Mr Francis was forced by mounting costs into making an out-of-court settlement of three years union dues, plus the current year's union dues, plus legal fees, plus the union's annual picnic day fee for the last six years. He also had to sign a deduction authority for future membership to be deducted from his wages. So Mr Francis, who after trying for nigh on a decade to get out of a union, is still forced, by law, to be a member of that union.

Three shearers that I know of found themselves in a similar situation. They decided to drop out of the Australian Workers Union after 1983 because of their dissatisfaction with that union. However, again because of this ridiculous resignation clause, they were summonsed. But these three Australians had the guts, like Mr Francis, to stand up and fight, and took their case to the Goulburn court. On 4 September 1987, the Chief Industrial Magistrate, Mr George Miller, determined that the shearers had not correctly resigned and forced them to pay their 1986 subscriptions of $115. He also hit them with the $3,600 legal costs of the trade union. However, he determined that the union must summons its members within six months of their subscriptions falling due so he waived the unpaid dues for 1984 and 1985 and awarded legal costs of $750 against the union. However, the shearers were also up for overall legal costs approaching $10,000.

I therefore alert all trade unionists that if their subscriptions fall due on, say, 1 August, the union can prosecute them any time after the end of that month and before 1 February the following year. One also cannot resign from a union during the months of May, June or July unless one pays the following year's dues. The point should be made that when one joins a union, one is not given a copy of the union rules which would alert one to section 145. This should be rectified. One is also not given a reminder notice that next year's fees are due, which again is unreasonable. The whole subject has many unsatisfactory areas that I believe the Minister should investigate, and as well section 145 should be deleted from the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. It is nothing more nor less than a clause that leads to extortion within the trade union movement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Anglo American Corporation is a very large company by any standard of judgment. It is a very large company in world terms. It is a massive company in terms of its native South Africa. I therefore feel somewhat uneasy about what appears to be the course the Western Australian Government has set upon in giving the Kalgoorlie tailings dumps to the Anglo American Corporation to treat. This Corporation has had an annual lease on these dumps for eight years. A tailings lease requires one to remove and treat the dumps within the terms of the licence. If there are more dumps than can be treated in one year it is the usual policy of the Government to extend the licence. However, in eight years Anglo American has not treated one ounce of these dumps but it has had its licence renewed annually.

SPEECH.PARA: Recently Anglo American was taken to court by a local company which had been seeking for some time to treat these dumps, but the warden did not make a decision. He said that he was not in a position to take the tailings dumps from Anglo American because it did not have them. I would have thought that was clear evidence that other people could apply for the licence, but it looks like the Western Australian Government, through its wholly owned subsidiary, Goldcorp, is going to enter into a joint venture with Anglo American, taking a 15 per cent position. The people of Kalgoorlie have endured the dust and the inconvenience of those dumps for 80 years, and I believe the people of Kalgoorlie are entitled to get at least something back from the treatment of those dumps. They are an enormous resource. Anglo American admits that there is close to half a billion dollars worth of gold contained within the dumps, although it says that it expects to get out only about $200m worth at today's prices.

There is one company, a local company called Goult Pro Partners, entirely Australian-owned, which treated in fact 186,000 tonnes of those dumps when they belonged to the previous owner. It was able to extract more gold from those dumps than Anglo American said was in them, which is not a bad effort, and it certainly indicates that there is no technological transfer from Anglo American to Australian interests.

I doubt whether there is any part of the whole of this nation that has contributed as much to the common weal as the gold fields. They are areas of great historical significance and they have made a great contribution to our export earnings over many years. But this area is one of the greatest areas of poverty in terms of public facilities. Kalgoorlie is now a town of some 30,000 people, I would estimate, which does not have a venue where visiting groups can perform, so denying the people of Kalgoorlie these advantages.

The Anglo American Corporation says that as it is operating under its Australian subsidiary, Anglo American Pacific, it is only 62 per cent South African-owned, and it intends to water this down by allowing the Western Australian Goldcorp, which is presently a subsidiary of the Western Australian Development Corporation, to take out 15 per cent. The reality is that Anglo American will retain 49 per cent and management, and that, in anyone's terms is control; it is total control. Not only that; the institutions which it elects to sell to are always institutions in which it has very strong interests. Honourable members might have noticed recently that the Newmont operations in America have been successfully taken over by the British company, Consolidated Goldfields, which in turn is owned by Anglo American. So we can see how incestuous this whole thing is. Anglo American is probably responsible for 70 per cent or more of South Africa's gold production, and it is clearly trying to establish itself as the controller of Australia's gold mining industry.

I think there is an enormous amount of hypocrisy in this situation. I think it is something that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Foreign Investment Review Board ought to be looking at, and it is something that the West Australian Government must examine its conscience about. As a member of parliament, I abhor hypocrisy. I believe that the sanctions we impose on South Africa do far more damage than good, for I am aware that in terms of economic downturn, there are no advances for democracy. In fact, democracy cannot survive in that climate. It cannot survive in South Africa any more than it can survive anywhere else in the world. So while we go down this rather fruitless and pointless path, yet hand the Anglo American Corporation $200m on a plate, I think we must really examine our consciences.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Webster Mr A.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —As we all know, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has, over the last few days, been in Ireland lauding the contribution of the Irish to the Australian Labor Party (ALP) and Australia. In one address, according to reports, he highlighted the influence of Irish Australians who have provided, as he said, his Party's spirit, principles, philosophy and leadership. Tonight I want to talk about one Irish-born Australian in my electorate who is keen to influence ALP principles and philosophy in 1987. His name is Jim Dunlop. Jim lives with his family in the Hawkesbury area of my electorate of Macquarie. He migrated to Australia in 1969 from Banbridge, County Down, in Ireland. For nearly 20 years he has contributed to his new country by the hard work he has put into a machine operating business in Sydney. At the moment, however, Jim is unable to run his business on building sites in Sydney. The reason? He opposes compulsory unionism and has spoken out against the damage union militancy is doing to workers and small businesses. Because of his stand and the subsequent union black ban, employers are effectively locking him out.

SPEECH.PARA: The Prime Minister told us in this place in April that there is no such thing as compulsory unionism. There are closed shops, but not compulsory unionism. According to the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Willis), closed shops are voluntary agreements which suit unions and employers. The euphemism and semantic dishonesty of this Government on the question of this coercion, which is compulsory unionism, is quite shameful. As the Australian editorialised on the Minister's views on closed shops, compulsory unionism arises from the weakness or duplicity of employers who sacrifice individual rights and freedoms for industrial peace. It said:

. . . closed shops neglect the fundamental rights of the workers the unions represent: under the closed shop they have the freedom either to join a union or to join the dole queue. This is as compulsory as unionism can be.

Jim Dunlop and the livelihood of his family have been sacrificed for the sake of industrial peace. I am not sure which is the more reprehensible: the cowardice and/or duplicity of employers, or the standover tactics and contempt for freedom which characterise some unionism in this country.

I want to commend Jim Dunlop. He is refusing to give in to the unions. He and his family are giving the principles upon which this country was built the honour they are due. Jim Dunlop's determined defence of his rights and the principles involved represent the real contribution Irish men and women have made to this great country. His case highlights the discrepancy between the image the Prime Minister projects overseas, and the reality of his policies for the average worker such as Irishman Jim Dunlop. Perhaps when the Prime Minister returns to Australia he might redirect his respect for the Irish in general towards one particular Irish-born Australian whose circumstances reflect all that is wrong with our economy but whose spirit we will be celebrating in 1988.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I would like to acquaint the House with a significant event that occurred today in Wollongong, and that was the meeting of the board of directors of the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd (BHP). As part of the meeting of the board of directors, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) was also invited to attend and officially to recommission a major refurbishment of a section of BHP's Port Kembla steelworks. I say that it is significant because BHP's board of directors attendance in Wollongong was the subject of a great degree of scepticism on the part of a number of people. The reason for that was the decision that was announced a couple of weeks ago, that due to economic circumstances in the steel industry, BHP would find it necessary over the next 15 months to retrench upwards of 4,000 steel workers from its major steel plants around Australia. The sad part about that is that as part of that plan, upwards of 2,600 steel workers are to be retrenched in BHP's operations at Port Kembla. I say it is sad because, if we look at the history of the plant at Port Kembla over the last six or seven years, we see that it is indeed a sorry history. And it is so simply because, in the early 1980s the work force at BHP's plant at Port Kembla numbered about 23,000. By the end of the 1986 that work force had dwindled to about 13,000, and as I understand at the moment, about 12,600 workers are associated with BHP's works at Port Kembla.

SPEECH.PARA: Clearly this announcement that a further 2,600 workers are to be retrenched over the next 15 months means that steelworks employment at Port Kembla will be down to around 10,000. The reason being advanced by BHP is a need to increase productivity. It says that it has done all it possibly can in terms of refurbishment and reinvestment in the industry at Port Kembla and right around Australia. I commend BHP for its investment program under the terms of the steel industry plan. In Wollongong alone BHP has invested upwards of $800m on new plant and equipment. In other parts of its steel works at Newcastle and Whyalla it has invested an additional $250m, taking its investment totally right around Australia to well in excess of $1 billion. That is way in excess of the commitment it gave under the steel industry plan when it was put in place.

I reiterate that I commend BHP for that initiative. I believe it was long overdue. The practices that it followed in the 1950s, 1960s, and indeed the 1970s, of trying to increase steel production in Australia by increasing its workforce obviously was something of a short-sighted approach. It did not take into consideration the massive technical advances that were being made overseas. But what does concern me is the way in which this approach to increases in productivity is being tackled in view of the refurbishment that has gone on. I understand that golden handshakes and voluntary retirement schemes will be offered to many of these people.

But what we will find, as we have found over the last six or seven years in the Illawarra community-I know it is also the case in Whyalla and the Hunter district-is a very sad lack of skills development associated with the steel industry and that will translate into the general community in all of these areas. The sad fact is that places such as Wollongong have for many years been economically dependent upon the steel industry and the coal industry. If we are to see these retrenchments take place, there has to be concern by not only the Federal Government but also the State and local governments for the future of these areas.

I ask BHP to look very carefully at the need for those retrenchments of the magnitude that it has suggested. I have had discussions with the company and I understand its point of view. I have had discussions with the trade union movement and I sympathise entirely with the views that it has, representing the views of its workforce. I hope that some compromise position can be reached. I pledge my support for that, and the support of my colleagues, the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West), the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) and the honourable member for Hughes (Mr Tickner), who represent the south coast as we look towards that solution.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I open my remarks by congratulating the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth) for a very entertaining adjournment speech tonight. I am here tonight to raise a matter regarding a phone call I received last week from a gentleman naming himself to me as Kieran Murphy. Kieran Murphy said to me that he is a reporter from the Northern Guardian, a newspaper that I know to be published in the town of Carnarvon, where I lived for many years. He was seeking my comments on some circumstances he had observed in Carnarvon and in particular the visit, he claimed, to his office, the Northern Guardian newspaper office in Carnarvon, of a Mr David Cox. Mr Cox went to his office, requesting the opportunity to go through back issues of the paper for as far as possible and inferred that the reason for his visit was to get information on one Wilson Tuckey, or in fact, a company which is the property of Wilson Tuckey. David Cox told Murphy that he had also visited the Carnarvon court house and a Mr Frank Baxter, a known enemy of Wilson Tuckey and a person who is prepared at any time to hand out information, probably erroneous, on Mr Tuckey. In fact, Mr Baxter has a number of files which, as I have said, are quite erroneous and which get him into trouble at times. Mr Cox had also visited Mr Baxter. I am not sure what he learned, even at the Carnarvon court house, although I am aware of a by-election about to be conducted there and that the clerk of the court is the candidate for the Australian Labor Party.

SPEECH.PARA: David Cox also claimed that he was the Canberra Press Secretary of Senator Peter Walsh. Consequently, Mr Murphy rang Senator Walsh to query him on this matter and Mr Murphy tells me that Senator Walsh dropped the phone in his ear. Mr Cox then rang Mr Murphy at a later date, claiming to be back in Canberra, and said that in fact he had not been in Carnarvon for the purposes he mentioned to Mr Murphy but had in fact been there on constituent work for Senator Walsh. I do not know why Senator Walsh, if he had some genuine constituent work in Western Australia in the town of Carnarvon-600 miles north of Perth, and I guess some 3,000-odd miles from Canberra-did not send one of his specially trained electorate staff to Carnarvon to undertake that work. Rather he chose to send his Press Secretary from Canberra.

What is more, I am not complaining about his dirt digging. Anybody who wants to check on Wilson Tuckey and who starts turning over stones with his name on them will find that they are all round on the edges. If anybody wants to go out in the fields and plough them again, seeking information on Wilson Tuckey, he will be up to his knees in dust because so many have been there before.

In fact, in recent times, through the activities of the State Government, we saw the shire, of which I had been a member for 16 years, sacked after I had left it, on the grounds that it had somehow failed to administer properly the health legislation. A commissioner was put in there for six months. I do not know what he looked for, but he did not find anything. Certain members of the Trades and Labour Council took what was, in fact, a very erroneous report to the police and had the police look into it. That did not work so they went to the Ombudsman and told him that the police had to work harder. That did not work either. There is a simple reason for all of this; the information that people have dreamed up in their imaginations just does not exist. But I am not complaining about that. It is all fair game with me.

But I am concerned about the cost for the Australian taxpayers. Having looked at the recent declaration of travelling allowances and such relating to consultants and staff of Ministers, we find that Senator Walsh's staff consumed $12,913 of the public's money, and I think that probably another $2,000 has been added on what obviously was a failed venture. When Senator Walsh previously mentioned his Carnarvon file, I begged him to produce it. I gave him the opportunity to do it under parliamentary privilege; I did not even make that rather spurious statement, `Take it outside'. But he has failed to do that. It is now a week since he sent his emissary at taxpayers' expense all the way to Carnarvon, but he has failed to do it. I disagree with that. When I want to rake up a bit of evidence on Senator Walsh, I just go down to the non-members' bar and check up on what he used to do with Harriet--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker--
—The honourable member is a bit late. I do not put the cost to the taxpayer. The point about it is--
—I take a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker.
—Order! I am not quite sure what remarks the honourable member for O'Connor was attempting to make there, but they probably should be withdrawn.
—Well, I do not think they should be withdrawn, Mr Deputy Speaker. I will do so in your interest, but I have not insulted the honourable senator in any way.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lamb Mr A.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise a matter which in turn has been raised with me by two correspondents. I have received two letters on the subject. It relates to the fact that in the Hall of Memory at the Australian War Memorial there is no reference on the many plaques in the cloisters to the contribution that Australian defence forces made in Burma, particularly in the period 1941-45. It seems that there was an oversight or that some decision was made and, when the 30 or so plaques in those cloisters were established, the theatre of war and campaign area of Burma was omitted.

SPEECH.PARA: All of us here are familiar with the contribution that Australians made to the liberation of Burma and to the defence of Australia and the end of World War II in that area. My father, a member of parliament for Victoria, died on the Burma railway and was in fact the only Australian member of parliament in our history to die at war. It seems incongruous and wrong that he and his colleagues, his comrades in arms-some 1,500 or so of them-who died on the infamous Burma railway are not remembered in some way on a plaque in those cloisters.

I understand that originally some 275 or so theatres of war, areas of combat, were considered by the Council of the Australian War Memorial but that, as it so happened, in the first instance only 60 were selected and, after further consideration, only 30 remained. It is also unfortunate that the Council would have to consider removing one of those plaques relating to one of those theatres of war in order to include the Burma theatre. However, the Council agrees that the omission of Burma was an oversight and that it should be recognised. I do not envy the Council's task. It seems to me that all sacrifices for this country, all those who have died, have an equal place in our memories and that no single plaque should be sacrificed in order to include Burma. I do not know the solution. The Council has my sympathy and I wish it well at one of its future meetings when it has to consider this dilemma of how to recognise the contribution of the people in the Burma campaign without displacing plaques to the memory of others who have died for this country.
